ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Board of zoning appeals, § 32-50; tree board, § 42-41 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-201. - Appointment of members of boards, commissions, committees or other entities. 
The mayor and council may appoint citizens to serve on boards, commissions, committees, or other entities to serve the public. 
(Ord. No. 668, § 1, 12-17-2007)  
Sec. 2-202. - Suspension or removal of appointees. 
Citizens appointed by the mayor and council to serve on boards, commissions, committees, etc., may be suspended or removed for cause. The existence of cause shall be discussed by the mayor and council in executive session as permitted by the Freedom of Information Act, S. C. Code 1976, § 30-4-70(a)(1) and the determination of removal shall be by vote in public session declaring a vacancy in the position without a statement of cause. 
Any fact which, in the discretion of the mayor and council, is deemed to adversely affect the public interest including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Poor attendance at meetings. Members who miss four meetings per year or three consecutive meetings without cause will result in dismissal; 
(2)  Charged with or conviction of a criminal offense; 
(3)  Acts of moral turpitude; 
(4)  Poor health; 
(5)  Conduct which creates or constitutes a conflict of interest; 
(6)  Conduct which causes an appointee to be disqualified to serve, etc., may constitute cause. 
(Ord. No. 668, § 1, 12-17-2007; Ord. of 7-21-2008)  
Secs. 2-203—2-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PLANNING COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Local planning commissions, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-7-310 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-221. - Created; purpose. 
In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote the public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the Mauldin planning commission referred to as the "planning commission," is created and established, to be organized, empowered and governed by the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1994, § 2-161)  
Sec. 2-222. - Composition; appointment of members; terms; vacancies; compensation. 
The planning commission shall consist of seven members, to be appointed by the city council. Members shall be residents of the city at the time of their appointment and shall maintain residency throughout their term of office. The term of office of the members shall be three years. Planning commission seats shall be designated by number. Upon initial appointment, the term of office for seats 1, 4, and 7 shall expire on June 30, 2005. The term of office for seats 2 and 5 shall expire on June 30, 2004. The term of office for seats 3 and 6 shall expire on June 30, 2003. Thereafter, all appointments shall be for three-year terms to expire on June 30 of the appropriate year. No person shall be eligible for more than two consecutive terms, except that any member who is first appointed to less than a full three-year term shall not have that term counted toward the consecutive term limitation. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the city council. The city council shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause including, but not limited to, unexcused absence from three meetings. All members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. 
(Code 1994, § 2-162; Ord. No. 563, § 1(2-162), 8-19-2002)  
Sec. 2-223. - Organization; rules; records; meetings; employees and staff; expenditures. 
(a)  The planning commission shall elect a chair and vice-chair from among its members. The term of the chair and other officers shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. The commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or an employee of the city council or of the planning commission. 
(b)  The planning commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its recommendations, transactions, findings and determinations and shall meet at the call of the chair and at such times as the chair or commission may determine. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public, and all records of the commission shall be a public record. 
(c)  The commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may make expenditures for salaries of any employees and staff, contracts with consultants and purchases of required equipment and supplies. The expenditures of the commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for such purpose by the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 2-163)  
Sec. 2-224. - Powers and duties generally. 
From and after the time when the planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers and shall have adopted its rules or procedures, the commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in S.C. Code 1976, §§ 6-7-10—6-7-1280. In general, the planning commission shall have the power to: 
(1)  Prepare and revise periodically a comprehensive plan and program for the development of its jurisdiction as provided in S.C. Code 1976, § 6-7-330. 
(2)  Prepare and recommend for adoption to the city council as a means for implementing the plan and program: 
a.  Zoning ordinances or resolutions, and maps and appropriate revisions thereof for its jurisdiction. 
b.  Regulations for the subdivision of land and appropriate revisions thereof within its jurisdiction and to administer the regulations that may be adopted. 
c.  An official map and appropriate revision thereof, showing the exact location of existing or proposed public street, highway and utility rights-of-way and public building sites, together with regulations to control the erection of buildings or other structures or changes in land use within such rights-of-way, building sites or open spaces within its political jurisdiction or a specified portion thereof. 
d.  A capital program for its jurisdiction, based on the comprehensive plan and the capital improvements necessary to implement the plan. Such a capital program shall include an annual capital budget, based on estimates of the cost of proposed projects and the means of financing them. The commission shall submit the capital program, including the capital budget, to the city council as directed. 
(3)  Establish principles and policies for guiding action in the development of the area. 
(4)  Prepare and recommend to the city council for adoption ordinances promoting orderly development in accordance with the comprehensive plan. 
(5)  Determine whether specific proposed developments conform to the principles and requirements of the comprehensive plan for the growth and improvement of the area. 
(6)  Review and recommend to the city council any needed changes in the zoning ordinance and the map of the city. 
(7)  Prepare and recommend for adoption subdivision regulations, and to administer such regulations. 
(8)  Keep the city council and the general public informed and advised as to these matters. 
(Code 1994, § 2-164)  
Secs. 2-225—2-260. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CODE OF ETHICS 
 
Sec. 2-261. - Declaration of policy. 
The proper operation of democratic government requires that public officials and employees be independent, impartial, and responsible to the people; that government decisions and policy be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, there is hereby established a code of ethics for all officials and employees, whether elected or appointed, paid or unpaid. The purpose of this code is to establish ethical standards of conduct for all such officials and employees by setting forth those acts or actions that are incompatible with the best interests of the city and by directing disclosure by such officials and employees of private financial or other interests in matters affecting the city. The provisions and purpose of this code and such rules and regulations as may be established are hereby declared to be in the best interests of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 2-186)  
Sec. 2-262. - Responsibilities of public office. 
Public officials and employees are agents of public purpose and hold office for the benefit of the public. They are bound to uphold the Constitution of the United States and the constitution of this state and to carry out impartially the laws of the nation, state and city and thus to foster respect for all government. They are bound to observe in their official acts the highest standards of morality and to discharge faithfully the duties of their office regardless of personal considerations, recognizing that the public interest must be their primary concern. Their conduct in both their official and private affairs should be above reproach. 
(Code 1994, § 2-187)  
Sec. 2-263. - Avoidance of impression of corruptibility. 
Public officials and employees, whether appointed or elected, full-time or part-time, paid or unpaid, should conduct their official duties with integrity, impartiality and in the public interest. They also should conduct both their official and private affairs so as not to give a reasonable basis for the impression that any such official or employee can be improperly influenced in the performance of his official duties and in so doing comply with all disclosure requirements of this article. Such official or employee should so conduct himself as to maintain public confidence in his performance of his public trust and in the government he represents. He should not be a source of embarrassment to that government and should avoid even the appearance of conflict between his public duties and private interests. 
(Code 1994, § 2-188)  
Sec. 2-264. - Dedicated service. 
(a)  All officials and employees of the city should be loyal to the political objectives expressed by the electorate and the programs developed to attain those objectives. Appointive officials and employees should adhere to the rules of work and performance established as the standard for their positions by the appropriate authority. 
(b)  Officials and employees should not exceed their authority or breach the law or ask others to do so, and they should work in full cooperation with other public officials and employees unless prohibited from so doing by law or by officially recognized confidentiality of their work. 
(Code 1994, § 2-189)  
Sec. 2-265. - Fair and equal treatment. 
(a)  Interest in appointments. Canvassing of members of the council, directly or indirectly, in order to obtain preferential consideration in connection with any appointment to the municipal service shall disqualify the candidate for appointment except with reference to positions filled by appointment by the council. 
(b)  Use of public property. No official or employee shall request or permit the use of city-owned vehicles, equipment, materials or property for personal convenience or profit, except when such services are available to the public generally or are provided as municipal policy for the use of such official or employee in the conduct of official business. 
(c)  Obligations to citizens. No official or employee shall grant any special consideration, treatment or advantage to any citizen beyond that which is available to every other citizen. 
(Code 1994, § 2-190)  
Sec. 2-266. - Discrimination in appointments. 
No person shall be appointed to or removed from, or in any way favored or discriminated against with respect to any appointive administrative office because of his race, religion, sex, age, national origin or political opinions or affiliations, if otherwise qualified for the position or office. However, this provision does not impair administrative discretion in determining the requirements of a position or in job assignment of a person holding such position, subject to review as provided by city policy. 
(Code 1994, § 2-191)  
Sec. 2-267. - Trust of public funds. 
No elected or appointive official or employee shall misuse the public funds entrusted to his care. All reimbursed expenses should be accompanied by valid documentation and be consistent with the city policy. 
(Code 1994, § 2-192)  
Sec. 2-268. - Conflict of interest. 
No councilmember, other city official or city employee, whether full-time or part-time, paid or unpaid, shall engage in any business or transaction or shall have a financial or other personal interest, direct or indirect, which is incompatible with the proper discharge of his official duties in the public interest or would tend to impair his independence of judgment or action in the performance of his official duties. Personal or indirect as distinguished from financial interests include an interest arising from blood or marriage relationships or close business or political association. In any such instances in which a conflict of interest is possible, the councilmember shall disclose in writing the matter requiring action or decision and the nature of the potential conflict of interest with respect to such action or decision and deliver a copy of such statement to the city administrator, mayor or presiding officer of the city council and further shall disqualify himself from voting, participating in any discussion or deliberations regarding the matter and further disqualify himself from acting in any official capacity with regard to the matter. Any nonelected city official or city employee shall disclose in writing the matter requiring action or decision and the nature of the potential conflict of interest with respect to such action or decision and deliver a copy of such statement to the city administrator and further shall disqualify himself from participating in any discussion or deliberations regarding the matter and further disqualify himself from acting in any official capacity with regard to the matter. No councilmember, other city official or city employee, whether full-time or part-time, paid or unpaid, shall directly or indirectly participate in any contract with the city. He shall not benefit from any transaction, which is to be paid in whole or in part by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 2-193) 
State Law reference— Conflict of interest of municipal officer or employee, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-130.  
Sec. 2-269. - Disclosure of income. 
An official or employee, whether paid or unpaid, who has a direct or indirect financial or other interest in any transaction, the disposition of which may be influenced by his official position or action, shall disclose all sources of income and the nature and extent of any personal interest in such transaction as an officer, agent, member or owner of any business entity or other association which is subject to regulation by the city when such income or interest may represent a substantial conflict of interest with his official duties. Such disclosure shall be made on the records of the authority constituted for that purpose or to the appointing authority. Such disclosure may be made periodically at the time designated for all such classes of officials or employees. Such disclosure shall remove any presumption of conflict of interest for any transaction where the information disclosed is pertinent. 
(Code 1994, § 2-194)  
Sec. 2-270. - Political activity. 
(a)  No appointive official or employee shall use the prestige of his position in behalf of any political party or candidate. 
(b)  No appointive official or employee shall orally, by letter, or otherwise, solicit or be in any manner concerned in soliciting any assessment, subscription or contribution to any political party; nor shall he be a party to such solicitation by others. Such appointed officials and employees shall not take an active part in political campaigns for candidates while at work for the city. 
(c)  No official or employee, whether elected or appointed, shall promise an appointment to any municipal position as a reward for any political activity. 
(d)  No councilmember, appointive official, candidate, or city employee may utilize city property in any manner in a political campaign; however, public facilities may be rented or used for political meetings and other campaign-related purposes if they are available on similar terms to all candidates. 
(Code 1994, § 2-195; Ord. No. 629, § 1, 6-26-2006)  
Sec. 2-271. - Applicability of Code. 
(a)  When a councilmember or other official or employee has doubt as to the applicability of a provision of this code to a particular situation, he should advise, seek counsel from the city attorney or state attorney general on ethical conduct constituted for the implementation of this code for an advisory opinion and be guided by that opinion when given. The councilmember or other official or employee shall have the opportunity to present his interpretation of the facts at issue and of the applicable provision of this code before such advisory decision is made. This code shall be operative in all instances covered by its provisions except when superseded by an applicable statutory or charter provision and statutory or charter action is mandatory, or when the application of a statutory or charter provision is discretionary but determined to be more appropriate or desirable. 
(b)  If an employee requests such an opinion, the city administrator must be advised and promptly forward that request as noted in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1994, § 2-196)  
Sec. 2-272. - Sanctions. 
(a)  Violation of any provision of this code should raise conscientious questions for the councilmember, other official or city employee concerned as to whether voluntary resignation or other action is indicated to promote the best interest of the city. Violation may constitute a cause for suspension, removal from office or employment, or other disciplinary action. 
(b)  Any councilmember, city employee or official who is indicted in a general sessions court or a federal court for a crime that is a felony, a crime that involves moral turpitude, a crime that has a sentence of two or more years, or a crime that violates election laws shall be suspended immediately. This suspension will remain in effect until such individual is acquitted or convicted. In case of conviction, the position shall be declared vacant, once appeals are exhausted. 
(c)  For members of council, if an election intervenes between the time of the suspension and final conclusion of the indictment, he shall again be suspended at the beginning of the term. The suspended councilmember will not, at any time, participate in the business of the city council or operation of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 2-197)  
Secs. 2-273—2-300. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PURCHASING 
 
Sec. 2-301. - Purchasing agent; specified duties. 
The city administrator or an employee designated by the city administrator shall be the purchasing agent for the city. He shall be responsible for: 
(1)  Compliance of the purchasing policy included in the Accounting Manual as adopted by city council. 
(2)  Approval of all large purchase orders. 
(3)  Notification of committee on all nonbudgeted large purchases that require shifts of budgeted funds within a department. 
(4)  Notification of council on all budgeted large purchases where the following exists: 
a.  Bid is more than budgeted amount. 
b.  Low bid is not accepted. 
(5)  Presiding over all formal bid openings. 
(Code 1994, § 2-221)  
Sec. 2-302. - Formal contract procedure. 
All supplies and contractual services regardless of funding source, except as otherwise provided, shall be bid in accordance with the purchasing policy. No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this section. All sales of personal property which has become obsolete or unusable, when the estimated value shall exceed five thousand dollars, shall be sold by formal written contract to the highest responsible bidder, after due notice inviting proposals. 
(Code 1994, § 2-222)  
Sec. 2-303. - Bidding; competitive; required exception. 
Ample opportunity for competitive bidding will be given in accordance with the purchasing policy. However, in the event of an emergency affecting the public welfare, health or safety, the provisions of this section shall not apply. A full report of the circumstances of a nonbudgeted emergency purchase shall be filed by the purchasing agent with the city council and shall be entered in the minutes of the council. 
(Code 1994, § 2-223)  
Sec. 2-304. - Award to lowest bidder; advertising; when required. 
All contracts for city improvements, materials, equipment, or services shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder; provided, however, in the case of professional services or consultants, this section shall not apply. Newspaper notices, when required by the procedures manual, shall include a general description of the articles or services to be purchased, and shall state where specifications may be secured and the time and place for opening the bid. 
(Code 1994, § 2-224)  
Sec. 2-305. - Bid deposits. 
When deemed necessary by the purchasing agent, bid deposits may be required. Upon entering a bid or proposal, bidders shall be entitled to the return of the bid deposit. A successful bidder shall forfeit any bid deposit required upon failure on his part to enter into a contract within ten days after the award; provided, however, that the city, in its uncontrolled discretion, may waive this forfeiture. 
(Code 1994, § 2-225)  
Sec. 2-306. - Sealed bid procedures. 
(a)  Sealing. Bids shall be submitted to the purchasing agent securely in an envelope, and shall be identified on the envelope in accordance with bid instructions. 
(b)  Opening. Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notices. 
(c)  Tabulation. A tabulation of all bids received shall be available for public inspection. 
(d)  Rejection of bids. The purchasing agent shall have the authority to reject all bids, parts of all bids, or all bids for any one or more supplies or contractual services included in the proposed contract, when the public interest will be served thereby. 
(e)  Bidders in default to city. The purchasing agent shall not accept the bid of a vendor or contractor who is delinquent in the payment of any moneys due the city. 
(f)  Award of contract. The contract shall be awarded as follows: 
(1)  Authority in agent. The purchasing agent shall have the authority to award contracts within the purview of this article; provided, however, that contracts are budgeted items. 
(2)  Lowest responsible bidder. Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining the "lowest responsible bidder," in addition to price, the purchasing agent shall consider: 
a.  The ability, capacity, skill, and financial resources of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required; 
b.  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference; 
c.  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder; 
d.  The quality of performance and compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to previous contracts or services; 
e.  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or contractual services to the particular use required; 
f.  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance, parts, and service for the use of the subject of the contract; 
g.  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid. 
h.  The quality and the suitability of a product for the intended use based on past performance. 
i.  The initial cost and related costs for the life of the item. 
j.  The ability, capacity and skill of the vendor to train personnel. 
(g)  Award to other than low bidder. When the award is not given to the lowest bidder, a full and complete statement of the reasons for placing the order elsewhere shall be prepared by the purchasing agent and filed with the papers relating to the transaction and reported to council. 
(h)  Tie bids; local vendors . In the tabulation of bids by the city administrator to ascertain the lowest responsible bidder, the city administrator shall, as to each local vendor, tabulate the local vendor's bid as if it were two percent below the figure actually set forth in the bid, up to a maximum of $2,500.00. The local vendor preference shall be utilized solely for the purpose of determining the lowest responsible bidder and shall not have the effect of altering the bid of any such local vendor. For the purpose of this section, a local vendor shall be a person or legal entity, which has its principal place of business located within the corporate limits of the City of Mauldin and has held a valid city business license for at least three consecutive years. The certificate claiming the local vendor preference shall accompany the bid and shall be notarized. If tie bids are received, the contract shall be awarded by drawing lots in public. 
(i)  Performance bonds. The purchasing agent shall have the authority to require a performance bond, before entering into a contract, in such form and amount as he shall find reasonable and necessary to protect the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 2-226; Ord. No. 630, § 1, 6-19-2006)  
Sec. 2-307. - Materials testing. 
The purchasing agent shall have the authority to require chemical and physical tests of samples submitted with bids and samples of deliveries which are necessary to determine their quality and conformance with the specifications. In the performance of such tests, the purchasing agent shall have the authority to make use of laboratory facilities of any agency of the city government or any outside laboratory. 
(Code 1994, § 2-227)  
Sec. 2-308. - Financial interest of city official and employees. 
The financial interest of city officials and employees is discussed in article V of this chapter, Code of Ethics. 
(Code 1994, § 2-228)  
Sec. 2-309. - Records of open market orders and bids. 
The purchasing agent shall keep a record of all open market orders and the bids submitted in competition thereon, and such records shall also be open to public inspection. 
(Code 1994, § 2-229)  
Sec. 2-310. - Stock reports. 
All offices, departments or agencies of the city government shall submit to the purchasing agent, at such times and in such form as he shall prescribe, reports showing stocks of all supplies which are no longer used or which have become obsolete, worn-out or scrapped. 
(Code 1994, § 2-230)  
Sec. 2-311. - Surplus stock. 
The purchasing agent shall have authority to transfer surplus stock to other offices, departments or agencies of the city government. 
(Code 1994, § 2-231)  
Sec. 2-312. - Supplies unsuitable for public use, sale or exchange. 
The purchasing agent shall have the authority to sell all supplies which have become unsuitable for public use, or to exchange the same for, or trade in the same on, new supplies. Such sales shall be made at auction or by bid. All moneys received from such sales shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 2-232)  
Sec. 2-313. - Cooperative purchasing. 
The purchasing agent shall have authority to join with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interests of the city would be served thereby; provided that the purchasing agent of the city has approval to make cooperative purchases of supplies, equipment, and services from the cooperating governmental agency where the cooperating agency operates under generally accepted governmental procurement standards. 
(Code 1994, § 2-233)  
Sec. 2-314. - Gifts and rebates. 
Gifts and rebates shall be in accordance with state statutes. 
(Code 1994, § 2-234)  
Sec. 2-315. - [Method to procure public infrastructure and/or public services by private development pursuant to a development agreement.] 
Whenever the city enters into a development agreement with a private developer, private property owner, or other private party or entity (hereinafter "private developer") which involves the installation of public infrastructure improvements or public services or a combination thereof then, in order to achieve efficiencies for such projects and to avoid delay in the completion of the respective projects, the city may enter into a written agreement with a private developer which permits the private developer's procurement practices to be utilized to procure the public infrastructure and/or public services to be provided by the city provided that the procurement practices ensure that the costs to the city are reasonable. Any such arrangement must be designed to secure the greatest value with the most efficient means available in accordance with reasonable business standards in order to ensure that the public investment associated with the project is reasonable and benefits the public, the city, its citizens and the private developer. Any written agreement relating to such projects must provide for the city's consent and approval of the procurement practices for the infrastructure, materials, or services to be paid for by the city and be subject to audit by the city. Such practices must assure adherence to principals of fairness, efficiency, and value for the use of public funds to benefit the public. The procurement process utilized by the private developer must include a competitive bid procedure which will ensure that the costs to the city are reasonable and will secure the greatest value for the public investment. The city will designate a representative to participate in the procurement process from its inception until the conclusion of the project. In this respect, the city shall retain the right to reject any proposals obtained for the infrastructure, materials, or services to be provided by the city. To the extent performance bonds or payment bonds are required by the general law of this state for public subdivisions, these practices shall assure their use for public improvements funded by the city. 
(Ord. No. 913, 6-17-2019)  

Chapter 3 - ADVERTISING[1]

Footnotes:
--- (1) ---
Cross reference— Advertising closing-out sales, § 11-86; advertising in lodging establishments, § 11-105.


Sec. 3-1. - Reserved.
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2003-34, adopted May 13, 2003, repealed § 3-1, which pertained to permit required for distribution of handbills and other advertising on streets, alleys and other public property and derived from Code 1980, § 7-9-1.

Sec. 3-2. - Placing advertising in or on automobiles.
No person in the city shall place or cause any commercial handbill to be placed within or upon, or under the windshield wiper of any private automobile parked upon any of the public streets of the city or in any public parking area. This shall not preclude the delivery of any handbill to an owner, occupant or person present and in charge of the vehicle willing to accept and receive the same.

(Code 1980, § 7-9-2)

Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12.

Sec. 3-3. - Use of radios, mechanical musical instruments, etc., for purposes of advertising.
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to maintain and operate in any building or on any premises in the city any radio or television device or mechanical musical instrument or device of any kind whereby the sound therefrom is cast directly upon the public streets and places in such a manner as to create unreasonably loud, excessive or disturbing noises, where the device is maintained and operated for advertising purposes or for the purpose of attracting the attention of the passing public, or which is so placed and operated that the sounds coming therefrom can be heard to the annoyance or inconvenience of travelers upon any street or public place or of persons in neighboring premises.

(Code 1980, § 7-9-3)

Cross reference— Noise generally, § 14-62.

Sec. 3-4. - Sound trucks and sound amplifying devices.
(a)Sound amplifying devices or equipment defined. The words "sound amplifying devices or equipment," as used in this section, shall mean any machine or device for the amplification of any sound.(b)Permit required for operation. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or permit to be operated in the city any sound amplifying devices or equipment for any purpose whatever, whether the same is stationary or operated from a vehicle or other carriage, unless a permit therefor has been obtained to do so from the city clerk, upon the approval of the city manager.(c)Loud and raucous noise prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person using any sound amplifying devices or equipment to make any loud and raucous noise to the disturbance of the peace. Any person to whom a permit has been issued under this section who abuses his discretion and causes or permits loud and raucous noises shall, in addition to any penalty imposed for the violation of this section, be subject to immediate revocation of the permit issued pursuant to this section.
(Code 1980, §§ 7-9-11—7-9-13)

Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12; noise generally, § 14-62.

Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 10; possession, consumption of alcoholic beverages in parks, § 30-3. 
State Law reference— Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alcoholic liquors means any spirituous malt, vinous, fermented, brewed or other liquors or any compound or mixture thereof, by whatever name called or known, which contains alcohol and used as a beverage, except those beverages specifically exempted from such definition by S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-30. 
Nonalcoholic and nonintoxicating (as applied to beverages) means all beers, ales, porter and other similar malt or fermented beverages containing not in excess of five percent of alcohol by weight, and all wines containing not in excess of 21 percent of alcohol by volume. 
(Code 1994, § 3-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definition of alcoholic liquors, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-20; definition of nonalcoholic and nonintoxicating beverages, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-4-10.  
Sec. 4-2. - Jurisdiction of municipal court; penalties. 
The municipal court and those lawfully acting as judges thereof shall try and determine all cases involving any violation of this chapter occurring within the city limits where the penalties do not exceed a fine of $100.00 or imprisonment of 30 days, except as provided in S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-4500, and such court and judges shall have jurisdiction over such criminal cases the same as that had by magistrates, with the right and duty of sending such cases occurring within the city limits but beyond their jurisdiction to try to the higher courts. Any person convicted under this chapter in the municipal court shall be treated as a municipal prisoner. 
(Code 1994, § 3-2) 
State Law reference— Jurisdiction of municipal courts relative to enforcement of state Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-4500.  
Sec. 4-3. - Violations generally. 
Any violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor, and anyone violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished at the direction of the court as provided in section 1-6 or as limited by the state statutes. 
(Code 1994, § 3-3)  
Sec. 4-4. - What constitutes prior offense. 
A conviction, plea of guilty, plea of nolo contendere or forfeiture of bond for the violation on or after March 28, 1956, of any of the laws of the state or of the United States relating to alcoholic liquor shall constitute a prior offense for the purpose of any prosecution, or for the purpose of imposition of sentence for any subsequent violation of this chapter, except as provided in S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-4220. 
(Code 1994, § 3-4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-4220.  
Sec. 4-5. - Unlawful purchase. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase or otherwise procure any alcoholic liquor other than that purchased from licensed dealers within the state, the first offense of which is a misdemeanor pursuant to S.C. Code 1976, §§ 61-6-4010—61-6-4170 and within the jurisdiction of the municipal court. 
(Code 1994, § 3-5) 
State Law reference— Unlawful purchase of alcoholic liquor, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-4050.  
Sec. 4-6. - Drinking on premises of liquor establishment. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drink alcoholic liquors on the premises of any retail, wholesale or manufacturing alcoholic liquor business or business establishment, the first offense of which is a misdemeanor pursuant to S.C. Code 1976, §§ 61-6-4010—61-6-4170 and within the jurisdiction of the municipal court. 
(Code 1994, § 3-6) 
State Law reference— Drinking alcoholic liquors on premises of liquor establishments, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-4700.  
Sec. 4-7. - Drinking in public conveyances. 
Any person who shall drink alcoholic liquor in any public conveyance in the city shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. This section shall not apply to any railroad dining or club car or to any aircraft of a commercial airline transporting passengers for hire. 
(Code 1994, § 3-7) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 61-6-4720.  
Sec. 4-8. - Open containers of alcohol while in vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any alcoholic liquor in an open container in a moving vehicle of any kind, licensed to travel in this state or any other state, that may travel upon the public highways of this state, except in the trunk or luggage compartment. 
(Code 1994, § 3-8) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 38.  
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 18. 
State Law reference— Animals, livestock and poultry, S.C. Code 1976, tit. 47. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise provided, the following terms and phrases shall have the following meanings in this chapter: 
Abandonment: Deserting, forsaking, or intending to give up absolutely any animal without provided adequate food, water, and sanitary shelter for 48 hours or longer. 
Animal: Any nonhuman living vertebrate, whether wild or domesticated. 
Animal control officer: The person or office designated by the city to enforce this chapter. 
Animal shelter: Any facility or premises designated by the city for the purpose of the impoundment, care, or destruction of animals help pursuant to this chapter. 
Cat: All members of the feline family. 
Contract enforcement agency: The South Carolina Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, doing business as Greenville Humane Society, or such other organization or business, designated by the city manager to administer and enforce this chapter. 
Domesticated animal: A dog or cat as defined herein. 
Dog: All members of the canine family. 
Euthanasia: The act of putting to death in a humane manner. 
Impound: To confine humanely while providing adequate food, water and ventilation. 
Kennel: Any facility wherein a person, business entity, or organization regularly keeps six or more dogs or other animals for any purpose and receives compensation for the service or for the sale of animals. 
Neutered male: Any male animal which has been operated on to prevent reproduction. 
Owner or keeper: Any person who: 
(a)  Has a right of property in an animal; 
(b)  Keeps or harbors an animal or has it in the person's care, or acts as its custodian for ten days or more; or 
(c)  Permits for 48 hours or longer an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by the person. 
Running at large: Being off the premises of the owner or keeper and not under the physical control of the owner or keeper by means of a leash or other similar restraining device. 
Spayed female: Any female animal which has been operated on to prevent conception. 
Stray animal: An animal running at large with no identifiable owner. 
Swine: Any hog, boar, pig (including pot-bellied pigs), peccary, or like animal of the suidae or tayassuidae families. 
Under restraint: An animal is under restraint when it is on the premises of its owner or keeper or when it is accompanied by its owner or keeper and under control of such person by means of a leash or other similar restraining device. 
Vicious or dangerous animal: As used in this section "vicious or dangerous animal" means an animal of the canine or feline family which the owner knows or reasonably should know has a propensity, tendency, or disposition to attack unprovoked, cause injury, or otherwise endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals which: 
(a)  Makes an unprovoked attack that causes bodily injury to a human being and the attack occurs in a place other than the place where the animal is confined as required by Mauldin Municipal Code section 6-55(a); 
(b)  Commits unprovoked acts in a place other than the place where the animal is confined as required by Mauldin Municipal Code section 6-55(a) and those acts cause a person to reasonably believe that the animal will attack and cause bodily injury to a human being; 
(c)  Which is owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of fighting or which is trained for fighting; or 
(d)  Whose owner or keeper has received written notice of a violation of Mauldin Municipal Code section 6-13(a)(2) in accordance with the provisions set forth in Mauldin Municipal Code section 6-13(b). 
"Vicious or dangerous animal" does not include an animal used exclusively for agricultural purposes or an animal which attacks a person who is trespassing or who appears to be trespassing. A trespasser is a person who is not lawfully upon the premises of the owner, as set forth in Mauldin Municipal Code section 6-55(j). An animal is not a "vicious or dangerous animal" solely by virtue of its breed or species. 
Wild animal: Untamed animal, living in its natural state, including but not limited to alligators, crocodiles, bears, cat family, canine family, non-human primates, and venomous snakes. This definition excludes non-venomous snakes. 
(Code 1994, § 4-1; Ord. No. 632, 6-19-2006) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 6-2. - Beekeeping. 
The keeping of bees within residential areas of the city shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1994, § 4-2)  
Sec. 6-3. - Bird sanctuary. 
(a)  The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the city is hereby designated as a bird sanctuary. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to shoot, molest, trap or hunt any songbird or to rob any bird or wild fowl nest in the city. 
(c)  If at any time birds are found to be congregating in such number in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or menace to health or property, the city officials will have authority to correct this problem in any manner feasible. 
(Code 1994, § 4-3)  
Sec. 6-4. - Animals running at large or grazing on streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  All cows, meat cattle, goats or other animals are prohibited from running at large or grazing on the streets of the city, except when any such animal is properly haltered and under the immediate control of a responsible person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to lead or drive a cow or cattle on sidewalks; and it shall be unlawful, negligently or wilfully, to allow a cow or cattle to run on any sidewalk in the city. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1994, § 4-4) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36. 
State Law reference— Livestock running at large, S.C. Code 1976, § 47-7-110 et seq.  
Sec. 6-5. - Exhibiting animals kept for service on streets. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit upon the public streets of the city any stallion, jackass, bull or other animal kept for service. No person shall, within the city, exhibit in an indecent manner any stallion, jackass, bull, boar or ram, or cause or permit any such animal to be let to any animal of the opposite sex, unless the animals are in some enclosed shed or stable and entirely out of public view and hearing. 
(Code 1994, § 4-5) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36.  
Sec. 6-6. - Dead animals. 
(a)  Whenever any animal or poultry shall die from any natural or other cause, except from being slaughtered or killed for the use of man, or the dead body thereof is found upon the premises of any person, such person, whether he is the owner of such dead animal or poultry or the owner or tenant of the lands or premises upon which such dead body may be found, shall immediately and not later than 24 hours after discovery burn or bury or cause to be burned or buried such dead animal or poultry. When buried, the animal shall be put not less than three feet and poultry not less than one foot under the ground. 
(b)  Any owner of any such animal or poultry, or any owner or tenant of premises having knowledge that such animal or poultry is lying dead on his premises, and who refuses or fails to bury such dead animal or poultry, upon conviction, shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 4-6) 
Cross reference— Solid waste management, ch. 34.  
Sec. 6-7. - Keeping or bringing diseased animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring or keep within the city limits any horse or other animal having a disease known as glanders or farcy or an animal having a disease known as hydrophobia. The person having an animal so affected shall forthwith report the same to the board of health, and appropriate action will be taken by the board. 
(Code 1994, § 4-7)  
Sec. 6-8. - Cruelty to animals. 
Whoever overloads, overdrives, overworks, tortures, torments, needlessly mutilates, cruelly kills, ill-treats, deprives of necessary sustenance or shelter or inflicts unnecessary pain or suffering upon any animal, or causes the same to be done, whether such person is the owner of such animal or has the charge of custody of such animal, shall, for every such offense, upon conviction, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 4-8) 
State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, S.C. Code 1976, § 47-1-10 et seq.  
Sec. 6-9. - Possession of wild or exotic animals. 
(a)  No person shall keep or be permitted to keep on his premises any wild or exotic animal for display or for exhibition purposes, whether gratuitously or for a fee. This section shall not be construed to apply to zoological parks, performing animal exhibitions, or circuses. 
(b)  No person shall keep or be permitted to keep any wild or exotic animal as a pet. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the term "wild or exotic animal" means any member of the following families, including hybrids thereof, which, due to their inherent nature, may be considered dangerous to humans, and further defined as follows: 
(1)  Class Mammalia. 
a.  Order Artiodactyla (hippopotamuses, giraffes, camels, deer, not cattle or swine or sheep or goats). 
b.  Order Carnivora. 
1.  Family Felidae (lions, tigers, cougars, leopards, ocelots, servals, not domestic cats). 
2.  Family Canidae (wolves, coyotes, foxes, jackals, not domestic dogs). 
3.  Family Ursidae (all bears). 
4.  Family Mustelidae (weasels, skunks, martins, minks, not ferrets). 
5.  Family Procyonidae (raccoons, coatis). 
6.  Family Hyaenidae (hyenas). 
7.  Family Viverridae (civets, genets, mongooses, binturongs). 
c.  Order Edentatia (anteaters, armadillos, sloths). 
d.  Order Marsupialia (opossums, kangaroos, wallabies, not sugar gliders). 
e.  Order Perissodactyla (rhinoceroses, tapirs, not horses or donkeys or mules). 
f.  Order Primates (lemurs, monkeys, chimpanzees, gorillas). 
g.  Order Proboscidae (elephants). 
(2)  Class Reptilia. 
a.  Order Squamata. 
1.  Family Varanidae (only water monitors and crocodile monitors). 
2.  Family Iguanaidae (only green iguanas and rock iguanas). 
3.  Family Boidae (all species whose adult length has the potential to exceed eight feet in length). 
4.  Family Colubridae (only boomslangs and African twig snakes). 
5.  Family Elapidae (such as coral snakes, cobras, mambas, etc.)—all species. 
6.  Family Natricidae (only keelback snakes). 
7.  Family Viperidae (such as copperheads, cottonmouths, rattlesnakes, etc.) — all species. 
b.  Order Crocodilia (such as crocodiles, alligators, caimans, gavials, etc.) — all species. 
(Code 1994, § 4-9; Ord. No. 591, § 4-9, 1-28-2004)  
Sec. 6-10. - Confining animals in heat. 
Every female dog or cat in heat shall be confined in a building or secured enclosure so that such female dog or cat cannot come into contact with another animal except for planned breeding purposes. 
(Code 1994, § 4-10)  
Sec. 6-11. - Animal waste. 
The owner of every animal shall be responsible for the removal of any excreta deposited by his animal on public walks, recreation areas or on private property. 
(Code 1994, § 4-11) 
Cross reference— Solid waste management, ch. 34.  
Sec. 6-12. - Keeping of swine. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any swine within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 4-12)  
Sec. 6-13. - Nuisance animals; acts deemed a public nuisance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, possess or maintain within the city an animal in a manner so as to constitute a public nuisance. By way of example and not of limitation, the follow acts or actions by an owner or keeper are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and are, therefore, unlawful: 
(1)  Allowing or permitting an animal to damage the property of anyone other than its owner or keeper, or to impede the property owner's ordinary use and enjoyment, even if the property is not physically damaged; 
(2)  Maintaining an animal that habitually or repeatedly chases, snaps at, or attacks persons, bicycles, or vehicles, or maintaining any animal whose behavior constitutes a reasonable risk of injury to a human or domesticated animal; 
(3)  Damages or destroys public property or the private property of another (including garden and flower beds and trees); 
(4)  Intrudes into waste containers; 
(5)  Trespasses onto school grounds, public parks, or other private property; 
(6)  Maintaining property in a manner which results in an environment of unsanitary conditions causing offensive odors, filth, vermin, or disease; or is dangerous or unhealthy to the animal or the public health, safety or welfare of the community because of the number, type, variety, density, or location of the animals on the property; or 
(7)  Allowing or permitting an animal to bark, bay, whine, howl, crow or cackle in an excessive, continuous, or unreasonable fashion, or to make other noise in a manner so as to result in a serious interference with the reasonable use and enjoyment of neighboring premises. 
(b)  Upon the receipt of two written and signed affidavits from individuals either residing in separate households or employed by separate businesses in proximity to the offender that a person is violating the provisions of this section, the animal control officer or other appropriate law or codes enforcement officer shall investigate the complaint. If the investigating officer determines that the complaint is justified, the animal control officer or other appropriate law or codes enforcement officer shall notify the owner or keeper of the animal, in writing, to correct the violation within ten days. In addition to this procedure, the animal control officer shall have the discretion to investigate other types of complaints that an owner or keeper is violating this section and take action consistent with this section. 
(c)  Should the owner or keeper of any animal found to be in violation of this section fail to correct the violation within ten days after the date of notice, the animal may be seized and impounded and the owner or keeper shall be charged with a violation of this section shall be fined not more than $200.00 or imprisoned for not more than 30 days. Upon conviction, the owner or keeper shall be responsible for the payment of all expenses including, but not limited to, shelter, food, necessary veterinary expenses, boarding expenses, and those expenses necessitated by the seizure of the animal for the protection of the public. This penalty is in addition to any other remedies contained in this chapter or provided for under statutory or common law. 
(Ord. No. 580, § 5(4-13), 6-16-2003; Ord. No. 632, 6-19-2006) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 18-31 et seq.  
Secs. 6-14—6-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal powers re dogs, S.C. Code 1976, § 47-3-70. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 6-51. - Running at large. 
The running at large of all dogs in the city is hereby prohibited. Any person owning, keeping, possessing or harboring any dog in the city who shall suffer or permit the running at large in the city of such dog whether licensed or unlicensed, wearing a registration tag or without a tag, shall be guilty of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 4-36) 
State Law reference— Quarantine of dogs found running at large, S.C. Code 1976, § 47-3-40.  
Sec. 6-52. - Leash required. 
No dog shall be permitted off the premises of the owner or the person keeping or harboring such dog, unless such dog shall be placed on a leash held by a person over the age of 12 years who shall have complete control of the dog. Such leash shall not exceed eight feet in length. 
(Code 1994, § 4-37)  
Sec. 6-53. - Impoundment and redemption procedures. 
(a)  A police officer, animal control officer or any person appointed for the purpose by the city, shall take into custody and impound or cause to be taken into custody and impounded, and thereafter destroyed or disposed of as provided in this section, any animal running at large in the city or any animal within the city not wearing a current and proper registration tag. 
(b)  Any animal impounded by the city shall be detained for a period of five days for redemption by the owner. If such animal is not redeemed by the owner within such period of five days, it may be offered for adoption to any member of the public or disposed of in such a manner as the city deems appropriate. When the name and address of the owner appears on the collar of the animal, the city shall notify the owner within two days of the time the animal was seized. 
(c)  Any owner of or the person keeping or harboring an animal which has been impounded may claim the animal upon paying the fee listed on the schedule of violation fees as adopted by the city council and by procuring a license and registration tag, if applicable. 
(Code 1994, § 4-38)  
Sec. 6-54. - Impoundment fees. 
Fees which may be imposed for the impoundment and redemption of dogs under this article shall be as determined by the city council from time to time and on file in the office of the municipal clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 4-39)  
Sec. 6-55. - Vicious or dangerous animals. 
(a)  No person owning or harboring or having the care or the custody of a dangerous animal may permit the animal to go unconfined on his premises. A dangerous animal is "unconfined" as used in this section if the animal is not confined securely indoors or confined in a securely enclosed fence or securely enclosed and locked pen or run area upon the person's premises. The pen or run area must be clearly marked as containing a dangerous animal and must be designed to prevent the entry of the general public, including children, and to prevent the escape or release of the animal. However, this section does not apply to an animal owned by a licensed security company and on patrol in a confined area. Nothing in this chapter is designed to abrogate any civil remedies available under statutory or common law. 
(b)  No person owning or harboring or having the care of a dangerous animal may permit the animal to go beyond his premises unless the animal is safely restrained and the requirements of subsection (i) herein are met. 
(c)  No person may own or harbor an animal for the purpose of fighting or train, torment, badger, bait, or use an animal for the purpose of causing or encouraging the animal to unprovoked attacks upon human beings or domestic animals. 
(d)  No person may possess with intent to sell, offer for sale, breed, or buy or attempt to buy a known dangerous animal; however, this subsection does not apply to a person who is licensed to possess and breed an animal under the classifications specified and regulated by the United States Department of Agriculture under the Animal Welfare Act as codified in Title 7 of the United States Code. 
(e)  Seizure and impoundment of vicious or dangerous animal: 
(1)  If a law enforcement agent, animal control officer, or animal control officer under contract with a county or municipal government to provide animal control services has probable cause to believe that a dangerous animal is being harbored or cared for in violation of subsections (a), (c), (d), or (i) of this section, the agent or officer may petition the court having jurisdiction to order the seizure and impoundment of the dangerous animal while the trial is pending. 
(2)  If a law enforcement agent, animal control officer, or animal control officer under contract with a county or municipal government to provide animal control services has probable cause to believe that a dangerous animal is being harbored or housed in violation of subsection (b) of this section, the agent or officer may seize and impound the dangerous animal while the trial is pending. 
(f)  Penalties; registration of dangerous animals. 
(1)  A person who violates subsection (a), (b), or (e) of this section or who is the owner of a dangerous animal which attacks and injures a domestic animal is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, for a first offense, must be fined not more than $500.00 or imprisoned not more than 30 days. 
(2)  A person who is the owner of a dangerous animal which attacks and injures a human being in violation of Mauldin Municipal Code section 6-1 "vicious or dangerous animal" subsection (a) or a person who violates Mauldin Municipal Code subsections 6-55(c) or (d) shall be prosecuted under state law in accordance with S.C. Code 1976 § 47-3-760. 
(g)  A dangerous animal which attacks a human being or domestic animal may be ordered destroyed when in the court's judgment the dangerous animal represents a continuing threat of serious harm to human beings or domestic animals. 
(h)  A person found guilty of violating this section shall pay all expenses, including, but not limited to, shelter, food, veterinary expenses for boarding and veterinary expenses necessitated by the seizure of an animal for the protection of the public, medical expenses incurred by a victim from an attack by a dangerous animal, and other expenses required for the destruction of the animal. 
(i)  A person owning a dangerous animal shall register the animal with the Greenville County Animal Control or other appropriate law enforcement authority. The requirements of the registration must be determined by the county governing body. However, the registration application must be accompanied by proof of liability insurance or surety bond of at least $50,000.00 insuring or securing the owner for personal injuries inflicted by the dangerous animal. The county governing body shall provide to the owner registering the dangerous animal a metal license tag and a certificate. The metal license tag at all times must be attached to a collar or harness worn by the dangerous animal for which the certificate and tag have been issued. 
(j)  A person lawfully is upon the premises of the owner within the meaning of this article when he is on the premises in the performance of a duty imposed upon him by the laws of this state, by the laws or postal regulations of the United States, when he is on the premises upon invitation, expressed or implied, of the owner, or when he is in the performance of a duty relative to public safety, which includes policemen, firemen, or other authorized personnel. A person may ingress to and egress from the premises for a purpose connected with the performance of the public safety duty. 
(k)  A person who lawfully is on the owner's premises and who is attacked by a dangerous animal or witnesses the attack may use reasonable force to repel the attack. A person is not liable in damages or otherwise for action to repel or action taken to restrain or control an animal from an unprovoked attack. 
(Code 1994, § 4-41; Ord. No. 632, 6-19-2006) 
State Law reference— Regulation of dangerous dogs, S.C. Code 1976, § 47-3-710 et seq.  
Sec. 6-56. - Applicability of article to dogs of nonlicensing age. 
All portions of this article, with the exception of the sections dealing with license fees and registration tags, shall apply to all dogs, including dogs under the licensing age of four months. 
(Code 1994, § 4-42)  
Sec. 6-57. - Dogs permitted in public parks. 
Dogs shall be permitted at any time during operating hours in any public park under specific conditions. 
(Code 1994, § 4-43; Ord. No. 750, 3-18-2013; Ord. No. 830, 7-30-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 830, adopted July 30, 2017, changed the title of § 6-57 from "Dogs prohibited in public parks" to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference— Parks and recreation, ch. 30.  
Secs. 6-58—6-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE; REGISTRATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Registration of dogs, S.C. Code 1976, § 47-3-510 et seq. 
 
Sec. 6-81. - Required. 
(a)  Every person who shall own, keep or harbor any dog of licensing age within the city limits shall obtain a dog license. The license shall run concurrent with the dog's inoculations required by state law. Licenses shall be renewed within 30 days of when the dog receives its latest inoculation. The owner shall have the dog registered and numbered with the municipal clerk. A license and official metal registration tag is required for each such dog owned, kept or harbored. The owner of each dog shall place upon such dog a collar or harness with the registration tag securely fastened thereto. 
(b)  New residents shall have 60 days to register their dog. 
(Code 1994, § 4-56; Ord. No. 580, § 1(4-56), 6-16-2003)  
Sec. 6-82. - Application of division provisions. 
Any person who shall own, keep or harbor any dog of licensing age for a period of ten days or more shall be deemed to be the owner of the dog so kept and harbored. Any dog over four months old shall be of licensing age. 
(Code 1994, § 4-57)  
Sec. 6-83. - Fees. 
Fees for the licensing and registration of dogs which may be imposed under this division shall be as determined by the city council from time to time and on file in the office of the municipal clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 4-58)  
Sec. 6-84. - Application generally. 
All applications for dog licenses shall be made to the municipal clerk and shall state the breed, sex, age, color and markings of the dog for which such license and registration are sought, whether it is a long-haired or short-haired variety, and the name, street and post office address of the owner or person who shall harbor such dog. 
(Code 1994, § 4-60)  
Sec. 6-85. - When application required; proration. 
The owner of any newly acquired dog of licensing age or of any dog which attains licensing age shall make application for a license and registration tag for such dog within ten days after such acquisition or age attainment. 
(Code 1994, § 4-61; Ord. No. 580, § 3(4-61), 6-16-2003)  
Sec. 6-86. - Causing or permitting unlicensed dog to wear registration tag. 
Any person who shall cause or permit any unlicensed dog to wear a registration tag shall be guilty of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 4-63)  
Sec. 6-87. - Proof of rabies vaccination prerequisite to licensing. 
No dog shall be licensed by the city unless and until adequate proof is furnished showing that the dog has been vaccinated against rabies and that such vaccination is current. 
(Code 1994, § 4-64)  
Secs. 6-88—6-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - RABIES CONTROL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 18. 
State Law reference— Rabies control, S.C. Code 1976, § 47-5-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 6-121. - Inoculation and tag required. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any dog which is four months of age or older to allow such dog to roam at large on streets, roadways or highways of the city or off the premises of the owner or keeper of the dog. The dog shall wear around his neck at all times a tag evidencing that such dog has been inoculated against rabies by a qualified veterinarian or duly authorized person administering the vaccine. Upon the inoculation being made, the veterinarian shall file a copy of the same with the county health department. Such inoculation shall be effective for the period stated on the inoculation certificate prepared by the veterinarian. 
(Code 1994, § 4-86; Ord. No. 580, § 6(4-86), 6-16-2003) 
State Law reference— Inoculation of all pets required, S.C. Code 1976, § 47-5-60.  
Sec. 6-122. - Order to confine or restrain. 
Whenever a case or suspected case of rabies has occurred in the city, the police department shall have the power, and it shall be its duty, to prevent the spread of the disease by ordering that all dogs or other domestic pets in the city shall be locked up, restrained by a leash or muzzled, or to order all owners or keepers of the same to take such preventive measures as the police department may deem necessary, or both. The police department shall exercise this power subject to state law governing the duties of the county health department in like situations. 
(Code 1994, § 4-87)  
Sec. 6-123. - Enforcement of order. 
If any owner or keeper of any dog or domestic pet shall knowingly fail or refuse to comply with the order of the police department duly given under the authority of section 6-122, it shall be the prerogative of the police department to seize the dog and take whatever action it deems appropriate and which is not inconsistent with state law governing the duties of the county health department in like situations. 
(Code 1994, § 4-88)  
Sec. 6-124. - Duty of owner detecting rabies symptoms. 
It shall be the duty of any person owning or having in his possession any dog or animal within the city which develops any symptoms of rabies to immediately notify the health officer of such condition and to immediately confine the dog or animal securely in such a manner that there will be no opportunity for it to come into contact with other animals and keep it segregated until notification by the health officer of proper disposition. 
(Code 1994, § 4-89)  
Sec. 6-125. - Animal bites; quarantine. 
Any domestic animal or other animal which bites a person or causes the skin to be broken in such a way as to cause bleeding shall be quarantined by the city for ten days, at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1994, § 4-90) 
State Law reference— Liability of owner or person controlling dogs who bite, S.C. Code 1976, § 47-3-110.  
Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 18; fire prevention and protection, ch. 20; flood damage prevention, ch. 21; soil erosion and sedimentation control, ch. 32; solid waste management, ch. 34; removal of construction debris, § 34-7; litter at construction sites, § 34-86; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; utilities, ch. 40; vegetation, ch. 42. 
State Law reference— Building codes and fire prevention, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-25-10 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 8-1. - Master's card required for certain trades. 
(a)  All persons engaging in business or a trade that are exempt from licensure by the currently enacted state legislation governing contractor licensing as set forth in S.C. Code, tit. 40, Professions and Occupations, S.C. Code, § 40-50-260 for Residential Home Builders, and S.C. Code, § 40-11-360 for commercial contractors, will be required to obtain a Masters Card from the Municipal Association of South Carolina to engage in the practice of electrical, mechanical, gas piping, and plumbing services performed within the city limits. 
(b)  Those persons obtaining a permit for electrical, heating and air conditioning, mechanical or plumbing work shall have a current master's card on the job site at all times when engaged in their trade. No master's card in electrical, heating and air conditioning, mechanical and plumbing shall be loaned to any other person so that he might do work in the city. 
(Code 1994, § 5-1; Ord. No. 471, § 5.1, 4-20-1998; Ord. No. 755, § 1, 8-19-2013)  
Sec. 8-2. - Violations. 
Any person who is convicted of violating any provision of this chapter or of the regulatory codes adopted herein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. All persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time, and when not otherwise specified, each ten days that the protested conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. The application of such penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions by court order. 
(Code 1994, § 5-2)  
Sec. 8-3. - Fire district. 
For the purpose of enforcing the regulatory codes adopted in this chapter, the fire district of the city shall be defined as the corporate limits of the city and the fire service area pursuant to contract with the county. 
(Code 1994, § 5-3) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 20. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to establish fire limits, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-25-20; municipalities to pass fire limits ordinance, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-25-1110.  
Secs. 8-4—8-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - REGULATORY CODES 
 
Sec. 8-31. - Adoption. 
The currently adopted building codes enforced in the City of Mauldin are those, which the State of South Carolina has mandated by legislation and as posted by the South Carolina Labor, Licensing and Regulation Building Codes Council (www.llr.state.sc.us/POL/BCC/.). In addition, the City of Mauldin, by local ordinance also adopts Chapter I Administration in its entirety as referenced in the enacted International Codes. 
(Code 1994, § 5-31; Ord. No. 755, § 2, 8-19-2013; Ord. No. 769, § 1, 6-16-2014) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to adopt technical codes by reference, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-9-60.  
Sec. 8-32. - Business and development services director to enforce technical codes. 
The business and development services director or his or her designee shall be deemed the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of such codes adopted in section 8-31. 
(Code 1994, § 5-33; Memo. of 3-5-2012; Ord. No. 769, § 2, 6-16-2014) 
Editor's note— A memorandum dated March 5, 2012, changed the title of § 8-32 from "Building and zoning director to enforce technical codes" to "Business and development services director to enforce technical codes."  
Sec. 8-33. - Adoption of International Property Maintenance Code. 
As permitted by S.C. Code 1976, § 6-9-60, "permissive codes" defined as the latest edition, may be used and adopted by a local jurisdiction's government body. The currently adopted permissive code, entitled, "International Property Maintenance Code" is hereby adopted and enforced in the City of Mauldin. In addition, the City of Mauldin, by local ordinance also adopts Chapter I Administration as referenced in the enacted International Property Maintenance Code. References to the "code official" shall be designated as the city administrator or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. 769, § 3, 6-16-2014)  
Sec. 8-34. - Violations; enforcement. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of the codes adopted in sections 8-31 and 8-33. The city administrator and or his or her designee shall investigate suspected violations and shall take appropriate action to prosecute violations. 
(Code 1994, § 5-34; Memo. of 3-5-2012; Ord. No. 769, § 4, 6-16-2014) 
Editor's note— Section 4 of Ord. No. 769, adopted June 16, 2014, amended and renumbered former § 8-33 as § 8-34.  
Secs. 8-35—8-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Flood damage prevention, ch. 21. 
State Law reference— Building permits, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-25-310. 
 
Sec. 8-61. - Required; fees. 
(a)  The city council may change building permit fees by resolution when deemed necessary to amend or update such fees. These fees shall remain in effect until such time as further amended and shall include, but not be limited to, building and related permits subject to this chapter. 
(b)  A reinspection fee will be charged by the building department for any inspections performed on the third and subsequent inspection during the course of construction when it is necessary to return to a job site for the following reasons: 
(1)  The contractor or his representative is not present on the job site at the agreed upon time when the inspector arrive to perform the inspection. 
(2)  An inspection has been ordered by the contractor for a specific time but the work is not ready for inspection. 
(3)  An inspection has been ordered by the contractor and the work has not been done according to standard codes. 
Such reinspection fee shall be set from time to time by the council, and a schedule of such fees is on file and available in the city offices. 
(Code 1994, § 5-56)  
Sec. 8-62. - Compliance with laws, rules, regulations prerequisite to approval of a building permit. 
No building permit shall be issued until the applicant has complied with all applicable municipal, county and state regulations. The real estate or subdivision involved must fully comply with all city requirements, including land development regulations, and all other governing bodies and agencies having jurisdiction. 
Applications for building permits shall be distributed to and reviewed by the development review team which shall consist of appropriate staff and applicable governmental agencies. Appropriate staff shall generally entail the following, where applicable: the fire marshal, the building official, the business and development services director, and the public works director, or their designees. Other governmental agencies may include the Greenville County Land Development Division, Greenville Water, ReWa, and SCDOT, among others, as applicable. 
The appropriate staff and applicable governmental agencies shall review the building permit application for compliance with the requirements and standards under their jurisdiction. The staff and agencies involved in the review may request additional information necessary to demonstrate compliance. Review time frames may vary by agency. Review time frames for City of Mauldin staff are established in the Mauldin Zoning Ordinance and the Land Development Regulations, and vary by application type. 
(Code 1994, § 5-57; Ord. No. 931, § 1, 1-21-2020) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 931, § 1, adopted Jan. 21, 2020, changed the title of § 8-62 from "Compliance with laws, rules, regulations of county planning commission prerequisite to issuance" to read as herein set out.  
Sec. 8-63. - Street paving prerequisite to issuance. 
No building permit will be issued by the city for any building to be constructed on any lot facing a public street which has not first been paved with suitable and approved hard surfacing. 
(Code 1994, § 5-58)  
Sec. 8-64. - Mobile home permits. 
No mobile home shall be set down or parked in the city for occupancy purposes, unless and until a mobile home permit has been obtained from the city. The city shall charge a fee for each mobile home permit and a schedule of such fees is on file in the municipal clerk's office. 
(Code 1994, § 5-59)  
Sec. 8-65. - Permits in areas of special flood hazard. 
Any applicant desiring to build or development with an identified area of special flood hazard shall be required issuance of a flood permit in accordance with the provision of chapter 21, flood damage prevention ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 7-21-2014) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 771, adopted July 21, 2014, repealed former §§ 8-65—8-68, and enacted new provisions as set out herein. Former §§ 8-65—8-68 pertained to elevation and floodproofing data; flood elevation data for subdivision proposals; flood protection for mobile homes; and permits in floodplain management area; and derived from the 1994 Code §§ 5-60—5-63.  
Chapter 10 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 4; commercial, business and multifamily waste disposal, § 34-41 et seq.; wreckers, § 38-161 et seq.; utilities, ch. 40.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 10-1—10-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 628, adopted June 19, 2006, amended the Code by repealing Art. II, §§ 10-31—10-51 in its entirety and enacted similar new provisions to read as herein set out. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
 
Sec. 10-31. - License required. 
Every person engaged or intending to engage in any calling, business, occupation or profession, in whole or in part, within the limits of the City of Mauldin, South Carolina, is required to pay an annual license fee for the privilege of doing business and obtain a business license as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 628, § 1, 6-19-2006; Ord. No. 928, § 1, 11-18-2019)  
Sec. 10-32. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed herein: 
Business means a calling, occupation, profession, or activity engaged in with the object of gain, benefit or advantage, either directly or indirectly. 
Charitable organization means an organization that is determined by the Internal Revenue Service to be exempt from federal income taxes under 26 U.S.C. section 501(c)(3), (4), (6), (7), (8), (10) or (19). 
Charitable purpose means benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary purpose which does not result in personal gain to a sponsor, organizer, officer, director, trustee or person with ultimate control of the organization. 
Classification means that division of businesses by major groups subject to the same license rate as determined by a calculated index of ability to pay based on national averages, benefits, equalization of tax burden, relationships of services, or other basis deemed appropriate by town council.
