Should the accommodation and/or hospitality tax and penalty fees remain unpaid for a period of 90 days after its due date, the official or appointed designee shall issue a written warning citation with an order that payment of the tax and assessed penalties be made within ten businesses days. 
After being issued a written citation warning any person or business that fails to make payment within the time allotted shall be served a formal citation and court summons in the amount of $500.00 with a prescribed date to appear before the Mauldin Municipal Court. Each day of violation shall be considered a separate offense. Punishment for violation shall not relieve the offender of liability for delinquent taxes, penalties and costs provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 11, 2-20-2001; Ord. No. 785, § 1, 2-23-2015) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 785, § 1, adopted Feb. 23, 2015, changed the title of § 10-303 from "Violations and penalties" to read as herein set out.  
Secs. 10-304—10-320. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LOCAL ACCOMMODATIONS TAX 
 
Sec. 10-321. - Imposed; rate. 
A uniform tax equal to three percent is hereby imposed on the gross proceeds derived from the rental of any accommodation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 2, 2-20-2001)  
Sec. 10-322. - Payment. 
(a)  Payment of the local accommodations tax established in this division shall be the liability of the consumer of the services. The tax shall be paid at the time of delivery of the services to which the tax applies, and shall be collected by the provider of the services. The city shall promulgate a form of return which shall be utilized by the provider of services to calculate the amount of local accommodation taxes collected and due. This form shall contain a sworn declaration as to the correctness thereof by the provider of services. 
(b)  The tax provided for in this division must be remitted to the city on a monthly basis when the estimated amount of average tax is more than $50.00 a month, on a quarterly basis when the estimated amount of average tax is $25.00 to $50.00 a month, and on an annual basis when the estimated amount of average tax is less than $25.00 a month. 
(c)  The provider of services shall remit the local accommodations tax, when due, to the city on the 20th of the month, or on the next business day if the 20th is not a business day. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 3, 2-20-2001)  
Sec. 10-323. - Special revenue fund. 
An interest-bearing, segregated and restricted account to be known as the "City of Mauldin Local Accommodations Tax Special Revenue Fund" is hereby established. All revenues received from the local accommodations tax shall be deposited into this fund. The principal and any accrued interest in this fund shall be expended only as permitted by this division. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 4, 2-20-2001)  
Sec. 10-324. - Distribution of funds. 
The city council shall distribute the local accommodations tax collected and placed in the "City of Mauldin Local Accommodations Tax Special Revenue Fund" to be used for tourism-related capital projects, the support of tourism and tourist services in a manner that will best serve the tourists from whom it was collected including being pledged as security for indebtedness issued by the city for public purposes. It shall be the responsibility of the city council to ensure that any and all money expended from the "City of Mauldin Local Accommodations Tax Special Revenue Fund" shall be spent to build capital projects which will serve and attract tourists and benefit those tourists who regularly seek accommodations in the city. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 5, 2-20-2001)  
Secs. 10-325—10-340. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LOCAL HOSPITALITY TAX 
 
Sec. 10-341. - Imposed; rate. 
A uniform tax equal to two percent is hereby imposed on the sales of prepared meals and beverages sold in establishments within the city. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 6, 2-20-2001)  
Sec. 10-342. - Payment. 
(a)  Payment of the local hospitality tax established in this division shall be the liability of the consumer of the services. The tax shall be paid at the time of delivery of the services to which the tax applies, and shall be collected by the provider of the services. The city shall promulgate a form of return which shall be utilized by the provider of services to calculate the amount of local hospitality tax collected and due. This form shall contain a sworn declaration as to the correctness thereof by the provider of the services. 
(b)  The tax provided for in this division must be remitted to the city on a monthly basis when the estimated amount of average tax is more than $50.00 a month, on a quarterly basis when the estimated amount of average tax is $25.00 to $50.00 a month, and on an annual basis when the estimated amount of average tax is less than $25.00 a month. 
(c)  The provider of services shall remit the local hospitality tax, when, due, to the city on the 20th of the month, or on the next business day if the 20th is not a business day. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 7, 2-20-2001)  
Sec. 10-343. - Special revenue fund. 
An interest-bearing, segregated and restricted account to be known as the "City of Mauldin Local Hospitality Tax Special Revenue Fund" is hereby established. All revenues received from the local hospitality tax shall be deposited into this fund. The principal and any accrued interest in this fund shall be expended only as permitted by this article. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 8, 2-20-2001)  
Sec. 10-344. - Distribution of funds. 
The city council shall distribute the local hospitality tax collected and placed in the "City of Mauldin Local Hospitality Tax Special Revenue Fund" to be used for tourism-related capital projects, the support of tourism and tourist services in a manner that will best serve the tourists from whom it was collected including being pledged as security for indebtedness issued by the city for public purposes. It shall be the responsibility of the city council to ensure that any and all money expended from the "City of Mauldin Local Hospitality Tax Special Revenue Fund" shall be spent to build capital projects which will serve and attract tourists and benefit those tourists who regularly visit the city. 
(Ord. No. 527, § 9, 2-20-2001)  
Chapter 12 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to acquire, operate, etc., cemeteries, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-39-10. 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Permit for place for burial of dead. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish or use, within the city, any place for the burial of the dead without permission of the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 6-1)  
Sec. 12-2. - Damaging shrubbery. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or deface any ornamental shrubbery or any other thing put, placed or growing on any lot in any cemetery in the city by plucking flowers or otherwise tearing, cutting or removing any part thereof. 
(Code 1994, § 6-2) 
Cross reference— Vegetation, ch. 42.  
Sec. 12-3. - Damaging or defacing tombstones or monuments. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or deface a tombstone or monument in any cemetery in the city by shooting the same or otherwise chipping, breaking or in any way marring the surface thereof. 
(Code 1994, § 6-3) 
State Law reference— Destruction or desecration of human remains, etc., S.C. Code 1976, § 16-17-600.  
Sec. 12-4. - Firing pistols or guns. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fire a pistol or gun in any cemetery or graveyard within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 6-4) 
Cross reference— Discharge of firearms within city, § 26-3.  
Chapter 14 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 20; law enforcement, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Emergency preparedness, S.C. Code 1976, § 25-1-420 et seq.; duties of municipal governments for mutual assistance in emergencies, S.C. Code 1976, § 25-1-450. 
 
Sec. 14-1. - States of emergency. 
(a)  In the event of a state of emergency, which shall be deemed to exist whenever, during times of great public crisis, disaster, rioting, civil disturbance, catastrophe or for any other reason, municipal public safety authorities are unable to maintain public order or afford adequate protection for lives, safety, health, welfare or property, the mayor may: 
(1)  Issue a public proclamation declaring to all persons the existence of such a state of emergency. 
(2)  In order to more effectively protect the lives, safety and property of people within the city, define and impose a curfew applicable to all persons within the jurisdiction of the city, during which it shall be unlawful for anyone subject to curfew to: 
a.  Be or travel upon any public street, alley or roadway or upon public property, unless such travel is necessary to obtain medical assistance. 
b.  Possess off his own premises, buy, sell, give away or otherwise transfer or dispose of any explosives, firearms, ammunition or dangerous weapon of any kind. 
c.  Sell beer, wine or intoxicating beverages of any kind, or possess or consume the same off his own premises. 
d.  Sell gasoline or any other similar petroleum products or any other combustible or inflammable substances, except as expressly authorized by the provisions of the curfew imposed. 
(3)  Limit the application of such curfew to any area specifically designated and described within the jurisdiction of the city and to specific hours of the day or night. 
(4)  Exempt from such curfew police officers, firefighters, doctors, nurses and such other classes of persons as may be essential to the preservation of public order and immediately necessary to serve the safety, health and welfare needs of the people within the city. 
(b)  The mayor shall: 
(1)  Call the city council into session within 24 hours after a state of emergency has been proclaimed. 
(2)  Proclaim the end of any state of emergency and curfew as soon as circumstances warrant or when directed to do so by the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 8-1)  
Chapter 16 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Elections, S.C. Code 1976, tit. 7. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Compliance with state law. 
All municipal elections in the city shall be held in accordance with the laws, rules and regulations as adopted by the city and the laws of the state. 
(Code 1994, § 7-1)  
Sec. 16-2. - When polls open; polling place. 
All regular elections in the city shall be conducted in accordance with the election laws of the state, with the polls open from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. The polling places for the city shall be designated in the public notice of election. 
(Code 1994, § 7-2)  
Secs. 16-3—16-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MAYOR AND COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq. 
 
Sec. 16-31. - Elections nonpartisan. 
(a)  All regular and special elections for the offices of mayor and city council shall be nonpartisan general elections pursuant to S.C. Code 1976, §§ 5-15-60(2) and 5-15-62. Eligible persons desiring to run for mayor or city council shall file a statement of candidacy with the municipal clerk and the city elections commission no later than 60 days prior to the election. The statement shall state what office the candidate is seeking, i.e., mayor or city council seat number, in the next municipal election. It shall set forth the name and address of the candidate and be signed by the candidate. No statement of candidacy shall be accepted without the payment by the candidate of a filing fee of $150.00 for mayor or $100.00 for city council, which shall be paid to the municipal clerk. Upon the timely receipt of the statement of candidacy and the payment of the filing fee, the candidate's name shall be placed on the ballot. No nominating petition shall be required or accepted. 
(b)  No political party affiliation shall be placed on any ballot for any candidate for mayor or councilmember. 
(Code 1994, § 7-31; Ord. No. 501, § 7-31(a), 6-21-1999)  
Sec. 16-32. - Qualification of candidates. 
Each candidate seeking election to the city council shall qualify with the municipal election board in accordance with the laws of the state and the city. 
(Code 1994, § 7-33)  
Sec. 16-33. - Composition of council; council seats; terms. 
The city council shall be composed of a mayor and six councilmembers. The mayor shall be elected for a term of four years. At the election to be held during the year 1975, the candidates offering for seats 1, 3, and 5 of the city council shall be elected for a term of two years, and the candidates offering for seats 2, 4 and 6 for the city council shall be elected for a term of four years; at the election to be held during the year 1977, the candidates offering for seats 1, 3 and 5 shall be elected for a term of four years; and at the election to be held during the year 1979, the candidates offering for seats 2, 4 and 6 shall be elected for a term of four years, so that three councilmembers will be elected each two years thereafter and shall hold office for a term of four years, so as to stagger the election of members of the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 7-34)  
Sec. 16-34. - Council seats at large, residency; designation of seat sought. 
Candidates offering for the office of city council shall not be required to be residents of any particular area of the city but shall run at large and shall be elected at large by all of the qualified electors of the city. Each council office shall constitute a separate and distinct office to which a separate number shall be assigned, and each candidate offering for the office of city council shall specify whether he is offering for seat 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6. Each candidate offering for election shall specify and qualify for one of the six seats enumerated in section 16-33. No candidate shall be permitted to qualify or run for more than one seat or office in any one general or special election. 
(Code 1994, § 7-34)  
Sec. 16-35. - Eligibility of candidates. 
To be eligible for the position of mayor or of councilmember of the city, a person shall be a duly qualified elector of the city under the constitution and statutes of the state. 
(Code 1994, § 7-36)  
Sec. 16-36. - When held. 
Municipal elections for mayor and councilmember, other than special elections, shall be held in odd-numbered years on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November. 
(Code 1994, § 7-37)  
Sec. 16-37. - Runoff elections. 
A runoff election shall be conducted two weeks after the first election pursuant to the provisions of S.C. Code 1976, § 5-15-62 for any office in which no candidate received a majority of the votes cast. 
(Code 1994, § 7-38)  
Sec. 16-38. - Taking office; assumption of duties. 
(a)  The mayor and the members of the city council elected at the regular general election in November shall take office and assume the duties of their respective offices at the first meeting of city council in January following their election in November. The terms of the previously elected mayor and members of the city council shall continue until the new officials have taken their oath of office. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a special election which may be required to fill the unexpired term of the mayor or any member of the city council because of resignation, death, disqualification or any other cause. 
(Code 1994, § 7-39)  
Sec. 16-39. - Oath of mayor and councilmember. 
The mayor and councilmember, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, shall take the following oath: 
"I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I am duly qualified, according to the constitution of this state, to exercise the duties of the office to which I have been elected and that I will, to the best of my ability, discharge the duties thereof and preserve, protect and defend the constitution of the state and of the United States. 
"As mayor (or councilmember) of the City of Mauldin, I will equally, fairly and impartially, to the best of my ability and skill, exercise the trust reposed in me and will use my best endeavor to preserve the peace and carry into effect, according to law, the purpose for which I have been elected. So help me God." 
(Code 1994, § 7-40) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-15-150.  
Chapter 18 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 6; rabies control, § 6-121 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; flood damage prevention, ch. 21; parks and recreation, ch. 30; solid waste management, ch. 34; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; utilities, ch. 40; vegetation, ch. 42. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 18-1—18-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Acts of animals deemed a public nuisance, § 6-13; litter a nuisance, § 34-118. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to abate nuisances, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-30. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-31. - Condition of premises generally. 
All persons shall maintain their yards, cellars, drains, stable lots and all other lands owned or occupied by them in the city, whether occupied or vacant, in a clean and healthy condition. It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any premises within the city limits to permit such premises to become filthy, dirty or so filled with rubbish as to emit dangerous or disagreeable odors to the annoyance or discomfort of persons who reside or transact business in that locality or who may pass along any street, lane, alley or sidewalk in the vicinity. Any place so kept or permitted is hereby declared a nuisance, subject to abatement by the building and zoning director. 
(Code 1994, § 13-1) 
State Law reference— Ordinances relating to upkeep of property within a municipality, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-80.  
Sec. 18-32. - Report of unsanitary conditions to council. 
It shall be the duty of the building and zoning director to report unsanitary conditions of buildings and premises to the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 13-2)  
Sec. 18-33. - Prohibited acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act which offends, endangers, injures or impairs the health, safety or life of any individual. Any such act is hereby declared a public nuisance. 
(Code 1994, § 13-3)  
Sec. 18-34. - Unsanitary, unsightly and unsafe conditions. 
(a)  All premises within the city, whether vacant, improved or occupied, shall at all times be kept in a sanitary condition. All damp low places and all garbage, leaves, trash, cans, vessels, broken bottles, pieces of metal, china, glass or other materials that may hold water are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. Weeds, grass and other rank vegetation which is allowed to grow, stand uncut upon, or garbage, trash, eroded soil and other debris allowed to accumulate and remain on any lot or allowed to spill into the public right-of-way, so as to render the premises unsightly or unsanitary, are hereby deemed and declared to be a public nuisance and a detriment to health and safety. The occupant or lessee of any such premises and the owner, his agent, representative or employee having control of any vacant premises within the city who shall permit or tolerate the existence of any conditions condemned in this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any owner and any lessee, occupant, agent or representative of the owner of any lot or parcel of land to cut or cause to be cut all weeds, grass and other rank vegetation and to remove all garbage, trash, eroded soil and other debris as often as may be necessary to prevent the development of any of the conditions which are prohibited in this section. 
(Code 1994, § 13-4)  
Sec. 18-35. - Conditions affording food or harborage for rats. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, leave, dump or permit to accumulate any garbage, rubbish or trash in any building, vehicle and their surrounding areas in the city so that the same shall or may afford food or harborage for rats. Any violation of this section shall constitute a public nuisance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and constitute a public nuisance for any person to permit to accumulate on any premises, improved or vacant, or on any open lots or alleys in the city, any lumber, boxes, barrels, bricks, stones or similar materials and permit them to remain thereon unless the same shall be placed on open racks that are elevated not less than 18 inches above the ground and evenly piled or stacked, so that these materials will not afford harborage for rats or violate any other provisions of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 13-5)  
Sec. 18-36. - Abatement. 
(a)  The building and zoning director, upon receiving notice of the existence of any condition declared by this article, shall notify the person responsible for such condition to clean up his premises and abate such public nuisance within ten days. It shall be sufficient notification to deliver the notice or a copy thereof to the person to whom it is addressed or to deposit a copy of such notice in the United States mail properly stamped and directed to such person at his last known address and post a copy thereof on the premises upon which the public nuisance exists. If service of notice cannot be obtained in either of such methods, notice will be posted in a conspicuous place, for 24 hours, on the premises where the violation has occurred. 
(b)  Upon failure of the person to abate the cited public nuisance, as provided for in this section, within ten days after notice, a person violating these provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(c)  The employees or agents of the city may enter upon the premises of the offending person and cause the public nuisance to be removed therefrom. The cost of removing such nuisance shall become a lien upon the land, and such person shall be liable to the city for the costs of removal or abatement in addition to being subject to prosecution for violating this article. 
(Code 1994, § 13-6)  
Sec. 18-37. - Right of entry to abate. 
The building and zoning director, together with his subordinates, assistants, workers, employees and agents, shall have the power to enter upon any premises within the city upon which there is suspected to be a public nuisance for the purpose of abating the same. Any person who in any manner hinders or obstructs any authorized officer or representative of the city in the inspecting of any premises within the city limits, in the abatement or removal of any public nuisance, or in the discharge of any duties prescribed in this article or any other ordinance for the prevention or correction of any unsanitary, unsightly, or unsafe condition in the city shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1994, § 13-7)  
Sec. 18-38. - Reserved.  
Sec. 18-39. - [Smoking and smokeless tobacco on municipal property and municipal buildings.] 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following words or phrases shall have the meaning prescribed below: 
Designated smoking area means any area outdoors which is outside of any enclosed public place and removed from building entrances and exits. Any designated smoking area must be so situated as to allow nonsmoking individuals to conduct normal activity in a smoke-free environment. 
Municipal property means all buildings, structures, and property owned by the city except for properties leased to private businesses. 
Parks and recreational facilities shall mean all public parks, playgrounds, or ball fields, publicly owned or leased by the city upon which the public is invited or upon which the public is permitted and where individuals gather for recreational activities, including all areas adjacent to such facilities including, but not limited to, any parking areas, driveways or drive aisles. 
Smokeless tobacco means tobacco that is not smoked, but is used in another form such as chewing tobacco or snuff. 
Smoking means to inhale, exhale, burn or carry any lighted cigarette, cigar, pipe, electronic cigarette, vapes, or similar devices that burn tobacco, (or similar products.) 
(b)  Smoking and smokeless tobacco use prohibited. Smoking and smokeless tobacco use are prohibited in and about any municipal property or on any park or recreational facility except outdoors in designated areas. 
"No Tobacco" signs, a "No Tobacco" symbol, or "Designated Tobacco Area" signs shall be clearly and conspicuously posted. 
No person shall cause, allow, or permit any person to smoke cigarettes, cigars, pipes, electronic cigarettes or other devices containing tobacco or other combustible smoking materials on municipal property or parks and recreational facilities owned by the city except in designated areas defined in subsection (a). 
No person shall cause, allow or permit any person to use smokeless tobacco on municipal property or parks and recreation facilities owned or leased by the City of Mauldin for city use except in designated areas defined in subsection (a). 
(c)  Violation and penalty. Any person who smokes or uses smokeless tobacco on municipal property or on parks and recreation facilities, or who causes, allows, or permits any person to smoke or use smokeless tobacco on municipal property or in parks and recreation facilities, except outdoors in designated areas, is in violation of this section and subject to its remedies and penalties. 
Any person in violation of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, must be fined between $10.00 and $25.00. (S.C. Code § 44-95-10 et seq. (1976, as amended)). 
(d)  Other applicable laws. This section shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking or the use of smokeless tobacco where it is otherwise restricted by other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 814, 12-19-2016) 
Editor's note— It should be noted, Ord. No. 814, adopted Dec. 19, 2016, has an effective date of July 1, 2017.  
Secs. 18-40—18-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ABANDONED AND JUNK MOTOR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 38. 
State Law reference— Disposition of abandoned and derelict motor vehicles on public and private property, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-5810 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-61. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Motor vehicle means any self-propelled land, water, or air vehicle which can be used for towing or transporting people or materials including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, buses, motor homes, motorized campers, boats, airplanes, motorcycles, motor scooters, tractors, snowmobiles, dune buggies, or other off the road vehicles. 
Motor vehicle, abandoned or derelict, means a motor vehicle: 
(1)  Left unattended or inoperable on public property other than a public street for more than 48 hours, or a motor vehicle that has remained illegally on private or public property for a period of more than seven days without the consent of the owner or person in control of the property; 
(2)  Of which the certificate of registration has expired and the registered and legal owner no longer resides at the address listed on the certificate of registration on record with the department and who cannot be found after a reasonable search; 
(3)  Of which the manufacturer's serial plates, motor vehicle identification numbers, license number plates, or any other means of identification have been removed so as to nullify efforts to locate or identify the registered and legal owner; 
(4)  Left unattended or inoperable upon a street or highway in violation of a law or ordinance controlling traffic or prohibiting parking and constituting a hazard to life or property; or 
(5)  Of which the registered and legal owner of record disclaims ownership or releases his rights thereto. 
Motor vehicle, junk, means any motor vehicle incapable of self-propulsion or being moved in the manner for which it was originally intended or in the condition of which is wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, or discarded, or cannot safely or legally be operated, or declared to be a nuisance by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 13-51) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-62. - Abandonment unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon any motor vehicle, including junk motor vehicles, on any private street, right-of-way or public grounds or upon any privately owned property; and it shall be unlawful for any person, including an owner or occupant, controlling privately owned property to abandon or to permit the abandonment thereupon of any motor vehicle. 
(Code 1994, § 13-52)  
Sec. 18-63. - Removal. 
The person responsible, or the registered owner of any such vehicle if such can be determined after reasonable search, or the owner of the premises on which such vehicle is located, or all, shall be given notice as prescribed in subsection (2) to remove and dispose of an abandoned vehicle at his own expense, or he shall be in violation of this article. 
(1)  Public property. If such person or owner cannot be determined or has not complied within the time prescribed by the notice, such vehicle, if located on public property, at the discretion of the city, may be removed to a storage area for safekeeping, at the direction of the city. Written notice of such removal shall be promptly given to the registered owner of the vehicle and to any holders of any lien on record in the office of the state department of motor vehicles, if such can be determined after a reasonable search. The city may remove such vehicles without prior notice when such vehicles constitute a safety hazard or other public nuisance. 
(2)  Private property. If located on private property, no such vehicle shall be so removed from such premises by the city without the written authorization of the owner of the vehicle, if known, or the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises, unless the vehicle has been declared by order of the codes enforcement officer, after due notice and hearing, to be a safety hazard or other public nuisance. Upon the issuance of such order, the costs of removal and disposal may be assessed against the person responsible for the nuisance. Such costs may be placed as a lien against his property, and such lien shall be collectible in the same manner as municipal taxes. 
(Code 1994, § 13-53)  
Sec. 18-64. - Disposition of vehicles. 
(a)  The owner of any removed vehicle, before obtaining possession thereof, shall pay to the city all reasonable costs incidental to its removal, storage or the locating of the owner. 
(b)  Should such owner fail or refuse to pay the costs within 20 days after receipt of the notice, or should his identity or whereabouts be unknown or unascertainable after a reasonable search and after notice, the stored vehicle may be sold after 20 days' notice has been given to the department of motor vehicles before the date of the sale and after the vehicle has been held for not less than 30 days. Junk motor vehicles and motor vehicle accessories shall govern disposition of any junk motor vehicles and motor vehicle accessories, section 18-65. 
(c)  The vehicle may be sold by public sale, after one public notice published in a newspaper of general circulation, but no vehicle may be sold or disposed of until its value has been determined in writing by at least two disinterested dealers or garagemen. 
(d)  A vehicle of an appraised value of less than $50.00 may be disposed of by any means in the discretion of the storing agent of the city. 
(e)  The proceeds of any sale shall be forwarded to the finance administrator, who shall pay from the proceeds the costs of removal, storage, investigation as to ownership and sale and other liens, in that order. If after the sale the ownership at the time of removal is established satisfactorily to the finance administrator, the owner shall be paid so much of the proceeds as remains after payment of the foregoing costs and liens. Otherwise, any remaining proceeds shall be deposited 90 days in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 13-54)  
Sec. 18-65. - Junk motor vehicles and motor vehicle accessories. 
(a)  The person responsible, or the owner of the premises on which such vehicle and/or motor vehicle accessories are located, or the registered owner of any such vehicle and/or motor vehicle accessories if such can be determined after reasonable search, or all, shall be given notice as prescribed in this article to remove and dispose of such vehicle and/or motor accessories at his own expense, or he shall be in violation of this article. If such person or owner cannot be determined or has not complied within the time prescribed by the notice, any such vehicle and/or motor vehicle accessories at the discretion of the city may be removed from public property to a storage area for safekeeping at the direction of the city. No such vehicle and/or motor vehicle accessories shall be so removed from privately owned premises, without the written authorization of the registered owner of the vehicle and/or motor vehicle accessories, if known, or the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises, unless the vehicle and/or motor vehicle accessories have been declared by order other codes enforcement officer, after due notice and hearing, to be a safety hazard or other public nuisance. Upon the issuance of such order, the costs of its removal and disposal may be assessed against the person responsible for the nuisance, and such costs may be placed as a lien against his property and collectible in the same manner as municipal taxes. 
(b)  A junk motor vehicle and/or vehicle accessories may be posted in place, and its owner may reclaim it by exhibiting reasonable proof of ownership and paying all reasonable costs incident to its removal, storage and administrative expenses. An unclaimed junk motor vehicle and/or motor vehicle accessories may be destroyed or otherwise disposed of in summary manner after 20 days following possession of such vehicle and/or accessories under the provisions of this article. Notice shall be promptly given after final disposition to the state department of motor vehicles on such forms as it provides that it was deemed a junk motor vehicle and disposed of as such. This notice shall fully and accurately describe such disposition of junk motor vehicles and/or motor vehicle accessories shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, after notification has been given, to remove any junk motor vehicle or motor vehicle accessories from any private property upon which such storage is not permitted or onto any public highway or other public property for purposes of storage. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to any motor vehicle or motor vehicle accessories completely screened by legally installed and maintained solid fencing, walls, buildings, landscape features, or a combination thereof. No vehicle or accessory shall exceed the height of the solid screen enclosure as to be readily visible from any public place or from any surrounding private property. 
(Code 1994, § 13-55)  
Sec. 18-66. - Disposition with owner's consent. 
With a vehicle owner's written consent, the city at its own discretion may remove and immediately dispose of any vehicle as a junk motor vehicle regardless of value or condition of the vehicle and without waiting such periods. Costs may be assessed to the vehicle owner. 
(Code 1994, § 13-56)  
Secs. 18-67—18-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - NOISE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 892, adopted Feb. 18, 2019, repealed div. 3 in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Former div. 3, §§ 18-91—18-100, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 550, § 1(13-71—13-80), adopted Oct. 15, 2001; and Ord. No. 576, §§ 1—5, adopted May 19, 2003. 
 
Sec. 18-91. - Findings. 
This article shall apply to the control of sound originating within the limits of the City of Mauldin. Prohibitions contained and enacted in this division are in pursuance of and for the purpose of securing and promoting the public health, comfort, convenience, safety, welfare, prosperity, peace, and quiet of the city and its inhabitants. The City of Mauldin finds that excessive sound is a serious hazard to the public health, welfare, and safety of citizens and their quality of life. A substantial body of science and general knowledge exists which shows that excessive noise is harmful to humans and diminishes their quality of life. Therefore, noise must be regulated in order to abate excessive noise. People have a right to an environment free from excessive noise. It is the policy of the City of Mauldin to prevent excessive sound that may jeopardize the health, welfare, or safety of the citizens or degrade their quality of life. 
(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019)  
Sec. 18-92. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ambient noise means the general prevailing sound or combination of sounds at the location where a listener receives the sound of the noise about which a complaint has been or is being made. It is the sound or combination of sounds which a person of ordinary sensibilities would reasonably expect to encounter at the location in the ordinary and customary use of the premises. 
Continuous sound means any sound which exists, essentially without interruption, for a period of five minutes or more. 
C-weighting is the electronic filtering in sound level meters that models a flat response (output equals input) over the range of maximum human hearing frequency sensitivity. 
dBA is the A-weighted unit of sound pressure level. 
Decibel (dB) is the unit of measurement for sound pressure level at a specified location. 
Emergency vehicle means a motor vehicle used in response to any emergency or to protect persons or property from imminent exposure to danger. 
Emergency work means work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, or work required to protect persons from an imminent exposure to danger. 
Motor vehicle means any vehicle which is self-propelled by mechanical power including, but not limited to, passenger cars, trucks, truck-trailers, semitrailers, campers, motorcycles, minibikes, go-carts, and racing vehicles. 
Noise means any sound which is unwanted or which causes or tends to cause an adverse psychological or physiological effect on human beings. 
Noise disturbance means any sound which annoys or disturbs the comfort, quiet, or repose of reasonable persons with normal sensitivities, or which injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, hearing, peace, and safety of such persons. 
Person means any human being, firm, association, organization, partnership, business, trust, corporation, company, contractor, supplier, installer, user, owner or operator, including any municipal corporation or its officers or employees. 
Property boundary means any imaginary line exterior to any enclosed structure, at the ground surface, and its vertical extension, which separates the real property owned by one person from that owned by another person. 
Property line means that part of a parcel of land legally approved and recorded and described by metes and bounds or an apartment, motel room or similar dwelling the interior wall or the common wall separating the living units or exterior wall of the building. 
Public right-of-way means any street, avenue, boulevard, highway, or alley, or similar place which is owned or controlled by a public governmental entity. 
Stationary noise source means any device, fixed or movable, which is located or used on property other than a public right-of-way. 
Use district means those districts established by the city zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-93. - Prohibited noise generally. 
(a)  Any noise emanating from within the jurisdictional limits of the city of such character, intensity, or duration which substantially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of persons with ordinary sensibilities occupying, owning, or controlling nearby properties within the jurisdictional limits of the city, or persons making use of public properties for their intended purposes, is hereby declared to be unlawful, constitutes a nuisance, and is prohibited. (See also section 18-97, enforcement factors, and section 18-99, measurement of noise level; establishment of prima facie violation.) 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued: 
(1)  Any excessive or loud noise which disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary sensitivity, within the jurisdictional limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019)  
Sec. 18-94. - Standard of reasonableness and use of technology. 
It is the intent of the city council in regulating noise to take into account the latest scientific advances in noise measurement and control while at the same time preserving the common sense and common law determination of what constitutes a disturbance or public nuisance. Therefore, technological sound level measurements, while desirable, shall not be required to demonstrate a violation of this section or any other ordinance or statute which establishes the creation of disturbance or public nuisance. Decibel measurements less than those specified in this section may still establish a violation of this section when due regard is made for time, place, and circumstance of the noise. 
(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019)  
Sec. 18-95. - Specific noises prohibited. 
(a)  Operation of certain instruments, devices, and equipment. Noise disturbances shall include, but not be limited to, the use and operation of the following instruments, devices, or pieces of equipment or the human voice when operated or used in the manner prohibited by section 18-93: 
(1)  Musical instruments. 
(2)  Radios, receivers, stereos, televisions, disc players, tape players, and comparable mechanical and electronic devices which produce sound. 
(3)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers or other devices which enhance or influence the level of sound in any way. 
(4)  Mechanical devices operating by compressed air, such as pneumatic drills and jackhammers. 
(5)  Horns, sirens and signal devices using loud, brash or harassing noises, whether on vehicles or otherwise, except when used as a warning or danger signal. 
(6)  Motor vehicle exhausts without mufflers or with inefficient or ineffective mufflers. 
(7)  The human voice when used to yell, shout, scream or the like. 
(8)  Construction machinery, heavy-duty equipment used in street repair and maintenance, and domestic and commercial power tools when operated from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m., unless a permit is obtained. 
(9)  The creation of unreasonably loud, raucous, and excessive noise in connection with the loading or unloading of any vehicle at a place of business or residence. 
(10)  The repair, rebuilding or testing of any motor vehicle in any residential district, so as to cause loud or offensive noises to be emitted therefrom during the hours between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(b)  Continuous or repeated sounds. Regardless of the level of sound, the following shall be deemed a nuisance and shall be prohibited under section 18-93: 
(1)  To keep any animal, including a bird, causing a frequent or long continued noise, such as barking, howling or screeching, which disturbs the comfort and repose of any reasonable person with ordinary sensibilities in the immediate vicinity. 
(2)  To install or operate a burglar alarm system which uses an audible warning or bell without a functioning device that will shut off the warning or bell within 20 minutes after the activation of the system when the alarm cannot be readily or conveniently silenced manually by persons who are disturbed by its activation. Each activation of such an alarm that continues beyond 20 minutes shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)  The procedure for responding to a noise complaint shall be as follows: 
(1)  Complaints must be reported to Mauldin law enforcement officer and shall include the name, address, and telephone number of the complainant, as well as the address, to the extent known, of the person responsible for the noise. 
(2)  Upon receiving a complaint as described in subsection (c)(1) of this section, the chief of police or any law enforcement officer, after verification of the complaint, and when reasonable and practical to do so, may give an oral or written warning to cease and abate the noise immediately, or as soon as reasonable and practical, prior to being charged with a violation. 
(3)  If a second complaint is received and verified by the chief of police or any law enforcement officer, and previous notification has been given to cease and abate the noise, a citation may be issued to the person responsible for the offending noise. 
(4)  Additional complaints, when verified by a law enforcement officer, shall each constitute a separate violation for which a citation may be issued to the person responsible for the noise. 
(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019)  
Sec. 18-96. - Exemptions. 
The following uses and activities shall be exempt: 
(1)  Noises from safety signals, warning devices, and emergency pressure relief valves. 
(2)  Noises resulting from an authorized vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or acting in time of an emergency. 
(3)  Noise resulting from emergency work. 
(4)  Any other noise resulting from activities of a temporary duration permitted by law and for which a license or permit therefor has been granted by the city. 
(5)  Any aircraft operated in conformity with, or pursuant to, federal law, federal air regulations, and air traffic control instruction used pursuant to and within the duly adopted federal air regulations. 
(6)  Except as specifically prohibited pursuant to section 18-95, any motor vehicle operating lawfully upon the public streets, roads, and highways in the city. 
(7)  Any railroad vehicles operating lawfully in the city. 
(8)  The sound produced by bells or chimes or other carillon instruments when used to signify the passage of an hour, half-hour, or quarter-hour components or to commemorate a wedding, funeral, or similar event, including religious services, provided that the sounds do not exceed five continuous minutes of duration in any one-hour period. 
(9)  Sound emanating from a ballpark, playing field, stadium, or comparable outdoor facility designed and intended for recreational sports activity when used for organized exhibition or participatory sports, recreational activities or scheduled outdoor events. 
(10)  Sound at community concerts, street fairs or parades which are conducted, sponsored or sanctioned by the city. 
(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019)  
Sec. 18-97. - Enforcement factors. 
In the enforcement of this section, an enforcement officer may be required to exercise judgement in determining if a particular noise is sufficiently loud or otherwise so offensive that it would substantially interfere with persons occupying nearby public or private property. When making such determinations, the enforcement officer may consider the following and other relevant factors: 
(1)  The time of day or night the noise occurs; 
(2)  The land use, nature, and zoning of the area from which the noise emanates and the area where it is received or perceived; 
(3)  The proximity of the noise to sleeping facilities, whether residential or commercial, during the hours of 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m.; 
(4)  The duration of the noise; 
(5)  Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent, or constant; 
(6)  The volume and intensity of the noise. 
(7)  Whether the nature of the noise is usual or unusual. 
(8)  Whether the origin of the noise is natural or unnatural. 
(9)  The type and intensity of ambient noise, if any. 
(See also section 18-93, prohibited noises generally, and section 18-99, measurement of noise level; establishment of prima facie violation.) 
(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019)  
Sec. 18-98. - Application for special permit. 
Applications for a permit for relief from the noise level designated in this division on the basis of reasonable cause may be made to the chief of police or his designee. Any permit granted under this division shall contain all conditions upon which such permit has been granted and shall specify a reasonable time that the permit shall be effective. The chief of police or his designee may grant a permit if it is found that: 
(1)  Additional time is necessary for the applicant to alter or modify his activity or operation to comply with this division; 
(2)  The activity, operation, or noise source will be of a temporary duration, and cannot be done in a manner which would comply with other subsections of this section; and 
(3)  No reasonable alternative is available to the applicant. 
The chief of police or his designee may prescribe any conditions or requirements he deems necessary to minimize adverse effects upon the community or a nearby neighborhood. 
(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019)  
Sec. 18-99. - Measurement of noise level; establishment of prima facie violation. 
A prima facie violation of section 18-93 shall be established whenever a measurement of offending noise shall be taken in accord with this section and shown to produce a level of noise in excess of the guidelines of the chart contained in this section. Noise levels identified in the chart of guidelines shall be measured in decibels and A-weighted, with the unit of measurement being designated as dB(A). For the purpose of determining dB(A)s, the noise shall be measured on the A-weighting scale having characteristics established by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). Measurements recorded shall be taken so as to provide a reasonable representation of the sound being measured with due regard to the location on the premises where the noise is heard by any person making a complaint. Precise positioning of the meter is not required. Guideline measurements establishing a prima facie violation for common noises are as follows: 
Noise Limit Table 
(1)  Except as authorized elsewhere in this article, no person shall cause, allow, or permit the operation of any sound source, including amplified sound, on a property or any public space or right-of-way located in the city in a manner which creates a sound level that exceeds the sound level limits set forth below unless otherwise noted. Such a sound constitutes a noise disturbance.

(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019)  
Sec. 18-100. - Enforcement procedures; penalty; additional remedies. 
The chief of police will have primary responsibility for the enforcement of the noise regulations contained in this division. Nothing in this division shall prevent the chief of police from obtaining voluntary compliance by way of warning, notice, or education. All law enforcement officers in the ordinary course of their duties shall have the authority to advise persons of the provisions of this section and request compliance without having received a complaint from a member of the public. However, no charge shall be made against any person unless: (1) a complaint is made to an officer or other agent of the city, or; (2) a law enforcement officer hears and observes the noise, and the person has first been provided an opportunity to abate the offending noise immediately without penalty. However, if the violation continues or reoccurs, or if the same person has been provided an opportunity within the preceding 30 days to abate a noise at the same location, and the person continues to make the noise or continues to allow it to be made, then such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined and/or be imprisoned as provided in section 1-6 . The city attorney may also seek any other appropriate remedy in the discretion of the city attorney available at law or in equity, in a court of competent jurisdiction, to ensure compliance. 
(Ord. No. 892, 2-18-2019)  
Chapter 20 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; fire district, § 8-3; civil emergencies, ch. 14. 
State Law reference— Fire protection generally, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-25-10 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 20-1. - Obstructing fire equipment, firefighters; parking near fire hydrant. 
No person shall park any vehicle or otherwise cause any obstruction to fire equipment at a fire or at an entrance to the fire station, or park within 15 feet of any fire hydrant. It shall be unlawful to interfere with or obstruct the activities of any member of the fire department who is acting in the line of duty at or proceeding to a fire. 
(Code 1994, § 9-2) 
Cross reference— Stopping, standing and parking, § 38-81 et seq. 
State Law reference— Parking near fire hydrant, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2530.  
Sec. 20-2. - Following fire apparatus too closely or parking near fire. 
No unauthorized person with any vehicle shall follow within 500 feet of any apparatus belonging to the fire department while such apparatus is en route to a fire or park within 300 feet of a fire. 
(Code 1994, § 9-3) 
Cross reference— Stopping, standing and parking, § 38-81 et seq. 
State Law reference— Following or parking near fire apparatus, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1960.  
Sec. 20-3. - Unauthorized riding on fire apparatus or handling of equipment. 
No person not a member of the fire department, unless authorized by a proper official, shall be allowed to ride on the fire apparatus or handle equipment. 
(Code 1994, § 9-4)  
Sec. 20-4. - Installation of fire hydrants and other fire protection devices. 
(a)  All fire hydrants and other fire protection devices installed by developers or other parties or interests in dealing with the improvement of land or other properties within the city shall be installed in accordance with the then prevailing rules, regulations and specifications of the commission of public works of the City of Greenville, South Carolina, and shall meet all current Fire Underwriters' requirements for class three fire insurance protective rates. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the commission of public works of the City of Greenville, South Carolina, to furnish or supply water to any hydrants installed, constructed or erected by the developers of new subdivisions or areas within the limits of the city which fail to meet the requirements of this section. 
(c)  Whenever any property is being developed and/or water lines being installed to service any area in the city limits, there shall be placed, at intervals of no more than 1,000 feet apart for residential areas and 500 feet apart for commercial areas, fire hydrants as approved by the chief of the fire department. Distances between fire hydrants shall be measured along street lines and not across property lines. 
(d)  Whenever any property within the city is rezoned to become a commercial zone, the owner must install any necessary fire hydrants called for under this section as a condition of rezoning and such hydrants must be installed prior to the issuing of any building permits for that property. 
(Code 1994, § 9-5)  
Sec. 20-5. - Fire investigations and reports. 
The inspector of buildings shall investigate all fires and file a report to the state fire marshal as provided by S.C. Code 1976, §§ 5-25-160—5-25-210. The mayor, chief of the fire department or any municipal official may be ex officio inspector of buildings. 
(Code 1994, § 9-6)  
Sec. 20-6. - Firefighter's insurance and inspection fund. 
The city hereby accepts the benefits of S.C. Code 1976, § 38-57-10 et seq., relative to the disposition of funds arising from insurance companies doing business in the state and the compulsory inspections to qualify therefor. 
(Code 1994, § 9-7)  
Sec. 20-7. - Penalty for fires due to criminal carelessness. 
If the investigating officer shall consider that any fire is due to criminal carelessness, the person responsible for such fire shall be indicted before a magistrate for a misdemeanor and, upon conviction for the same, may be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 9-8) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-25-190.  
Sec. 20-8. - Open burning. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to start, or cause to be started, an open fire to burn any woodlands, brush, grass, structures, leaves, debris or other matter, except as provided in this section. 
(b)  The city fire department may burn for official training purposes. 
(c)  The city may issue a burning permit, at its discretion, for the burning of trees, brush and undergrowth on land in excess of five acres where such land has been cleared for development, under the following conditions: 
(1)  The applicant shall give the city notice in writing of all information required by the city. This notice shall include, but not be limited to, the location of the proposed burn, the material to be burned, the times and dates of the proposed burn, and the location of public roads, streets, property lines, and dwellings in the proximity of the burn. 
(2)  The applicant shall clear the area around the burn site and have immediately available sufficient equipment and personnel to adequately secure the fire and prevent its spread. If, in the opinion of the fire department, it is necessary for the city to send fire department equipment to the burn site, the applicant shall be responsible to pay for the reasonable cost thereof, as determined by the city. 
(3)  No matter may be burned which is not native to the site. 
(4)  The applicant shall conduct the burn at such location and under such conditions that smoke or fumes will not go onto any roadway or the property of others and not pose a health or environmental hazard. Weather, atmospheric conditions and recent rainfall shall also be factors to be considered. 
(5)  No burning shall be carried out during any period which the governor or other authorized official has declared that an emergency exists in connection with forest fires or open burning. 
(6)  The applicant agrees to be fully responsible for any damages or injuries to others as a result of the burning activity. The city requires the applicant to provide proof of liability insurance in such amounts as determined by the city. 
(7)  The city may impose such other conditions and restrictions as are deemed appropriate based on the type and size of the proposed burn. 
(8)  The chief of the fire department and city administrator are authorized to establish additional rules and regulations for burning permits. 
(9)  The applicant will pay a permit fee as determined by resolution of the city council. No permit shall be issued without the approval of the city council. 
(d)  This section shall not prohibit cooking fires built in fireplaces, grills or barbecue pits which shall be kept under competent and continuous supervision. 
(e)  The city may issue permits for open fires as part of special events under such terms and conditions as provided by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 9-9)  
Sec. 20-9. - Fire sprinklers. 
(a)  Required. All new construction shall be equipped with an approved automatic quick response fire sprinkler system installed to the N.F.P.A. 13 or other applicable national standards to the following classification of occupied structures: Group R occupancies and multiple dwelling structures including hotels, motels, motor inns, apartment houses, apartment hotels, convents, dormitories, townhouses, condominiums and other similar buildings except single-family structures and duplex apartments. 
(b)  Retrofitting existing buildings. Existing buildings, as defined in Group R, shall be made to conform to the requirements of this section if such building is altered, improved or repaired after damage by fire or otherwise, the cost of which equals or exceeds 50 percent of the then physical value of the building immediately preceding any alterations or improvements thereto or any damage thereof. 
(c)  Physical value. Physical value in this section shall mean the estimated cost to replace the building in-kind. The city shall determine the physical value based upon documentation submitted by the owner or other interested parties. 
(d)  Inspections and certifications. Each building's owner shall have each standpipe and sprinkler system inspected and certified annually by a qualified sprinkler contractor or qualified individual. A copy of that certification shall be forwarded to the fire department. 
(e)  Compliance and approval. No automatic fire sprinkler system required by this section shall be installed without prior approval by the fire chief. 
(f)  Alternate/modified sprinkler system. The N.F.P.A. 13D Standard does not recommend installation of sprinkler systems in multiple dwellings. A sprinkler system conforming to an applicable national standard will be considered by the fire department. 
(Code 1994, § 9-10)  
Secs. 20-10—20-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to adopt technical codes by reference, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-280. 
 
Sec. 20-41. - Code adopted. 
The currently adopted fire prevention codes enforced in the City of Mauldin are those, which the State of South Carolina has mandated by legislation and as posted by the South Carolina Labor, Licensing and Regulation Building Codes Council (www.llr.state.sc.us/POL/BCC/.). In addition, the City of Mauldin, by local ordinance also adopts Chapter I Administration in its entirety as referenced in the enacted International Codes. 
(Code 1994, § 9-36; Ord. No. 538, § 1, 6-18-2001; Ord. No. 822A, § 1, 4-17-2017)  
Sec. 20-42. - Enforcement. 
The code adopted by this article shall be enforced by the chief of the fire department, subject to such rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the chief insurance commissioner. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with such code. The chief of the department shall have the authority to reference the following appendices on matters of interpretation and application of the codes when warranted to ensure the public health, safety and welfare: Appendices D - Fire Department Access Roads, Appendix F - Hazard Ranking, and Appendix I- Fire Protection Systems - Noncompliant Conditions, when such circumstances and life safety concerns are warranted. 
(Code 1994, § 9-37; Ord. No. 822A, § 3, 4-17-2017)  
Sec. 20-43. - Storage of explosives and blasting agents, storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks and bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas. 
The limits referred to in the code adopted by this article, in which storage of explosives and blasting agents is prohibited, the limits referred to in such code, in which storage of class 1 liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited, and the limits referred to in such code, in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted, are hereby established as within areas zoned OD, C-1, C-2, or I-1. 
(Code 1994, § 9-38)  
Sec. 20-44. - Modifications. 
The chief of the fire department shall have the power to modify any of the provisions of the currently adopted International Fire Code as mandated by the state, upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code; provided, however, that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modifications when granted or allowed, and the decision of the chief of the fire department thereon, shall be entered upon the records of the department, and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1994, § 9-39; Ord. No. 822A, § 2, 4-17-2017)  
Sec. 20-45. - Appeals. 
Whenever the chief of the fire department shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the currently adopted International Fire Code as mandated by the state, do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of such code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief of the fire department to the city council within 30 days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Code 1994, § 9-40; Ord. No. 822A, § 2, 4-17-2017)  
Sec. 20-46. - Violations. 
Any person who is convicted of violating any provision of this article or of the code hereby adopted shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, unless a different penalty is provided for a specific offense, shall be punishable as provided in section 1-6. All persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time, and when not otherwise specified, each day that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. The application of such penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions by court order. 
(Code 1994, § 9-41)  
Sec. 20-47. - Flameproofing decorative materials used in places of public assembly. 
In addition to the requirements of the currently adopted International Fire Code as mandated by the state, relative to decorative materials in places of assembly, all combustible decorative materials, including curtains, acoustical materials, streamers, cloth, cotton batting, straw, vines, leaves, trees and moss, but not including floor coverings, shall be rendered flameproof; provided that this shall not be required of materials not exceeding 1/16 of an inch in thickness applied directly to and adhering to a noncombustible base. Such flameproofing, unless certified by Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., or other laboratories of recognized standing as being of a permanent nature, shall be tested by the council each six months and the treatment renewed if necessary. 
(Code 1994, § 9-42; Ord. No. 822A, § 2, 4-17-2017)  
Sec. 20-48. - Permit for use of certain decorative materials; flameproofing of materials used to decorate electric lightbulbs. 
Cotton batting, straw, dry vines, leaves, trees, celluloid or other highly flammable materials shall not be used for decoration purposes in show windows or stores without a permit; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be held to prohibit the display of saleable goods permitted and offered for sale in the store. Electric lightbulbs in stores or public halls shall not be decorated with paper or other combustible materials, unless such materials shall first have been rendered flameproof. 
(Code 1994, § 9-43)  
Sec. 20-49. - Fire alarm boxes in hospitals and public schools. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of applicable requirements of the currently adopted International Fire Code as mandated by the state, each hospital operating over ten beds and all public schools in which there is a general fire alarm station and an electrically operated fire alarm system shall be equipped with a fire alarm box of the type and character used in the city, to be located on the premises at such place as the chief of the fire department may direct. When such box is installed by such hospital or public school, the municipal authorities shall connect such box with the general fire alarm system and shall thereafter maintain such box in good repair, and such municipal authorities or their agents may enter every such hospital or school at any reasonable time for the purpose of inspecting and repairing any such box. The failure to so install and equip any such hospital or public school shall be a misdemeanor and punishable in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 9-44; Ord. No. 822A, § 2, 4-17-2017) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-25-40.  
Secs. 20-50—20-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to equip and control a fire department, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-25-20. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 20-81. - Officers. 
(a)  The fire department shall consist of a chief and other officers as may be deemed necessary by the city council for the effective operation of the department. 
(b)  The chief shall be appointed by the city administrator with the approval of the city council for an indefinite period, and his tenure of office shall depend upon his good conduct and efficiency. He shall be technically qualified by training and experience and shall have ability to command men and hold their respect and confidence. He shall be suspended only for just cause by the city administrator. 
(c)  The chief shall be held accountable for the fire department only and shall make written and verbal reports to the city council as the city council may require. 
(Code 1994, § 9-66) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq. 
State Law reference— Appointment of chief of fire department, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-25-110.  
Sec. 20-82. - Members. 
The volunteer membership of the fire department shall consist of citizens 18 years old or older residing in the fire district of the city or the city's fire service area and who qualify for membership by meeting the selection criterion provided in the official city job description. All memberships in the volunteer fire department will be considered as part-time employees and subject to all departmental and city regulations. 
(Code 1994, § 9-67)  
Sec. 20-83. - Equipment. 
(a)  The fire department shall be equipped with such apparatus and other equipment as may be required from time to time to maintain its efficiency and properly protect life and property from fire. 
(b)  Recommendations of apparatus and equipment needed shall be made by the chief or the fire committee of the city council and shall be purchased in such manner as may be designated by the city council. 
(c)  No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private purpose, nor shall any person wilfully and without proper authority take away or conceal any article used in any way by the department. 
(d)  No person shall use or tamper with the fire trucks or fire equipment owned by the city, unless authorized to do so by the mayor, the councilmember in charge of the fire department or the chief. 
(Code 1994, § 9-68)  
Sec. 20-84. - Duties generally. 
(a)  Chief. The chief shall be held responsible for the general conditions and efficient operation of the fire department, the training of members and the performance of all other duties imposed upon him. 
(b)  Drivers. Drivers shall be thoroughly familiar with the territory to be served, including the condition of the routes during the different seasons and the location of all water supplies. They shall observe speed limits which are consistent with safety, considering traffic, weather and road conditions. Special care shall be taken when approaching all intersections, the apparatus being kept under control at all times. 
(c)  Members. All members shall assist in the work of the fire department as ordered and trained and, in the absence of specific orders, shall do as they see fit. All members shall attend regular meetings and drills, if possible, to increase the efficiency of the department. Each member is responsible for his fire helmet, coat, boots and pants, and when his membership in the department is terminated, he shall return all department property in his possession to the chief. 
(Code 1994, § 9-69)  
Sec. 20-85. - Enforcement of chapter. 
All regularly appointed members of the fire department are hereby given the necessary special powers to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 9-70)  
Sec. 20-86. - Insignia for cars. 
Each member of the fire department driving a car shall be issued a suitable insignia to be attached to the car. 
(Code 1994, § 9-71)  
Sec. 20-87. - Assistance by police. 
It is hereby made the special duty of the chief of police and other peace officers who may be on duty and available for fire duty to respond to all fire alarms and assist the fire department in the protection of life and property, in regulating traffic, in maintaining order and in enforcing observance of all sections of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 9-72)  
Sec. 20-88. - Rules; regulations. 
The city administrator and fire chief are empowered to make such rules and regulations necessary for the operation of the fire department as they deem necessary; provided that no such rules or regulations shall be inconsistent with the rules made by city council. 
(Code 1994, § 9-73)  
Secs. 20-89—20-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - EXTRATERRITORIAL FIRE PROTECTION 
 
Sec. 20-111. - When service permitted. 
No fire protection service shall be rendered outside the corporate limits by the fire department, except under the following conditions: 
(1)  To serve the fire service area pursuant to contract with the county. 
(2)  To protect property within the city or the fire service areas threatened by the fire from outside. 
(3)  Where human life is in danger. 
(4)  Pursuant to the terms of a mutual aid agreement. 
(Code 1994, § 9-86)  
Secs. 20-112—20-140. - Reserved.

Sec. 20-141. - Possession, sale, storage, transport or use. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, sell, offer for sale, store, transport or use any fireworks within the city. The term "fireworks," for the purposes of this section, shall be as defined in S.C. Code 1976, § 23-35-30. 
(Code 1994, § 9-111) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 23-35-30.  
Sec. 20-142. - Permits for special displays. 
The city council may, upon application, grant permits to persons or organizations for special fireworks displays. 
(Code 1994, § 9-112) 
State Law reference— Municipal permits for fireworks displays, S.C. Code 1976, § 23-35-60.  
Chapter 21 - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 685, § 1, adopted Dec. 15, 2008, set out provisions intended for use in ch. 5. For purposes of alphabetization, and to preserve the style of this Code, these provisions have been included as a new ch. 21, as set forth herein, at the discretion of the editor.  Subsequently, Ord. No. 771, § 2, repealed former ch. 21, and enacted new provisions as set out herein. Former ch. 21, §§ 21-1—21-13, 21-26—21-31, 21-41—21-45, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 685, § 1, adopted Dec. 15, 2008. 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; environment, ch. 18, streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; utilities, ch. 40. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 21-1. - Statutory authorization. 
The Legislature of the State of South Carolina has in SC Code of Laws, Title 5 and Title 6, and amendments thereto, delegated the responsibility to local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of its citizenry. Therefore, the City Council of the City of Mauldin, South Carolina does ordain as follows [below]. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2(Art. I, § A), 7-21-2014)  
Sec. 21-2. - Findings of fact. 
The special flood hazard areas of the City of Mauldin are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life, property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures of flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
Furthermore, these flood losses are caused by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities, and by the occupancy in flood hazard areas by uses vulnerable to floods or hazardous to other lands which are inadequately elevated, floodproofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2(Art. I, § B), 7-21-2014)  
Sec. 21-3. - Statement of purpose and objectives. 
It is the purpose of this chapter to protect human life and health, minimize property damage, and encourage appropriate construction practices to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions by requiring that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction. Uses of the floodplain which are dangerous to health, safety, and property due to water or erosion hazards, or which increase flood heights, velocities, or erosion are restricted or prohibited. These provisions attempt to control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers which are involved in the accommodation of floodwaters, and control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage or erosion. Additionally, the ordinance prevents or regulates the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert floodwaters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands. 
The objectives of this chapter are to protect human life and health, to help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of floodprone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas, and to insure that potential home buyers are notified that property is in a flood area. The provisions of the ordinance are intended to minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone, and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in the floodplain, and prolonged business interruptions. Also, an important floodplain management objective of this chapter is to minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects and rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding. 
Floodplains are an important asset to the community. They perform vital natural functions such as temporary storage of floodwaters, moderation of peak flood flows, maintenance of water quality, groundwater recharge, prevention of erosion, habitat for diverse natural wildlife populations, recreational opportunities, and aesthetic quality. These functions are best served if floodplains are kept in their natural state. Wherever possible, the natural characteristics of floodplains and their associated wetlands and water bodies should be preserved and enhanced. Decisions to alter floodplains, especially floodways and stream channels, should be the result of careful planning processes that evaluate resource conditions and human needs. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 2(Art. I, § C), 7-21-2014)  
Sec. 21-4. - Lands to which this chapter applies.
