(b)  Such assistance shall be rendered only in emergencies, and such emergency shall be declared by the governing body of the requesting political subdivision. 
(c)  When law enforcement officers are sent to another political subdivision pursuant to this section, the jurisdiction, authority, rights, privileges and immunities, including coverage under the worker's compensation laws, S.C. Code 1976, tit. 42, and tort liability coverage obtained pursuant to S.C. Code 1976, tit. 15, which they have shall be extended to and include the area in which like benefits and authorities are or could be afforded to the law enforcement officers of the requesting political subdivision. When so sent, they shall have the same authority to make arrests and to execute criminal process as is vested by law in the law enforcement officers of the requesting political subdivision, but this section shall not extend the effect of the laws of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 17-4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-120.  
Sec. 22-5. - Giving false name or address to officers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, when given a written promise to appear or given a written notice by any police officer to appear before the municipal court to answer for an offense against any law of the state, section of this Code or any other ordinance of the city, or during the course of any official investigation, to give an assumed or fictitious name or a false place of residence or address, or any other than his true name and the true place of his residence or address, upon the request of such officer. 
(Code 1994, § 17-5)  
Chapter 24 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; law enforcement, ch. 22; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 26; traffic and vehicles, ch. 38. 
State Law reference— Municipal courts, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-5 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 24-1. - Established; state law adopted. 
The city hereby establishes a municipal court, which shall be a part of the unified judicial system of this state, for the trial and determination of all cases within the jurisdiction of this city. S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-5 et seq. is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated as a part of this chapter as fully as though set out in this section. 
(Code 1994, § 12-1)  
Sec. 24-2. - Powers of municipal judge. 
The municipal judge of the city shall have all the power and authority of magistrates in criminal cases within the corporate limits and police jurisdiction of the city and especially shall have the power and authority to try speedily all offenders against this Code or other ordinances or laws of the city in a summary manner and without a jury, unless demanded by the accused. 
(Code 1994, § 12-2)  
Sec. 24-3. - Power to try cases, compel attendance of witnesses. 
The municipal judge shall speedily try all persons charged with violations of this Code or other ordinances of the city or the laws of the state within his jurisdiction. The municipal judge shall have the same power as a magistrate to compel the attendance of witnesses and require them to give evidence upon the trial of any person for the violation of this Code or other ordinances of the city or the laws of the state, subject to S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-30. The judge shall have no jurisdiction in civil matters. 
(Code 1994, § 12-3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-45.  
Sec. 24-4. - Clerk of court. 
A clerk of the municipal court shall be appointed by the city council to serve at the pleasure of the city council. The clerk of the municipal court shall keep such records and make such reports as may be determined by the state court administrator. 
(Code 1994, § 12-4) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq. 
State Law reference— Appointment and duties of clerk of court, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-35.  
Sec. 24-5. - Duty to attend court when summoned, subpoenaed or otherwise directed to appear. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to attend a session of the municipal court to which he has been directed by ticket, summons or subpoena signed by a police officer, the municipal judge or other presiding officer of the municipal court, whether such person so ticketed, summoned or subpoenaed is directed to appear as a witness, defendant or otherwise. It shall also be unlawful for any person under bond to appear before such court, at a time therein stated, to fail or refuse to so appear. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to attend or appear in the municipal court when ordered or directed so to do by the municipal judge or other presiding officer of such court when such order or directive has been given to such person in open court, whether such order or directive is in writing or verbal. The municipal judge or other presiding officer of the municipal court may excuse any person so ticketed, summoned, subpoenaed, ordered, directed or bound over from attending such court by general order of the court or otherwise as he, in his discretion, deems appropriate. 
(Code 1994, § 12-5)  
Sec. 24-6. - Appeals to court of general sessions. 
From all decisions of the municipal court, any party in interest, feeling himself aggrieved, may appeal to the court of general sessions for the county; provided, however, that he must give notice of such appeal in writing within ten days from the time of sentence or judgment. The appeal shall not operate to stay the execution of the sentence, unless the appellant gives bond, to be approved by the municipal judge, conditioned to abide the judgment of the court of general sessions or pay the fine assessed by the court. Payment of the fine imposed will in no case waive the right of appeal for ten days following payment. Such appeal in the court of general sessions shall be heard upon the report of the presiding officer of the trial below and upon the testimony reported by him. 
(Code 1994, § 12-6) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-95.  
Sec. 24-7. - Municipal judge; appointment; qualifications; term. 
The city council shall appoint a lawyer of good and reputable standing who is a member of the South Carolina Bar as a municipal judge for the municipal court. The attorney shall have at least two years' experience at the bar. The attorney shall hold office for two years or until his successor is appointed and qualified. The municipal judge shall not be considered an officer of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 12-7) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq.  
Secs. 24-8—24-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 24-41. - Authority to compel attendance of witnesses. 
The municipal judge has the same power which a magistrate now has to compel the attendance of witnesses and require them to give evidence upon the trial before them of any person for violation of the laws or the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 12-31)  
Sec. 24-42. - Recording testimony in jury trials. 
Any party shall have the right to have the testimony given at a jury trial taken stenographically or mechanically by a reporter. The requesting party shall pay the charges of such reporter for taking and transcribing if such testimony is recorded by a court reporter. 
(Code 1994, § 12-32) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-195.  
Sec. 24-43. - Proceedings to be commenced by information. 
All proceedings before the municipal judge in criminal cases shall be commenced on information under oath, plainly and substantially setting forth the offense charged, upon which, and only which, shall a warrant of arrest issue. The information may be amended at any time before trial. 
(Code 1994, § 12-33)  
Secs. 24-44—24-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PENALTY ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 24-81. - Imposition of penalties. 
Whenever the municipal judge shall find the party tried before him guilty of violating any provision of this Code or any other ordinance of the city, he may impose, in his discretion, a fine or imprisonment not to exceed the limits prescribed for such violation by such provision of this Code or other ordinance or, where a specific penalty for such violation is not provided, not to exceed those limits provided by section 1-6; provided, however, that such provisions of this Code or other ordinances, rules, bylaws or regulations are not contrary to the laws of the state. 
(Code 1994, § 12-56)  
Sec. 24-82. - Execution to sheriff to collect fines. 
The municipal judge may issue execution to the sheriff of the county or the police chief for the collection of all fines imposed by him. 
(Code 1994, § 12-57)  
Sec. 24-83. - Fines to go to city. 
All revenues arising from all fines imposed pursuant to this article shall be appropriated to the use of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 12-58) 
State Law reference— Disposition of fines and penalties, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-85.  
Secs. 24-84—24-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - JURIES 
 
Sec. 24-111. - Right to jury trial. 
Any person to be tried in municipal court may, prior to trial, demand a jury trial, and such jury when demanded shall be composed of six persons drawn from the qualified electors of the city in the manner prescribed in this article. The right to a jury trial shall be deemed to have been waived unless demand is made prior to trial. 
(Code 1994, § 12-81) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-125.  
Sec. 24-112. - Service on juries limited to two times per year. 
No person shall be required to serve on a jury in the municipal court more often than two times in each year. 
(Code 1994, § 12-82)  
Sec. 24-113. - Failure to obey jury summons. 
If any juror, duly summoned, shall neglect or refuse to appear in obedience to any venire issued by the municipal court and shall not, within 48 hours, render to the municipal judge a sufficient reason for his delinquency, he may be punished for contempt of court. 
(Code 1994, § 12-83) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-185.  
Sec. 24-114. - Jury commissioners. 
Jury commissioners shall be appointed in accordance with S.C. Code 1976, §§ 14-25-135 and 14-25-145. 
(Code 1994, § 12-84)  
Sec. 24-115. - Drawing of jury list; selection of jury from list. 
The drawing and composing of juries for single trials or terms of the municipal court shall be conducted, mutatis mutandi, according to the statutes relating to the drawing and composing of juries in magistrates' court, except as otherwise specifically provided by state law. 
(Code 1994, § 12-85) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-155.  
Sec. 24-116. - Drawing and summoning jurors by computer. 
In lieu of the manner required by this article, jurors for municipal courts, at the discretion of the city council, may be drawn and summoned by computer in the manner the supreme court, by order, directs. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-170.  
Sec. 24-117. - Essential service to business excuse. 
Upon furnishing an affidavit to the clerk of court requesting to be excused from jury duty, a person either may be excused or transferred to another term of court by the municipal judge if the person performs services for a business, commercial, or agricultural enterprise, and the person's services are so essential to the operations of the business, commercial, or agricultural enterprise that the enterprise must close or cease to function if the person is required to perform jury duty. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 14-25-180.  
Chapter 26 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Law enforcement, ch. 22; municipal court, ch. 24; traffic and vehicles, ch. 38. 
State Law reference— Crimes and offenses, S.C. Code 1976, tit. 16. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Fortunetelling, palmistry, and other forms of predicting future events. 
It shall be unlawful to engage in the business, trade or profession of fortunetelling, palmistry, phrenology, clairvoyance or the prediction of future events by cards or other means or to offer to tell fortunes or predict future events by palmistry, astrology, clairvoyance, cards or other means as an inducement to promote some other business, trade or profession. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 14-1) 
State Law reference— Fortunetelling, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-17-690.  
Sec. 26-2. - Advertisements. 
(a)  Placing on public property. It shall be unlawful to place any advertisement, business, political or otherwise, or any notice or sign of any nature on public property within the city, by the use of a placard, picture, paper, circular or painting or by any means or device whatsoever. 
(b)  Placing on property in which city has interest. It shall be unlawful to place any advertisement, business, political or otherwise, or any notice or sign of any nature on property in which the city has an interest or which the city has the right to regulate, such as a telephone pole, telegraph pole, electric pole or tower and the like. 
(c)  Placing on private property. It shall be unlawful to place any advertisement, business, political or otherwise, or any notice or sign of any nature on private property within the city, without written consent of the owner or lessee of the property. 
(Code 1994, § 14-3)  
Sec. 26-3. - Discharge of firearms within city. 
No person shall discharge any firearm within the city except by permission of the chief of police, granted for special occasions, except in proper position for firing salutes or by command of a proper military or police officer in the performance of official duty, or in a licensed shooting range or gallery. 
(Ord. No. 519, § 1, 9-25-2000) 
Cross reference— Firing pistols or guns in cemeteries, § 12-4.  
Sec. 26-4. - Casting dangerous object on to the property of others. 
No person shall discharge, fire, cast, or sling any arrow or other dangerous object, which might cause bodily harm to another person, onto or across the property of another person, without permission of the other property owner. 
(Ord. No. 519, § 2, 9-25-2000)  
Secs. 26-5—26-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Offenses against property, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-11-10 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-31. - Altering, removing, cutting landmarks. 
If any person shall knowingly, willfully, maliciously or fraudulently cut, fell, alter or remove any certain boundary tree or other allowed landmark, such person so offending shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 14-31) 
State Law reference— Altering and removing landmarks, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-11-680.  
Secs. 26-32—26-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - GRAFFITI 
 
Sec. 26-41. - Graffiti prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to either: 
(1)  Apply graffiti; or 
(2)  Attempt to apply graffiti; or 
(3)  Conspire to apply graffiti; or 
(4)  Solicit or command another person to apply graffiti; or 
(5)  Aid or abet another person in planning or applying graffiti to any public or private property, real or personal. 
(Ord. No. 674, 4-21-2008)  
Sec. 26-42. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this division, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the content clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Graffiti means any unauthorized inscription, word, figure, painting or other defacement that is written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn, painted, glued or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface of public or private property by any means whatsoever to the extend tot the graffiti was not authorized in advance by the owner or occupant of the property, or despite advance authorization, is otherwise deemed a public nuisance by council. 
Person means any individual, partnership, corporative association private corporation, personal representative, receiver, trustee, assignee or any other legal entity. 
(Ord. No. 674, 4-21-2008)  
Sec. 26-43. - Penalties. 
(a)  Fines and imprisonment. Any person violating this article shall be punished by a fine up to $500.00, or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed 30 days, or both by fine and imprisonment at the discretion of the court. 
(b)  Restitution. In addition to any punishment specified in this section, the court shall order any violator to make restitution to the victim for damages or loss directly or indirectly by the violator's offense in the amount or manner determined by the court. 
(c)  Community service. In lieu of, or as part of, the penalties specified in this section, a minor or adult may be required to perform community service. Reasonable effort shall be made to assign the minor or adult to a type of community service that is reasonable expected to have the most rehabilitative effect on the minor or adult, including community service that involves graffiti removal. 
(Ord. No. 674, 4-21-2008)  
Sec 26-44. - Graffiti as nuisance. 
(a)  The existence of graffiti on public or private property in violation of this article is expressly declared to be a public nuisance and, therefore, is subject to the removal and abatement provisions specified in this article. 
(b)  It is the duty of both the owner of the property to which the graffiti has been applied and any person who may be in position or who has the right to possess such property to at all times keep the property clear of graffiti. 
(Ord. No. 674, 4-21-2008)  
Sec. 26-45. - Removal of graffiti by perpetrator. 
Any person applying graffiti on public or private property shall have the duty to remove the graffiti within 24 hours after notice by the city or private owner of the property involved. Such removal shall be done in a manner prescribed by the chief of police, the director of the department of public works, or any additional city department head, as authorized by city council. Any person applying graffiti shall be responsible for the removal or for the payment of the removal. Failure of any person to remove graffiti or pay for the removal shall constitute an additional violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 674, 4-21-2008)  
Sec. 26-46. - Same—By property owner or city. 
If graffiti is not removed by the perpetrator according to section 26-45, graffiti shall be removed pursuant to the following provisions: 
(1)  Property owner responsibility. It is unlawful for any person who is the owner or who has primary responsibility for control of property or for repair or maintenance of property in the city to permit property that is defaced with graffiti to remain defaced for a period of ten days after service by first class mail of notice of the defacement. The notice shall contain the following information: 
a.  The street address and legal description of the property sufficient for identification of the property; 
b.  A statement that the property is a potential graffiti nuisance property with a concise description of the conditions leading to the finding; 
c.  A statement that the graffiti must be removed within ten days after receipt of the notice and that if the graffiti is not abated within that time the city will declare the property to be a public nuisance; 
d.  An information sheet identifying any graffiti removal assistance programs available through the city and private graffiti removal contractors. 
(2)  Exceptions to property owner responsibility. The removal requirements of subsection (a) above shall not apply if the property owner or responsibly party can demonstrate that: 
a.  The property owner or responsible party lacks the financial ability to remove the defacing graffiti or is actively engaged in actions to remove the graffiti, or 
b.  The property owner or responsible party has an active program for the removal of the graffiti and has scheduled the removal of the graffiti as part of that program, in which case it shall be unlawful to permit such property to remain defaced with graffiti for a period of 15 days after service by first class mail of notice of the defacement. 
(3)  Right of city to remove. 
a.  Use of public funds. Whenever the city becomes aware or is notified and determined that graffiti is located on publicly or privately owned property viewable from a public or quasi-public place, the city shall be authorized to use public funds for the removal of the graffiti, or for the painting or repairing of the graffiti, but shall not authorize or undertake to provide for the painting or repair of any more extended an area than that where the graffiti is located, unless the city administrator or other designee of the city administrator, determined in writing that a more extensive area is required to be repainted or repaired in order to avoid an aesthetic disfigurement to the neighborhood or community, or unless the property owner or responsible party agrees to pay for the costs of repainting or repairing the more extended area. 
b.  Right of entry on private property. Prior to entering upon private property or property owned by a public entity other than the city for the purpose of graffiti removal, the city shall attempt to secure the consent of the property owner or responsible party and a release of the city for liability for property damage or personal injury. 
(Ord. No. 674, 4-21-2008)  
Secs. 26-47—26-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE[3] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference— Offenses against the public peace, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-7-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 26-61. - Disruption of court or council. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to interrupt the proceedings of the municipal court or city council, or any meeting of the city council, or be guilty of disorderly conduct therein, or to commit any contempt of either. Every person found guilty and sentenced for a contempt shall be entitled to the right of appeal as is provided for by state law in appeals from the courts of municipalities and councils. 
(Code 1994, § 14-51)  
Secs. 26-62—26-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 
 
Sec. 26-91. - Abandoned iceboxes, refrigerators, or other airtight containers. 
Any person who abandons or discards any icebox, refrigerator, ice chest or other type of airtight container of a capacity sufficient to contain any child and who neglects prior to such abandonment to remove the door, lid or other device for the closing thereof, and any owner, lessee or other person in charge of property who knowingly permits any abandoned icebox, refrigerator, ice chest or other type of airtight container to remain thereon accessible to children without removing the door, lid or other closing device therefrom, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 14-91) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-3-1010.  
Sec. 26-92. - Closure of abandoned wells. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner or tenant to permit or allow any abandoned well to remain open and unprotected, curbed or fenced in on any place or premises owned or occupied in the city. Any person convicted of allowing any such abandoned well to remain open and unprotected, curbed or fenced in shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 14-92) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-3-1020.  
Sec. 26-93. - Discharging air rifles, slingshots, bows and arrows, or other dangerous devices. 
It shall be unlawful to discharge or fire any air rifle, slingshot, bow and arrow or other dangerous device on any public property within the city including, but not limited to, parks, sidewalks or streets, or near any public building, school, church, hospital or in any other public area where the firing or discharge of such device would tend to disturb the peace or endanger the life or property of any person. 
(Code 1994, § 14-93)  
Sec. 26-94. - Fences and gates; removing, destroying, leaving down. 
Any person, other than the owner, who shall remove, destroy or leave down any portion of any fence in the city intended to enclose animals of any kind or crops or cultivated lands, or who shall leave open any gate or leave down any bars or other structure intended for a like purpose, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 14-94)  
Sec. 26-95. - Pointing firearms at other persons. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to present or point at any other person any loaded or unloaded firearm, and upon conviction therefor, any such person shall be punished by fine or imprisonment. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to abridge the right of self-defense or to apply to theatricals or like performances. 
(Code 1994, § 14-96) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-23-410.  
Sec. 26-96. - Electric fences. 
Electric fences are prohibited in the city. Any device consisting of an electrically charged conductor or device intended to enclose, exclude, or resist persons or animals by electrical shock shall not be installed or used, regardless of the source of energy; however, this section shall not apply to "invisible fences" for animals. 
(Ord. No. 512, § 14-97, 12-20-1999)  
Sec. 26-97. - Resisting a stop by police; interfering with a law enforcement officer. 
It is unlawful for any person to resist or interfere with any law enforcement officer by any means including, but not limited to, flight, force, or threat of force, while the officer is performing official duties. Except as provided by law, it is not a defense to prosecution under this section that the offender believed the action of the officer was unlawful or unreasonable. Any person violating the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Ord. No. 548, § 1, 10-15-2001)  
Secs. 26-98—26-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS[4]

Sec. 26-131. - Gambling. 
(a)  Frequenting house or place for purpose of. It shall be unlawful for any person to indulge or play in any house or place in the city for the purpose of gambling in any form or permitting persons to resort in such location for such purpose. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Playing at games in which betting is involved; betting on other persons. It shall be unlawful for any person to play at any game with cards or dice, or by any other means or instruments in the city, when there is betting in such game, or for any person to bet on the side of hands of such as do play, whether the players are betting or not. 
(Code 1994, §§ 14-116, 14-117)  
Secs. 26-132—26-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - FALSE ALARMS 
 
Sec. 26-161. - Findings. 
The mayor and city council find that the police and fire departments are spending a considerable amount of time each year responding to false alarms. Such time represents not only a loss of valuable staff hours and needless expense to the city, but also may delay the response of police or fire personnel to a true emergency. Therefore, the mayor and city council find it necessary and appropriate to adopt an ordinance that encourages alarm users to properly use and maintain the operational effectiveness of alarm systems and to reduce or eliminate false alarms that may unduly divert emergency personnel from responding to true emergencies. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-130, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-162. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm administrator means a person or persons designated by the city administrator to administer, control and review false alarm reduction efforts. 
Alarm company means the business, by an individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving, installing or monitoring an alarm system in an alarm site. 
Alarm dispatch request means a notification to the police or fire departments that an alarm, either manual or automatic has been activated at a particular alarm site. 
Alarm registration means the notification by an alarm user to the alarm administrator that an alarm system has been installed and is in use. 
Alarm site means a single fixed premise or location served by an alarm system or systems. Each tenancy if served by a separate alarm system in a multitenant building or complex shall be considered a separate alarm site. 
Alarm system means a device or series of devices, including, but not limited to, systems interconnected with a radio frequency method such as cellular or private radio signals, which emit or transmit a remote or local audible, visual or electronic signal indicating an alarm condition and intended to summon police or fire service of the City of Mauldin. Alarm system does not include an alarm installed on a vehicle or person. 
Alarm user means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity that uses or is in control of any alarm system at its alarm site. 
Cancellation is the process by which an alarm company providing monitoring service or an alarm user verifies that a false dispatch has occurred and that there is not an existing situation at the alarm site that requires a police or fire response. 
Catastrophic event means those acts or events, whether natural or manmade, outside the control of an alarm user that causes false alarms at four or more separate alarm sites within a continuous 30-minute period of time. A catastrophic event may include, but not limited to, acts of nature such as storms and high winds or electrical power surges. 
Conversion means the transaction or process by which one alarm company begins the monitoring of a previously unmonitored alarm system or an alarm system previously monitored by another alarm company. 
Duress alarm means a silent alarm system signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a life threatening situation or a serious crime in progress requiring a law enforcement response. 
False alarm means the willful, intentional or unintentional activation of any alarm system causing an alarm dispatch request of police or fire personnel at a time when there is no evidence of criminal activity having been committed or attempted, or no fire or other emergency exists at the alarm site. False alarm also includes an alarm system activation due to an equipment malfunction, improper installation or maintenance of equipment or for any other cause within the alarm users control. False alarms shall not include alarm activations caused by catastrophic events outside the control of alarm users. 
Fire alarm means any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, designed to signal the occurrence of a fire, smoke, water flow, or other condition to which the fire department may be reasonably expected to respond. 
Holdup alarm means a silent alarm signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a robbery in progress. 
Mobile security device (telematic) means a pushbutton panic alarm device mounted in a vehicle or a portable unit using two-way wireless communications and global positioning satellite (GPS) technology to summon an emergency response from police or fire personnel. 
Monitoring means the process by which an alarm company receives signals from an alarm system and relays an alarm dispatch request to the municipality for the purpose of summoning a police or fire response to an alarm site. 
One plus duress alarm means the manual activation of a signal by entering at a keypad a code that adds one to the last digit of the normal arm/disarm code (normal code 1234 one plus duress code 1235). 
Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, organization, or similar entity. 
Takeover means the transaction or process by which an alarm user assumes control of an existing alarm system that was previously controlled by another alarm user. 
Verify means an attempt, by the alarm company, or its representative, to contact the alarm site by any means, whether or not actual contact with an alarm user is made, before initiating an alarm dispatch request, in an attempt to avoid a false alarm. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-131, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-163. - Alarm registration. 
(a)  No alarm user may have or maintain on any premises, except a vehicle, an alarm system unless the person has registered the alarm system with the alarm administrator. A separate alarm registration is required for each alarm site. The alarm administrator is authorized to charge a nominal one-time registration fee as set forth by city council and on file in the city clerk's office. Additional registration fees may only be charged if the alarm user adds additional alarm sites, or there is a change in the alarm user at a given alarm site. The information on the registration will be made available to the emergency dispatch office to enable them to properly administer this article and to assist police and fire personnel in their response to an alarm site. 
(b)  The alarm registration application and appropriate fee must be submitted to the alarm administrator within ten days after the alarm installation or alarm takeover. For alarm systems in service before the passage of this article, the alarm registration fee must be submitted to the alarm administrator within 30 days after the passage of this article. 
(c)  Upon receipt of a completed application form and the alarm registration fee, the alarm administrator shall register the applicant unless the applicant has failed to pay a fine or fee assessed under this article or the alarm registration for the alarm site is suspended or revoked. 
(d)  Each alarm registration application must include the following information: 
(1)  The name, complete mailing address, and telephone numbers of the person who will be the registered holder and responsible person for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and responsible for fees or fines assessed under this article; 
(2)  The alarm site address (including apt/suite #), alarm site telephone numbers, the name of the alarm user; 
(3)  The classification of the alarm site as either residential (includes condominium, townhouse, manufactured home, etc), commercial, or apartment; 
(4)  The purpose of the alarm system at the alarm site classified as burglar, duress, fire, and/or other, and for each purpose whether the alarm is audible and/or silent; 
(5)  Any dangerous or special conditions present at the alarm site that may endanger emergency response personnel such as animals, chemicals, etc.; 
(6)  Name and telephone numbers of at least two individuals who are able to receive notification of an alarm activation at any time and willing to respond to the alarm site and can grant access to the alarm site and deactivate the alarm system if necessary; 
(7)  Type of business conducted at the alarm site if applicable; 
(8)  The date of installation, conversion, or takeover of the alarm system and name, address, and phone number of the alarm company responsible for the alarm system; 
(9)  The name, address, and phone number of the company monitoring the alarm system if different from the alarm company; 
(10)  The signature and date of the person responsible for the alarm system indicating that they have read and understand this ordinance, that they agree to notify the alarm administrator of any change that alters any information provided on the registration application within ten days of the change, and that they understand that police and fire response may be based on factors such as: availability of police and fire units, priority of calls, weather conditions, traffic conditions, emergency conditions, staffing levels, and other factors. 
(e)  Any false statement of a material fact made by an applicant for the purpose of obtaining an alarm registration shall be sufficient cause for refusal to issue a registration. 
(f)  An alarm registration cannot be transferred to another person or alarm site and no alarm registration fee shall be waived or refunded. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-132, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-164. - Alarm user responsibilities. 
(a)  An alarm user shall: 
(1)  Maintain the premises and the alarm system in a manner that will minimize or eliminate false alarms; and 
(2)  Make every reasonable effort to respond or cause a representative to respond to the alarm site within 30 minutes when notified by the municipality to deactivate a malfunctioning alarm system, to provide access to the premises, or to provide alternative security for the premises. If the alarm dispatch request is for a fire alarm, the alarm user or representative must be able to respond to the alarm site within 15 minutes or if unable to do so a commercial business must provide a knox box at the alarm site containing keys to the business; and 
(3)  Not manually activate an alarm for any reason other than an occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report; and 
(4)  Have an alarm system with a fire alarm feature monitored by an alarm company; and 
(5)  Display the registered fire alarm sticker issued by the alarm administrator on the front door or in close proximity of the door at the alarm site. 
(b)  An alarm user shall adjust the mechanism or cause the mechanism to be adjusted so that an alarm signal audible on the exterior of an alarm site will sound for no longer than 15 minutes after being activated. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-133, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-165. - Alarm company responsibilities. 
(a)  Upon enactment of this article alarm companies shall not program alarm systems so that they are capable of sending one plus duress alarms. Alarm companies may continue to report one plus duress alarms received from alarm systems programmed with this feature prior to the enactment of this article. However, upon enactment of this article when a takeover or conversion occurs or if an alarm user requests an alarm system inspection or modification, an alarm company must remove the one plus duress alarm capability from such alarm system. 
(b)  Upon enactment of this article alarm companies shall not install a device activating a holdup alarm which is a single action nonrecessed button. An alarm company must remove all single action nonrecessed buttons when a takeover or conversion occurs. 
(c)  Upon enactment of this article alarm companies shall use control panels tested for conformance to the Security Industry Association (SIA) Control Panel Standard—Features for False Alarm Reduction. 
(d)  Upon enactment of this article alarm companies shall install all alarm systems in compliance with all building and fire codes adopted by the City of Mauldin and NFPA 72. 
(e)  An alarm company performing monitoring services shall: 
(1)  Report alarm signals by using telephone numbers designated by the alarm administrator; and 
(2)  Attempt to verify every alarm signal, except a duress, holdup or fire alarm activation, before initiating an alarm dispatch request; and 
(3)  Communicate to the emergency dispatcher the type of alarm activation (burglar, fire, duress, holdup, mobile security device, telematic) and (silent, audible, automatic, interior or perimeter); and 
(4)  Communicate specific information about the location of the alarm activation (north, south, front, back, floor, ceiling, etc...); and 
(5)  Communicate any additional information to the emergency dispatcher as may be needed to insure an adequate response by emergency personnel; and 
(6)  Endeavor to contact the alarm user when an alarm dispatch request is made; and 
(7)  Ensure that the alarm user has received adequate training on the proper use of the alarm system; and 
(8)  Provide the alarm administrator with a written list containing the names, mailing addresses, alarm site addresses and telephone numbers of all persons for whom monitoring service is provided at the beginning of each calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-134, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-166. - Alarm administrator responsibilities. 
The alarm administrator shall: 
(1)  Designate the manner, form and telephone numbers for the communication of alarm dispatch requests; 
(2)  Establish a procedure to accept cancellation of alarm dispatch requests; 
(3)  Establish a procedure to record such information on alarm dispatch requests necessary to permit the alarm administrator to maintain records, including, but not limited to, the following information. This information may be relayed by the responding police or fire personnel at the time of clearance to emergency dispatchers, who will then record said information on the call record. 
a.  Identification of the alarm site; 
b.  Date and time the alarm dispatch was received; 
c.  Case number; 
d.  Responding officer; 
e.  If emergency contact was made and if a representative of the alarm user responded; 
f.  Disposition (unfounded/founded/catastrophic event); 
(4)  Establish a procedure for notification to the alarm user after the third false alarm at the alarm site in a (fiscal) year. The written notice mailed to the billing address of the responsible person shall include the following: 
a.  The date and time the alarm dispatches occurred; 
b.  If emergency contact was made; 
c.  The case number; 
d.  A statement urging the alarm user to insure that the alarm system is properly operated, inspected, and serviced in order to avoid false alarms and resulting fees; 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-135, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-167. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No alarm user may cause or allow more than three false alarms leading to an alarm dispatch request to occur (during any fiscal year) at any single alarm site. False alarms shall not include alarm activations caused by catastrophic events. 
(b)  No alarm user shall fail to register an alarm system as prescribed in section 26-163. 
(c)  No alarm user shall operate an alarm system at an alarm site that the alarm administrator has suspended alarm response. 
(d)  No Person shall willfully violate any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-136, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-168. - Notification. 
(a)  The responsible person who signed the alarm registration application will be notified in writing after the third false alarm (during any fiscal year), and shall include the information required in section 26-166(4). 
(b)  The responsible person who signed the alarm registration application will be notified in writing, by certified mail, after the sixth false alarm (during any fiscal year) that alarm response has been suspended. This notice of suspension will include the amount of fees due and a description of the appeals procedure available to the alarm user. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-137, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-169. - Fees. 
An administration fee shall be imposed upon the responsible person who signed the alarm registration application or the alarm user for each false alarm in excess of the limits set forth in section 26-167. This fee shall be paid in full within 30 days after the alarm administrator makes billing notification. Fees shall be as determined by the city council periodically and on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-138, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-170. - Penalties. 
Any person willfully violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-139, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-171. - Suspension of response. 
(a)  The alarm administrator may suspend alarm response if it is determined that: 
(1)  The alarm user has six or more false alarms (during any fiscal year); or 
(2)  There is a false statement of a material fact in the application for a registration; or 
(3)  The alarm user failed to register the alarm site; or 
(4)  The alarm user has failed to make a timely payment of a fee assessed under this article. 
(b)  The alarm administrator shall not suspend alarm response to an alarm site when the alarm monitoring company indicates that the alarm dispatch request is for a duress alarm or fire alarm. 
(c)  If the alarm registration is reinstated pursuant to section 26-173, the alarm administrator may suspend alarm response if it is determined that two false alarms have occurred within 60 days after the reinstatement date. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-140, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-172. - Appeals. 
(a)  An alarm user may appeal the assessment of a fee, suspension, or request reinstatement to the alarm administrator. The filing of an appeal with the alarm administrator or city administrator stays the assessment of the administrative fee or suspension until the appeal process is exhausted. 
The alarm user shall file a written appeal to the alarm administrator by setting forth the reasons for the appeal within ten days after notification by the alarm administrator of the fees due. If an appeal is not made within the ten day period, the action of the alarm administrator is final. 
If the alarm administrator denies the waiver of fees, issuance or renewal of an alarm registration, or suspends response, the alarm administrator shall send written notice of the action and a statement of the right to appeal. 
(b)  A second level of appeal is available to the city administrator for cases in which the alarm user is not satisfied with the decision reached by the alarm administrator. 
The alarm user may appeal the decision of the alarm administrator by setting forth the reasons for the appeal within 20 days after receiving the decision of the alarm administrator. If an appeal is not made within the 20-day period, the action of the alarm administrator is final. 
The city administrator must render a decision within ten working days after having reviewed the appeal and shall inform the alarm user in writing of the decision. The city administrator may affirm or reverse the decision of the alarm administrator in whole or part after considering any relevant information in regards to the appeal. The decision of the city administrator is final as to administrative remedy available to the alarm user. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-141, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-173. - Reinstatement. 
An Alarm user whose alarm response has been suspended may have alarm response reinstated by the alarm administrator if the person has met the following conditions: 
(1)  Has submitted an updated application and a reinstatement fee as determined by city council and on file in the city clerk's office; and 
(2)  Has paid, or otherwise resolved, all criminal citations and/or administrative fees; and 
(3)  Has provided the alarm administrator with certification from a properly licensed alarm company that the alarm system has been inspected and repaired if necessary; and 
(4)  Has provided the alarm administrator with a completed customer false alarm prevention checklist furnished by the alarm administrator and answers all statements in the affirmative. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-142, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-174. - Response to mobile security devices. 
If an alarm dispatch request is initiated from a mobil security device where there is no separate indication that a crime is in progress, emergency personnel will not be dispatched to the location of the alarm activation. 
(Ord. No. 549, 14-143, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-175. - Confidentiality. 
All employees or representatives of the municipality shall hold information contained in registration application and applications for appeals in confidence. No information obtained from the registration application may be released to any third party, except by a court order or subpoena from court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-144, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Sec. 26-176. - Government immunity. 
Registration of an alarm system is not intended to, nor will it, create a contract, duty or obligation, either expressed or implied, for response. Any and all liability and consequential damage resulting from the failure to respond to a notification is hereby disclaimed and governmental immunity as provided by law is retained. By registering an alarm system, the alarm user acknowledges that police response may be based on factors such as: Availability of police and/or fire units, priority of calls, weather conditions, traffic conditions, staffing levels and other factors. 
(Ord. No. 549, § 14-145, 10-15-2001; Ord. of 9-17-2007)  
Chapter 28 - PARADES, PICKETING AND DEMONSTRATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate parades and assemblages on highways, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710(3). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 28-1—28-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PARADES, PROCESSIONS AND MEETINGS 
 
Sec. 28-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Meeting means any assembly together or concert of action between or among three or more persons for the purpose of protesting any matter or of making known any position or promotion of such persons, or on behalf of any organization or class of persons, or for the purpose of attracting attention to such assembly. 
Parade and procession mean any assemblage of three or more persons participating in, or three or more vehicles being operated in, any march, ceremony, show, exhibition or procession of any kind in or upon the public streets, sidewalks, alleys, parks or other public grounds or places, not including a bona fide funeral procession. 
(Code 1994, § 15-26) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 28-32. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. No procession or parade shall occupy, march or proceed along any street, sidewalk or any other public place, nor shall any person conduct any public or private meeting on any street, sidewalk or other public place in the city, except in accordance with a permit issued by the chief of police and such other regulations as are set forth in this article which may apply. 
(b)  Application; authority of police chief to designate route. A written application shall be made to the chief of police by any person desiring to have a parade, procession or meeting, setting forth the object, time, place and route of the parade or procession, or the object, time and place of the meeting. The chief of police shall have authority to designate the route of the parade or procession and the portion of the streets or other public places to be used in such a way as to avoid as much as possible the obstruction or impediment of public travel or public business. The chief of police may refuse to issue a permit for a parade, procession or meeting, unless application therefor is filed with him at least ten days before the time thereof. In the absence of the chief of police, the ranking officer of the police department present shall act in his name and stead. 
(Code 1994, §§ 15-27, 15-28)  
Sec. 28-33. - Restricted hours. 
No parade shall be permitted between the hours of 11:30 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. or between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m., local time, and no parade or procession shall commence or continue after sunset or commence before sunrise. 
(Code 1994, § 15-29)  
Sec. 28-34. - Interfering with, addressing abusive language to participants. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to physically interfere with processions, marches or meetings, or with the persons lawfully engaged therein in the use of any street, sidewalk or other public place, or to address profane, indecent, abusive or threatening language or other fighting words to or at such participants, which would tend to provoke such participants or others to a breach of the peace. 
(Code 1994, § 15-30)  
Sec. 28-35. - Conduct. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or participate in any parade, procession or meeting of such character, extent and duration, or of such nature, as to create a public disturbance, to operate as a nuisance or to tend to create or threaten rioting, disorderly conduct or public or private mischief. 
(b)  Abusive or threatening language by participants. It shall be unlawful for any person conducting or participating in any parade, procession or meeting to address abusive or threatening language or other fighting words to or at any person, which would tend to provoke such person or others to a breach of the peace. 
(Code 1994, §§ 15-31, 15-32)  
Secs. 28-36—28-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PICKETING 
 
Sec. 28-71. - Permitted; conditions. 
Peaceful picketing, including demonstrating, in the furtherance of a lawful purpose shall be permitted in the city, provided that the same is done under the following conditions: 
(1)  Picketing shall be conducted only on the sidewalks or other city-owned area normally used or reserved for pedestrian movement, including easements and rights-of-way, and shall not be conducted on the portion of a street used primarily for vehicular traffic. 
(2)  Not more than ten picketers promoting the same objective shall be permitted to use the sidewalks within one block in the city at any one time. 
(3)  Such picketers may carry written or printed placards or signs not exceeding two feet in width and two feet in height promoting the objective for which the picketing is done; provided that the words used are not defamatory in nature and would not tend to produce violence. The staff on which such placard is carried shall not exceed 40 inches in length, must be made of wood, shall not exceed three-fourths of an inch in diameter at any point and must be blunt at each end. 
(4)  Picketers must march in single file and not abreast and may not march closer together than 15 feet, except in passing one another. 
(5)  If picketers promoting different objectives desire to use the same sidewalk for picketing and such use would result in the presence of more than ten picketers thereon, the chief of police shall allot time to each group of picketers for the use of such sidewalk on an equitable basis, but each group shall be permitted to picket subject to the provisions of this section at least once every two hours. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any picketers to address abusive or threatening language to or at any person, which would tend to provoke such person or others to a breach of the peace. 
(Code 1994, § 15-56)  
Sec. 28-72. - Interference with pickets. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to physically interfere with pickets in the use of the sidewalk or to address profane, indecent, abusive or threatening language to or at such picketers, which would tend to provoke such picketers or others to a breach of the peace. 
(Code 1994, § 15-57)  
Sec. 28-73. - Authority of police. 
The police officers of the city may, in the event of the assemblage of persons in such numbers as to tend to intimidate picketers pursuing their lawful objective, through numbers alone or through the use of inflammatory words, direct the dispersal of persons so assembled and may arrest any person who fails to absent himself from the place of such assemblage when so directed by the police. 
(Code 1994, § 15-58) 
Cross reference— Law enforcement, ch. 22.  
Sec. 28-74. - Maintenance of free passage. 
Whenever the free passage of any street or sidewalk in the city shall be obstructed by a crowd, the persons composing such crowd shall disperse or move on when so directed by a police officer as provided in section 28-73. 
(Code 1994, § 15-59)  
Secs. 28-75—28-100. - Reserved.  
Article IV. - Begging 
 
Sec. 28-101. - Definitions. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions apply for purposes of this section: 
Beg means to solicit, request or ask for money or other good and benefits as a charity, whether done by words, bodily gestures, signs or any other means. 
Charitable organizations means those organizations and their members who are defined by S.C. Code § 33-56-170(1) ( charitable organization means any organization, institution, association, society or corporation which is exempt from taxation pursuant to Section 501(c)(3) or 501(d) of Title 26 of the United States.). 
Charitable purposes means those purposes defined by S.C. Code § 33-56-20(2) ( charitable purposes means a purpose described in Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code or a benevolent, social welfare, scientific, educational, environmental, philanthropic, humane, patriotic, public health, civic or other eleemosynary objective, including an objective of an organization of law enforcement personnel, firefighters or other person who protect the public safety if a stated purpose of the solicitations includes a benefit to a person outside the actual service of membership of the organization.). 
Obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic means to walk, stand, sit, lie or place an object in such a manner as to block passage by another person or a vehicle, or to require another persons or a driver of a vehicle to take evasive action to avoid physical contact. Acts authorized as an exercise of one's constitutional right to picket or to legally protest, and acts authorized by a permit issued pursuant to parades as defined in article II, shall not constitute obstruction of pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
Public place means an area generally visible to public view and includes alleys, bridges, buildings, driveways, parking lots, parks, plazas, sidewalks and streets open to the general public, including those that serve food or drink or prodwellings and the grounds enclosing them. 
(b)  Prohibited acts means it shall be unlawful for any person within the city in any public place to: 
(1)  Beg; or 
(2)  Obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic while engaging in begging activities. 
(c)  Exemption for charitable organizations soliciting charitable funds for charitable purposes. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, it shall not be unlawful for a charitable organization to solicit charitable funds for charitable purposes, provided they do so in a reasonable and orderly manner, and without obstructing pedestrian or vehicular traffic in any public place. 
(Ord. No. 677, 6-16-2008)  
Chapter 30 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Dogs permitted in public parks, § 6-57; environment, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36; vegetation, ch. 42. 
State Law reference— Municipal parks, recreational facilities, S.C. Code 1976, § 51-15-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 30-1. - Dogs permitted in public parks. 
Dogs shall be permitted during park hours of operation under specific conditions spelled out in "Dogs in Park Rules." 
Violation and penalty. Any person who brings dogs to parks and recreation facilities and does not follow the stated park rules is in violation of this chapter and subject to its remedies and penalties. 
Any person in violation of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, must be fined between $10.00 and $25.00. (S.C. Code 1976, §§ 44-95-10 et seq. (1996)). 
(Code 1994, § 16-1; Ord. No. 830, 7-30-2017) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 830, adopted July 30, 2017, changed the title of § 30-1 from "Dogs prohibited in public parks" to read as herein set out.  
Sec. 30-2. - Interference with permittees. 
No person in a park shall disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area or participating in any activity under the authority of a permit. 
(Code 1994, § 16-2)  
Sec. 30-3. - Possession, consumption of alcoholic beverages in parks. 
No person in a park shall have brought alcoholic beverages into such park, nor shall any person drink alcoholic beverages at any time in the park. 
(Code 1994, § 16-3)

Sec. 30-4. - Operation of motor vehicles. 
No person in a park shall operate any motor-driven vehicle in the park area, except in the parking lots and drives and then only for the purpose of parking or ingress or egress. 
(Code 1994, § 16-4)

No person in a park shall leave trash, refuse, bottles, cans, paper or other litter about the buildings or grounds. All such litter shall be placed in designated containers. 
(Code 1994, § 16-5)

No person in a park shall violate any rules and regulations pertaining to the park or fail to abide by any posted sign. 
(Code 1994, § 16-6)  
Sec. 30-7. - Hours; closing of public areas. 
(a)  Hours. The opening and closing hours for each individual public mall, park or other public property, or facility or area therein, where adopted, may be posted therein for public information, and no person shall remain therein beyond the times prescribed without permission or permit from the city. 
(b)  Closing of areas to public. Any section or part of any public mall, park or other public property may be declared closed to the public by the city administrator or the city at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular and stated intervals (daily or otherwise), and either entirely or merely to certain uses, as the city administrator or the city or his representative shall find reasonably necessary. 
(Ord. No. 914, 7-15-2019)  
Chapter 32 - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36. 
State Law reference— Sediment control programs, S.C. Code 1976, § 48-13-10 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 32-1. - Findings. 
(a)  The city council finds that accelerated erosion from unprotected construction sites, road maintenance and other land disturbing activities is a major source of sediment. Sediment suspended in streams, lakes and other waters of this county constitutes a major pollution problem and contributes to flooding conditions. As the sediment settles out, it fills stream channels, lakes and reservoirs. 
(b)  Erosion and sedimentation can be effectively controlled, but cannot be completely eliminated, either during active construction or after stabilization, from both a technical and an economic standpoint. 
(c)  Natural erosion during stormwater runoff has always occurred and will continue at low rates from well-stabilized areas. It will cause stream turbidity regardless of the control measures applied. During construction, accelerated erosion will occur during stormwater runoff with a proportionate increase in visible turbidity in stream flow. 
(d)  This chapter is promulgated pursuant to the authority contained in the South Carolina Erosion and Sediment Reduction Act of 1983, S.C. Code 1976, § 48-18-10 et seq. This program is oriented toward prevention of pollution and drainageway obstruction from sediment by requiring preparation and implementation of an erosion and sedimentation control plan adapted to site conditions and meeting specified performance criteria. 
(Code 1994, § 18-1)  
Sec. 32-2. - Purpose of chapter. 
This chapter is designed to ensure a better environment for the city by protecting the lands and waters, to the extent possible, from the effects of soil erosion and sedimentation by controlling them. 
(Code 1994, § 18-2)  
Sec. 32-3. - Scope of chapter. 
The provisions of this chapter impose requirements on any persons, unless specifically excluded, engaged in land disturbing activities within the city. This chapter is designed to ensure planning and implementation of effective temporary and permanent control measures to prevent accelerated erosion and sedimentation. 
(Code 1994, § 18-3)  
Sec. 32-4. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accelerated erosion means any increase over the rate of natural erosion as a result of land disturbing activities. 
Active construction means activities which contribute directly to the completion of facilities contemplated or shown on the construction plans. 
Adequate erosion control measure, structure or device means one which controls the soil material within the land area under responsible control of the person conducting the land disturbing activity. 
Applicant means the owner of record or his designated representative. 
Borrow means fill material which is required for on-site construction and is obtained from other locations. 
Buffer zone means the strip of land adjacent to a lake or natural watercourse, the width of which is measured from the edge of the water to the nearest edge of the disturbed area, with the 25 percent of the strip nearer the land disturbing activity containing natural or artificial means of confining visible siltation. 
Commercial activity means any activity which, under the terms of the city's zoning ordinance, is classified as an allowable use within the O-D, C-1, C-2, C-1N, I-1 and S-1 zoning classifications. 
Conservation district means the soil and water conservation district of the county. 
County engineer means the county engineer or duly appointed official of the county. 
Embankment means a deposit of soil, rock or other material either constructed by man or resulting from excavation. 
Enforcement authority means the city council or its designated representative. 
Erosion means the process by which the ground surface is worn away by the action of water. 
Excavation means any act by which soil or rock is cut into, dug, quarried, uncovered, removed, displaced or relocated and shall include the conditions resulting therefrom. 
Fill means a deposit of soil, rock or other material placed by man. 
Grading means any displacement of soil by stripping, excavating, filling, stockpiling or any combination thereof and shall include the land in its excavated or filled condition. 
Ground cover means any natural vegetative growth or other material which renders the soil surface stable against accelerated erosion. 
Industrial activity means any activity which, under the terms of the city zoning ordinance, would be an allowable use in the S-1, excluding commercial uses, and I-1 classifications. 
Issuing authority means the municipal or county permit department having jurisdiction over the site for which a site grading permit is being requested. 
Lake and natural watercourse mean any stream, river, brook, swamp, sound, bay, creek, run, branch, canal, waterway, estuary, natural drainageway and any reservoir, lake or pond, natural or impounded, in which sediment may be moved or carried in suspension, and which could be damaged by accumulation of sediment. 
Land disturbing activity means any use of the land by any person in residential, industrial, educational, institutional or commercial development, highway and road construction and maintenance that results in a substantial change in the natural cover or topography and that may cause or contribute to sedimentation. 
Multifamily dwelling means a building used exclusively as a place of residence containing two or more dwelling units. 
Natural erosion means the wearing away of the earth's surface by water, wind or other natural agents under natural environmental conditions undisturbed by man. 
Person engaged in or conducting land disturbing activity means the individual, partnership, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private institution, utility, cooperative, interstate body or other legal entity who initiates and is financially responsible for the project which necessitates the land disturbing activity. 
Plan means the erosion and sediment control plan required by this chapter to be a part of the application for a grading permit. 
Planning commission means the city planning commission. 
Residential subdivision means the division of a tract or parcel of contiguous land into two or more lots, sites or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale or building development, and includes the dedication of new street rights-of-way or a change in an existing street, resubdivision and, when appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided. The following shall not be included: 
(1)  The division of land into parcels greater than five acres where no street right-of-way dedication is involved. 
(2)  The public acquisition by purchase of strips of land for the widening or opening of streets. 
Sediment means soil or other surface materials transported by wind or surface water as a product of erosion. 
Siltation means sediment resulting from accelerated erosion which is settleable or removable by properly designed, constructed and maintained control measures; and which has been transported from its point of origin within the site of a land disturbing activity; and which has been deposited, or is in suspension in water. 
Single-family dwelling means a detached building used exclusively as a place or residence for one family. 
Standard design storm (SDS) means a ten-year storm, a rainfall of 2.4 inches in 60 minutes. 
Stormwater runoff means the direct runoff of water resulting from precipitation in any form. 
Tract means all contiguous land and bodies of water in one ownership, or contiguous land and bodies of water in diverse ownership being developed as a unit, although not necessarily all at one time. 
Uncovered means the removal of ground cover from, on, or above the soil surface. 
Undertaken means the initiating of any activity, or phase of activity, which results or will result in a change in the ground cover or topography of a tract of land. 
Utility means a company, regulated by the public service commission, municipality or special purpose district, providing a utility service, including construction, maintenance and repair of lines, pipelines or support activities. 
Waste means surplus materials resulting from on-site construction and disposed of at other locations. 
Working days means days exclusive of Saturday and Sunday during which weather conditions permit land disturbing activity to be undertaken. 
(Code 1994, § 18-4) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 32-5. - Inspection and enforcement. 
(a)  The issuing authority shall periodically inspect the sites of land disturbing activities for which permits have been issued to determine if the activities are being conducted in accordance with the plan approved by the soil and water conservation district and if the measures required in the plan are effective in controlling erosion and sedimentation. 
(b)  If, through inspection, it is determined that a person engaged in land disturbing activities has failed to comply with the approved plan, a written notice to comply shall be served upon that person. The notice shall set forth the measures necessary to achieve compliance with the plan and shall state the time within which such measures must be completed. If the person engaged in the land disturbing activity fails to comply within the time specified, he shall be deemed in violation of this chapter and subject to the provisions of this section. 
(c)  The issuing authority shall have the power to conduct such investigations as it may reasonably deem necessary to carry out its duties as prescribed in this chapter, and for this purpose to enter at reasonable times upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of investigating and inspecting the sites of land disturbing activities. 
(d)  No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent who requests entry for purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials, nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while in the process of carrying out his official duties. 
(Code 1994, § 18-5)  
Sec. 32-6. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who engages in any grading operation subject to the provision of this chapter without first obtaining a grading permit or who willfully violates the provisions of a grading plan submitted to obtain a grading permit shall be subject to the following actions: 
(1)  Upon determination that a violation of this chapter has occurred, the person engaged in the land disturbing activity will be given 48 hours to apply for a site grading permit and submit the required plans. If a plan is not submitted, an immediate stop work order may be issued by the issuing authority. 
(2)  If a plan has been submitted and approved, but violations of the plan are occurring, an immediate stop work order may be issued by the issuing authority. 
(3)  If violations remain uncorrected and/or stop work orders are not obeyed, the violator shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punishable in accordance with section 1-6. Notice of violation shall be sufficient if directed to the owner, the agent of the owner, or the contractor and left at his known place of residence or place of business. 
(b)  The soil and water conservation district or the city council may obtain injunctive relief to enjoin violations of any grading plan submitted for the purpose of obtaining a grading permit; and any person damaged as a result of such violations may, upon a proper showing of such damages, obtain payment therefor by a civil action. 
(Code 1994, § 18-6)  
Secs. 32-7—32-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PLAN AND PERMIT 
 
Sec. 32-41. - Required. 
A site grading permit shall be required prior to any land disturbing activity unless otherwise excluded in section 32-42. No permit shall be issued until the applicant has submitted a plan to control erosion and sedimentation and such plan has been approved by the soil and water conservation district. 
(Code 1994, § 18-31)  
Sec. 32-42. - Exclusions. 
The requirement to submit a type 1, 2, or 3 sediment and erosion control plan as provided for in this chapter shall not apply to: 
(1)  Commercial mining operations. 
(2)  Agricultural land management and agricultural practices. 
(3)  The construction of on-farm buildings and structures used in a farming operation. 
(4)  The construction of single-family residences, or their accessory buildings which are not a part of a residential subdivision. 
(5)  Construction of a dwelling unit within a subdivision which is being developed in accordance with an approved sedimentation plan. 
(6)  All minor land disturbing activities such as home gardens and individual home landscaping, repairs, maintenance work and other related activities which result in minor soil erosion. 
(7)  Any project involving the movement of not more than 500 cubic yards of land, which is promptly stabilized to prevent erosion and sedimentation, provided this land change does not occur within 200 feet of the banks of any major stream or river. 
(8)  Emergency repairs or maintenance of existing structures and facilities which require ground to be broken. 
(9)  Construction activities of the state department of highways and public transportation conforming to the requirements of section 108.03 of the latest edition of the state standard specifications for highway construction. 
(Code 1994, § 18-32)  
Sec. 32-43. - Application. 
All applications for permits under this article shall be submitted to the city through the business and development services department for processing and permit issuance. Applications for permits shall be accompanied by three copies of the applicant's soil erosion and sediment control plan. Plans shall include, as a minimum, the data specified in section 32-53. Soil erosion and sediment control plans shall also conform to the provisions of sections 32-52 and 32-53. 
(Code 1994, § 18-33; Memo. of 3-5-2012)  
Sec. 32-44. - Fees. 
The erosion and sedimentation plan shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee according to the established fee schedule which is on file in the office of the municipal clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 18-34)  
Sec. 32-45. - Review by soil and water conservation district. 
Immediately upon receipt of an application for permit under this article, the issuing authority shall refer the application and plan to the soil and water conservation district for its review and recommendations. The results of their review shall be forwarded to the appropriate issuing authority which shall issue the final approval or denial on all applications. 
(Code 1994, § 18-35)  
Sec. 32-46. - Approval. 
If the application conforms to the requirements of this chapter, the soil and water conservation district shall recommend approval to the issuing authority within ten working days and forward the approved application to the issuing authority. 
(Code 1994, § 18-36)  
Sec. 32-47. - Denial. 
If the application does not conform to this chapter, the soil and water conservation district shall recommend disapproval to the issuing authority. The recommendation for disapproval shall be accompanied by written reasons for disapproval and suggested corrective actions and shall be forwarded to the issuing authority within ten working days. 
(Code 1994, § 18-37)  
Sec. 32-48. - Resubmittal of application. 
If an application is disapproved by the soil and water conservation district, the applicant may correct the deficiencies in conformance with this chapter and resubmit the application for reconsideration. If the revised application is approved, then the issuing authority shall issue the site grading permit. 
(Code 1994, § 18-38)  
Sec. 32-49. - Issuance of permit. 
Site grading work may not proceed until such time as approval of the applicable type 1, 2, or 3 is granted. However, in the case of a type 2 sedimentation and erosion control plan as described in section 32-53, site grading work may begin prior to the final approval of the sedimentation and erosion plan and issuance of a site grading permit. In order to proceed prior to the issuance of the permit, the applicant must meet the following conditions: 
(1)  An application must be filed with the issuing authority accompanied by a sketch plan and narrative. 
(2)  The applicant shall proceed under the terms of the sedimentation and erosion control sketch plan and narrative as submitted until otherwise notified. 
(3)  The applicant shall begin the installation of sedimentation and erosion control measures within 48 hours of the commencement of land disturbing activity. 
(4)  The applicant must take the steps necessary to receive final approval of the sketch and narrative plan within 30 days of the application or be subject to the penalties outlined in section 32-6. 
(Code 1994, § 18-39)  
Sec. 32-50. - Board of zoning appeals. 
All requests for variances and exceptions under this chapter shall be heard by a zoning board of adjustment and appeals.
