(Code 1994, § 18-40) 
Cross reference— Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-201 et seq.  
Sec. 32-51. - Variances and exceptions. 
The board of zoning appeals may authorize upon written appeal in specific cases such variances or exceptions from the terms of this chapter as will not be contrary to the public interest, where owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this chapter would result in unnecessary hardship or peculiar and exceptional practical difficulties. Before action is taken on a request for a variance, the board shall hold one or more public meetings, at which any party may appear in person or by agent or attorney. A variance from the terms of this chapter may be granted by the board upon a finding that: 
(1)  There are special conditions and circumstances which are peculiar to the land, structure or building involved which are not applicable to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same area. 
(2)  A literal interpretation of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by similar properties under the terms of this chapter. 
(3)  Granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is denied by this chapter to similar other lands structures, or buildings. 
(4)  The variance requested will be in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this chapter, and will not be injurious to the neighborhood, or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare. 
(5)  The variance requested is the minimum variance that will make possible the legal use of the land, building or structure. 
(Code 1994, § 18-41)  
Sec. 32-52. - Types of sedimentation and erosion control plans. 
For the purposes of this chapter, erosion and sedimentation plans shall be divided into three types: type 1, type 2 and type 3. The designs, presentations and submittal shall be the responsibility of the person engaged in or conducting the land disturbing activity. 
(1)  Type 1 sedimentation and erosion control plan. A type 1 sedimentation and erosion control plan must be prepared and certified by a registered, professional engineer or registered landscape architect. The registration seal must be affixed to the plan. The specific requirements of a type 1 plan are detailed in section 32-53(a)—(c). 
(2)  Type 2 sedimentation and erosion control plan. A type 2 sedimentation and erosion control plan is comprised only of a narrative description accompanied by a sketch plan. This plan does not require preparation or certification by a registered engineer or registered landscape architect. The specific requirements of a type 2 plan are enumerated in section 32-53(d)—(f). 
(3)  Type 3 sedimentation and erosion control plan. A type 3 sedimentation and erosion control plan, at a minimum, may be comprised of a narrative description accompanied by a sketch plan. This type of plan may only be used by public utilities in the installation of utility services. This plan does not require preparation or certification by a registered engineer or registered landscape architect. The specific requirements of a type 3 plan are enumerated in section 32-53(g), (i). 
(Code 1994, § 18-42)  
Sec. 32-53. - Data required. 
(a)  Type 1 sedimentation and erosion control plans shall be submitted for the following projects: 
(1)  All shopping centers or group commercial developments two acres or larger, all multifamily developments two acres or larger. 
(2)  All planned developments. 
(3)  All industrial developments two acres or larger. 
A type 1 plan shall also be included with the stormwater management plan (i.e., drainage plan) where required for the development of a residential subdivision. Type 1 plans shall also be submitted in any case where site development requires the construction of sedimentation and erosion control devices, i.e., sediment basin, retaining walls, etc. 
(b)  When, under the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, a detailed engineering plan for sedimentation and erosion control is required, three copies of the plan shall accompany the application. The plan may be included as a part of the stormwater management plan. However, the plan shall include, as a minimum, the following data to the extent required by the city: 
(1)  A vicinity map sufficient to locate the site and to show the relationship of the site to its general surroundings at a scale of not less than one inch equals one mile. 
(2)  A site drawn to a workable scale. 
a.  The boundary lines of the site on which the work is to be performed, including the approximate acreage of the site. 
b.  Existing contours with intervals of not more than ten feet. 
c.  Proposed improvements on the site including present development and future utilization, if known. 
d.  All drainage provisions, erosion and sediment control measures, vegetative practices, or other protective devices to be constructed in connection with, or as a part of, the proposed work. 
e.  Provisions for temporary erosion control during construction and permanent control during the life of the facility. Such provisions shall include an estimated time schedule and sequence of operations indicating the anticipated starting and completion dates of the particular development sequence. 
f.  The name and address of the property owner and developer. 
g.  Title, scale, north arrow, date and name of individual or organization preparing plans. 
(c)  When a type 1 engineering plan for sedimentation and erosion control is required, the plan and specifications shall be supported by such supplemental reports, data and additional information as the conservation district and the city may reasonably require including but not limited to any of the following: 
(1)  Finished contours at the same interval as required or used for existing topography, proposed building and pavement grades, and the elevations, dimensions, locations, extent and slope of all proposed grading. 
(2)  Storm drainage computations and studies including the estimated runoff from the area served by drains, adequacy of outlets, ditch and pipe sizing computations, and map showing the drainage area. 
(3)  Field investigation reports indicating the nature, condition, and characteristics of existing drainage and flooding conditions. 
(4)  Results from actual soils investigations, reports, or test borings, if available. 
The data of subsections (c)(1)—(4) of this section is to be provided on an "as needed" basis and will not be required in total for each application for a grading permit. 
(d)  A type 2 plan shall be submitted for land disturbing activities within the city not falling under a type 1 or type 3 classification. Certain land disturbing activities are specifically excluded from the requirements of this chapter. These exclusions are contained in section 32-42. When, under the provisions of a type 2 plan above, a narrative description (an optional checklist available from the issuing authority may be used in lieu of a narrative) and sketch plan of the overall project are required, this narrative shall include: 
(1)  An anticipated starting and completion date of the various stages of land disturbing activities and the expected date the final stabilization will be completed. 
(2)  A description of the sediment control program and sediment control practices. 
(3)  A general description of topographic and soils conditions of the tract as available from the county planning commission or the local soil and water conservation district. 
(4)  A general description of adjacent property and a description of existing structures, buildings, and other fixed improvements located on surrounding properties. 
(5)  A description of the maintenance program for sediment control facilities including inspection programs, vegetative establishment of exposed soils, method and frequency of removal and disposal of solid waste material removed from control facilities and disposition of temporary structural measures. 
(e)  A sketch plan (no professional seal required) to accompany the narrative shall contain: 
(1)  A site location drawing of the proposed project, indicating the location of the proposed project in relation to roadways, jurisdictional boundaries, streams and rivers. 
(2)  The boundary lines of the site on which the work is to be performed. 
(3)  A topographic map of the site, available from the county planning commission. 
(4)  The location of temporary and permanent vegetative and structural erosion and sediment control measures. 
The requirements contained in subsections (e)(1)—(4) of this section may be indicated on one map as illustrated in the example of a typical sketch plan in subsection (f) of this section. 
(f)  A sample sketch plan map shall be provided. 
(g)  A type 3 plan shall be submitted for all utility installations within the city not excluded by the provisions of section 32-42 and/or this subsection. The use of a type 3 plan shall be limited to the installation of utility services. The construction by a utility provider of permanent facilities involving sites one acre or larger shall be included under the provisions of a type 1 or type 2 plan as described in section 32-52. 
(h)  Under the provisions of a type 3 plan (section 32-52(3)), the following shall be included: 
(1)  A site location drawing of the proposed project, indicating the location of the proposed project in relation to roadways, jurisdictional boundaries, streams and rivers. 
(2)  The location of temporary and permanent vegetative and structural erosion and sediment control measures. 
(3)  An anticipated starting and completion date of the various stages of land disturbing activities and the expected date the final stabilization will be completed. 
(4)  A description of the sediment control program and sediment control practices. 
(5)  A general description of topographic and soils conditions of the tract as available from the county planning commission or the local soil and water conservation district. 
(i)  Certain activities undertaken by utility providers are not substantial land disturbing activities and are therefore not intended to be regulated by this chapter. Those activities, in addition to those exclusions listed in section 32-42, which are not subject to this chapter include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Installation of utilities on a site of one acre or less. 
(2)  Installation of utilities in a ditch section one foot or less in width. 
(3)  Installation of utility poles. 
(4)  Maintenance of easements and rights-of-way. 
(5)  Service connections, i.e., tapping main lines and/or setting meters, including installation of a manhole, bell hole, underground vault, valve box or fire hydrant. 
(6)  Projects for which an encroachment permit has been issued by the state department of highways and public transportation, or county or a municipality. 
(7)  Emergency repairs. 
(8)  Any other activity determined not to be a substantial land disturbing activity by the soil and water conservation service. 
(Code 1994, § 18-43)  
Sec. 32-54. - Standard sedimentation and erosion control measures. 
(a)  Implementation. Excessive soil erosion and resulting sediment pollution can take place during land disturbing activities. Therefore, plans for those land disturbing activities which are not excluded by this chapter shall contain provisions for application of soil erosion and sediment control measures. These provisions shall be incorporated into the sketch plan. Soil erosion and sediment control measures shall conform to the standards and specifications of this chapter. The application of measures shall apply to all features of the site, including street and utility installations, drainage facilities and other temporary and permanent improvements. Measures shall be installed to prevent or control erosion and sediment pollution during all stages of any land disturbing activity. 
(b)  General design principles. Practical combinations of the following principles and/or best management practices shall be utilized as a minimum in determining the sediment and erosion control devices to be installed for any land disturbing activity: 
(1)  The land disturbing activity shall conform to existing topography and soil type so as to create the lowest practical erosion potential. 
(2)  Land disturbing activities shall be conducted in a manner minimizing erosion. 
(3)  The disturbed area and the duration of exposure to erosive elements shall be kept to a practicable minimum. 
(4)  Cut-fill operations must be kept to a minimum. 
(5)  Disturbed soil shall be stabilized as quickly as practicable. 
(6)  Whenever feasible, natural vegetation shall be retained, protected and supplemented. 
(7)  Temporary vegetation or mulching shall be employed to protect exposed critical areas during development. 
(8)  Permanent vegetation and structural erosion control measures shall be installed as soon as practicable. 
(9)  Adequate provisions must be provided to minimize damage from surface water to the cut face of excavations or the sloping surface of fills. 
(10)  To the extent necessary, sediment in runoff water must be trapped by the use of debris basins, sediment basins, silt traps, or similar measures until the disturbed area is stabilized. 
(11)  Cuts and fills may not endanger adjoining property. 
(12)  Fills may not encroach upon natural watercourses or constructed channels in a manner so as to adversely affect other property owners. 
(13)  Grading equipment must cross flowing streams by means of bridges or culverts except when such methods are not feasible and provided, in any case, that such crossings are kept to a minimum. 
(c)  Maintenance. 
(1)  Maintenance of all soil erosion and sedimentation control practices, whether temporary or permanent, shall be at all times the responsibility of the person responsible for the land disturbing activity. 
(2)  Sediment basins shall be considered hazardous to life or property and shall be fenced and posted in accordance with the standards and specifications incorporated by reference in this chapter and detailed in the drainage design certification. Large scale office or industrial complex developments of ten acres or more, which incorporate natural or manmade lakes, streams or ponds, shall be exempt from fencing upon review and approval by the city. 
(Code 1994, §§ 18-44—18-46)  
Chapter 34 - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Dead animals, § 6-6; animal waste, § 6-11; buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; environment, ch. 18; littering in parks, § 30-5; interfering with manholes covers; dumping trash, other waste into manholes, § 40-4. 
State Law reference— Collection of garbage, S.C. Code 1976, §§ 44-55-1010—44-55-1060. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 34-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Cart means a plastic, 90-gallon refuse receptacle having a tightfitting lid, carrying an embossed serial number, and the design, construction, and capacity shall be designated by the city. Its use shall be primarily for single-family residential refuse collection. 
Container means a container constructed of metal, of a capacity of not less than two nor more than eight cubic yards, of sound construction, having a sufficient number of doors for loading and unloading, equipped with drains sufficient to keep the container free of accumulated liquids at all times, and equipped with a suitable top designed to return to a closed position after dumping. 
Garbage means organic waste matter, both animal and vegetable, being comprised chiefly of waste food. 
Refuse means waste material other than garbage. 
Rubbish means tree limbs, cuttings, shrubbery, weeds, leaves, etc. 
(Code 1994, § 19-1; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-1), 6-16-2003) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 34-2. - Violations. 
Every person failing to comply with this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. In addition, the city shall have the authority to refuse collection services for failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 19-2; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-2), 6-16-2003)  
Sec. 34-3. - City to operate service; frequency of collections; amount of garbage collected. 
The city will operate a garbage disposal pickup service for the residents and small business establishments located within the city, and such service shall be once a week. No single pickup shall exceed two 90-gallon city-approved receptacles or carts. Nonsingle-family uses requiring more than two 90-gallon carts will be required to use containers. 
(Code 1994, § 19-3; Ord. No. 500, § 1(19-3), 6-21-1999; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-3), 6-16-2003)  
Sec. 34-4. - Drainage of liquid. 
All garbage and refuse shall be drained of liquid before being deposited for collection. 
(Code 1994, § 19-4; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-4), 6-16-2003)  
Sec. 34-5. - Receptacles. 
(a)  Generally. All single-family residences and small business in the city, including townhouses, condominiums, duplexes, and all apartment complexes with less than nine units, shall purchase and use city-approved receptacles or carts for the disposal of normal household garbage, refuse and recyclable materials. The city has available for purchase garbage and recycle receptacles and carts. Receptacles must be brought to the curb or ditch line before 7:30 a.m. on the scheduled collection day and removed from the curb or ditch line before 12:00 midnight of the scheduled collection day. 
(b)  Certain deposits prohibited. 
(1)  No dirt, rocks, yard waste or construction materials as described in section 34-7 shall be put in city approved receptacles. 
(2)  No oil, batteries, or hazardous waste of any type shall be put in city-approved receptacles or along the curbside. 
(c)  Responsibility of resident. The resident or small business shall be responsible for the replacement of any stolen, damaged, or abused receptacle. The city will not be responsible for any stolen, damaged, or abused receptacles or carts. 
(d)  Accessibility. All garbage and refuse receptacles must be brought to the public street curb or ditch line adjacent to a driveway on the designated day. Receptacles not so located when the city truck services the street shall not be emptied. 
(e)  Back door service. Residences where no one is physically able to roll the city-provided receptacles to the street for collection will be extended back door service. Applications for back door service will be subject to approval of the city verifying such request. 
(Code 1994, §§ 19-5—19-10; Ord. No. 487, 10-26-1998; Ord. No. 500, § 1(19-5, 19-7), 6-21-1999; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-5—19-10), 6-16-2003; Ord. No. 760, 12-16-2013)  
Sec. 34-6. - Use of commercial containers restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dump refuse or trash in a refuse commercial container located in the city if such person is not a resident of the city or if the trash or refuse is not from within the city limits. It shall likewise be unlawful to dump refuse, trash or any other matter in such containers when the containers are full or to throw refuse from such containers. 
(Code 1994, § 19-11; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-11), 6-16-2003)  
Sec. 34-7. - Removal of construction debris. 
(a)  Disposal of construction materials. Every contractor, carpenter, or builder or the property owner, after completing or during the construction or alteration of a building or property must remove all trash incident to such construction or alteration at his own expense. 
(b)  Construction materials defined. The term "construction materials" means, but is not limited to, carpet, padding, sheetrock, lumber, shingles, siding, shutters, or other lumber materials, bricks, blocks, cement and mortar, concrete, rocks, and dirt. 
(Code 1994, § 19-12; Ord. No. 487, 10-26-1998; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-12), 6-16-2003) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8.  
Sec. 34-8. - Disposal in public places. 
No person shall place or throw garbage or refuse in any public street, public alley, or other public place in the city. 
(Code 1994, § 19-12; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-13), 6-16-2003) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36.  
Sec. 34-9. - Collection of tree limbs, cuttings, shrubbery and leaves. 
(a)  Tree limbs, cuttings, shrubbery, etc., will be collected by the city as soon as practical; provided, however, that such limbs, cuttings, shrubbery, etc., are no longer than six feet and no more than six inches in diameter and placed on the front of the owner's or tenant's property nearest the street or public alley on the city street right-of-way adjacent to the property line. The amount collected shall be not more than four cubic yards per pickup. The city reserves the right to charge an additional fee for excessive amounts. An excessive amount is defined as more than four cubic yards of yard waste per pickup. Should the city decide to implement this fee, it shall be based on, but not limited to, twice the actual costs of the current landfill rate for disposal of such yard wastes. 
(b)  Trees pruned by a contractor or taken down by the contractor shall be disposed by the contractor. 
(c)  Grass clippings and leaves will be separated from yard rubbish and other refuse. It shall be free of rocks and other extraneous material. Grass clippings will not be picked up unless they are placed in a disposable plastic bag. The plastic bag shall be tied, closed and placed on the city street right-of-way adjacent to the property. 
(d)  No leaves, grass clippings, tree limbs, or debris shall be placed within six feet of any storm drainage appurtenance or catch basin. 
(e)  The city administrator may relax or omit any provision(s) of this code section with the exception of size and placement location, in order to provide the highest level of collection possible in response to a storm or similar event to section 34-9 of our city Code. 
(Code 1994, § 19-14; Ord. No. 487, 10-26-1998; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-14), 6-16-2003; Ord. No. 618, 1-23-2006; Ord. No. 680, 6-16-2008; Ord. No. 759, 12-16-2013; Ord. of 3-19-2018, § 1) 
Cross reference— Vegetation, ch. 42.  
Secs. 34-10—34-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COMMERCIAL, BUSINESS AND MULTIFAMILY WASTE DISPOSAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 10. 
 
Sec. 34-41. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Cart means a plastic, 90-gallon refuse receptacle having a tightfitting lid, carrying an embossed serial number, and the design, construction, and capacity shall be designated by the city. Its use shall be primarily for single-family residential refuse collection. 
Container means a container constructed of metal, of a capacity of not less than two nor more than eight cubic yards, of sound construction, having a sufficient number of doors for loading and unloading, equipped with drains sufficient to keep the container free of accumulated liquids at all times, and equipped with a suitable top designed to return to a closed position after dumping. 
Industrial establishment means any person engaged in manufacturing or processing any item or goods. 
Institution means schools, hospitals, and charitable, philanthropic, and religious institutions conducted for the benefit of the public or a recognized section of the public. 
Retail and commercial establishment means any office, retail store, restaurant, hotel, motel, garage, trailer park or private club. 
Multifamily means an apartment complex consisting of nine or more dwelling units. 
(Code 1994, § 19-41; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-41), 6-16-2003) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 34-42. - Special rules and regulations. 
The city shall make specific collections of refuse and other wastes from business and institutional units as follows: 
(1)  Retail, commercial, and institutional units using carts. 
a.  General rubbish. General rubbish shall be collected from all retail, commercial, and institutional units using carts on a regular basis in accordance with a schedule set by the public works director. 
b.  General bulk waste. General bulk waste shall be collected in accordance with a schedule set by the public works director. 
c.  Other waste. No other types of waste shall be collected. 
(2)  Retail, commercial, institutional, industrial, and multifamily units using container service. The city will not provide any solid waste service to businesses using containers. Multifamily apartments as defined in section 34-41 shall be required to use containers. 
The city council may, from time to time, make special rules and regulations for the method and manner of garbage storage and collection in order to facilitate the efficient collection thereof. 
(Code 1994, § 19-42; Ord. No. 581, § 1(19-42), 6-16-2003)  
Sec. 34-43. - Unlawful disposal. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, place, throw or sweep any garbage or rubbish, paper, trash or waste matter of any kind resulting from the operation of any business, industrial or commercial establishment in any alley, street, sidewalk, storm drain or other public place, or to place or store any such matter on any private property, vacant lot or open place within the city, unless the same shall be enclosed in suitable containers as specified in this article. 
(Code 1994, § 19-43)  
Sec. 34-44. - Commercial containers. 
The owner of any business, commercial, industrial establishment or multifamily complex shall provide such commercial containers as necessary for the storage of garbage and waste matter, and such containers shall at all times be kept in a place easily accessible to city equipment. The owner shall be responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of such containers and shall not permit them to fall into an unsafe or nonrodentproof condition. The owner shall not permit hazardous waste to be placed in such containers or they shall be responsible for its disposal. No service shall be given to those establishments permitting objects, obstructions or vehicles to hinder in any way whatsoever the servicing of such containers. 
(Code 1994, § 19-44)  
Sec. 34-45. - Authority to limit amount collected. 
The city council shall have the right and authority to limit the amount of garbage and waste matter it will collect and remove from any business, industrial or commercial establishment. 
(Code 1994, § 19-45)  
Sec. 34-46. - Frequency of collections. 
(a)  The city shall collect and remove authorized garbage and waste matter from any business, commercial, industrial establishment or multifamily complex at such times and intervals as are deemed appropriate by the city. 
(b)  Industrial establishments, multifamily complexes and mobile home parks shall not be affected by these container and collection limitations, but the city council reserves the right to pass resolutions regulating the volume and frequency of industrial waste collection. 
(Code 1994, § 19-46)  
Sec. 34-47. - Fees and charges. 
(a)  Retail, commercial, institutional, industrial, eleemosynary, and multiple residential housing units having dumpster containers collected by rear-loading vehicles shall be charged a fee per cubic yard collected, billed quarterly, and as set from time to time. Such fees are on file in the office of the municipal clerk. 
(b)  Fees shall be due and payable within 30 days from date of mailing, or as specified on the bill. After this 30-day period, a late fee, which is on file in the office of the municipal clerk, shall be added in addition to any costs of collection. Partial payments shall not be accepted. If a bill is not paid within 30 days, the city may discontinue service to that user and initiate any civil action necessary to collect the amount due, and code inspectors shall be notified to inspect the property for violations of law. Retail, commercial, institutional, industrial, and eleemosynary units may contract with private waste companies according to their needs. 
(c)  The public works director shall determine the required size, capacity requirements, location, and frequency of pickups of containers necessary for proper service, but not less than once per week. 
(Code 1994, § 19-47)  
Secs. 34-48—34-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LITTER[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Dumping litter prohibited, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-11-700. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 34-81. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bulk means all bulk waste, including used or damaged appliances, furniture, mattresses, tires, etc. 
Container means a watertight receptacle made of metal, heavy-duty plastic or material of similar strength, with a tightfitting cover for the storage and disposal of solid waste. 
Garbage means all perishable refuse, except for those items being recycled by the city sanitation department, including animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food; household rubbish, including paper, cardboard, boxes, rags, plastic, cloth, glass, bottles, cans and any similar waste; and small dead animals. 
Litter means any quantity of solid waste which is not properly disposed of. 
Private property means, but is not limited to, the following exterior locations owned by any private person: yards, grounds, walks, driveways, entrances, passageways, parking areas, working areas, storage areas, vacant lots and recreational facilities. 
Public property means, but is not limited to, the following exterior locations: streets, roads, public rights-of-way, medians, sidewalks, alleys and other public ways; and any and all public parks, grounds, lots, recreation facilities, waterways and drainage systems. 
Recyclables means any garbage that may be recycled by the city sanitation department. 
Rubbish means yard rubbish, including ashes, weeds, brush, leaves, grass, vines, wood, shrubbery, trees, branches, stumps and similar materials; bricks, stones and metal. 
Solid waste means bulk, garbage, refuse, rubbish, debris and other solid waste. 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 34-82. - Penalties. 
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. The court, in lieu of a monetary fine, may direct the substitution of litter-gathering labor under the supervision of the court, not to exceed one-hour for each $5.00 of fine imposed. In addition to any other punishment authorized by this article, in the sound discretion of the judge, such person may be directed by the judge to pick up and remove from any public place or any private property, with prior permission of the legal owner, upon which it is established by competent evidence that such person has deposited litter, any or all litter deposited thereon by any person prior to the date of execution of sentence. 
(Code 1994, § 19-67)  
Sec. 34-83. - Prohibited on public and private property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, throw, drop, discard, deposit or otherwise dispose of litter or other solid waste on any public or private property within the city except in containers or areas lawfully provided therefor. 
(Code 1994, § 19-68)  
Sec. 34-84. - Keeping property clean. 
The owner or occupant of private property is responsible to keep his property free from litter. Failure to do so shall be a violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 19-69)  
Sec. 34-85. - Truck loads or tires causing litter. 
No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or public property or private property of others. No person shall drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or private property, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Code 1994, § 19-70) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 38.  
Sec. 34-86. - Construction sites. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or contractor at a construction site to: 
(1)  Permit garbage, rubbish, paper or other solid waste to be blown or washed away from the construction site onto public property or other private property. 
(2)  Fail to secure all construction material in such a manner as to prevent same from blowing or washing from the construction site to public property or private property of others. 
(Code 1994, § 19-71) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8.  
Secs. 34-87—34-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - HANDBILLS 
 
Sec. 34-111. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial handbill means any printed or written matter, sample, device, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or otherwise reproduced matter of literature: 
(1)  Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity, or thing; 
(2)  Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; 
(3)  Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; but the terms of this clause shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, when either of the same is held, given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety and good order; provided that nothing contained in this clause shall be deemed to authorize the holding, giving or taking place of any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, without a license, where such license is or may be required by any law of this state or under any ordinance of this city; or 
(4)  Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
Newspaper means any periodical of general circulation, regularly published and sold to the public, with not less than 12 issues per year. 
Noncommercial handbill means any printed or written matter, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other printed or reproduced matter of literature not included in the definitions of a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
(Code 1994, § 19-81) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 34-112. - Certain existing ordinances not affected. 
This division shall not be deemed to repeal, amend or modify any ordinance ever ordained, either prohibiting, regulating or licensing canvassers, hawkers, peddlers, transient merchants, or any person, using the public streets or places for any private business or enterprise, or for commercial sales, not covered in this division. 
(Code 1994, § 19-82)  
Sec. 34-113. - Penalties. 
Any person violating or causing another person to violate the provisions of this division shall be fined in accordance with section 1-6. The court, in lieu of a monetary fine, may direct the substitution of litter-gathering labor under the supervision of the court, not to exceed one hour for each $5.00 of fine imposed. In addition to any other punishment authorized by this division, in the sound discretion of the judge, such person may be directed by the judge to pick up and remove from any public place or any private property, with prior permission of the legal owner, upon which it is established by competent evidence that such person has deposited litter or handbills, any or all litter or handbills deposited thereon by any person prior to the date of execution of sentence. 
(Code 1994, § 19-83)  
Sec. 34-114. - Commercial, noncommercial handbills. 
(a)  Throwing, distributing in public places. No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city. 
(b)  Placing on vehicles. No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill into or upon any unoccupied vehicle in such a manner as to cause the handbill to become scattered by the elements and become litter. This section shall not prevent the display of handbills on a vehicle by the owner thereof. 
(c)  Depositing on uninhabited or vacant premises. No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private premises which reasonably appear to be uninhabited or vacant. Indicators that such premises are uninhabited or vacant are the accumulation of newspapers or handbills, a sign indicating the house is for sale or rent, the lack of draperies and furnishings in the dwelling, and other such conditions. 
(d)  Prohibited where posted. No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill upon any private premises, if requested by any person thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on such premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisement" or any similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of such premises do not desire to be molested or disturbed, or to have any such handbills left upon such premises. 
(e)  Distributing at inhabited private premises. 
(1)  No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant, or other person then present in or upon such private premises willing to accept it, or by placing or depositing it within five feet of the main door of such inhabited private premises and securing it to prevent it from being blown or scattered about such premises or sidewalks, streets, or other public places. Mailboxes may not be so used when prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. 
(2)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States, nor to newspapers except that newspapers shall be placed on private property in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place, or upon private property. 
(Code 1994, §§ 19-84—19-88)  
Sec. 34-115. - Distributing noncommercial handbills in public places. 
It shall not be unlawful in any public place for a person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the receiver thereof, a noncommercial handbill to any person who is willing to accept it. 
(Code 1994, § 19-89) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36.  
Sec. 34-116. - Names and addresses of responsible parties. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, scatter, hand out or circulate any commercial or noncommercial handbill in any place, under any circumstances, which does not have printed on the cover, front or back thereof, the name and address of the following: 
(1)  The person who printed, wrote, compiled or manufactured the same. 
(2)  The person who caused the same to be distributed; provided, however, that in the case of a fictitious person or club, in addition to such fictitious name, the true names and addresses of the owners, managers or agents of the person sponsoring such handbill shall also appear thereon. 
(Code 1994, § 19-90)  
Sec. 34-117. - Offensive handbills. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to post, hand out, distribute or transmit any commercial or noncommercial handbill which: 
(1)  May reasonably tend to incite riot or other public disorder, or which advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by means of any artifice, scheme, or violence; 
(2)  Is obscene or libelous; or 
(3)  Is harmful to minors, if it is distributed in such a manner as to be reasonably expected to be viewed by minors. 
(Code 1994, § 19-91)  
Sec. 34-118. - Nuisance. 
In addition to the penalties stated in section 34-113, the violation of any provision of this division is hereby declared to be a nuisance, which may be abated pursuant to state law. 
(Code 1994, § 19-92) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 18-31 et seq.  
Chapter 36 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-12(5); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-12(9); drinking in public conveyances, § 4-7; animals running at large or grazing on streets and sidewalks, § 6-4; exhibiting animals kept for service on streets, § 6-5; buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; consent agreement for placing lines in streets or similar public places, § 10-211 et seq.; cemeteries, ch. 12; environment, ch. 18; flood damage prevention, ch. 21; parades, picketing and demonstrations, ch. 28; parks and recreation, ch. 30; soil erosion and sedimentation control, ch. 32; disposal of solid waste in public places, § 34-8; distributing noncommercial handbills in public places, § 34-115; utilities, ch. 40; vegetation, ch. 42; distance of trees from curbs and sidewalks, § 42-48. 
State Law reference— Municipal regulation of streets, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-30. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 36-1. - Council approval of street names or name changes. 
No person shall name any street or change the name of any street, except upon consent of the city council as authorized by resolution. 
(Code 1994, § 20-1)  
Sec. 36-2. - Numbering of residences, businesses and other establishments. 
All residences, businesses, buildings, structures and other establishments must be numbered according to the street number designation provided by the city. The numbers shall be located in a conspicuous place and must be of such size that the numbers may be easily read from the street. No number shall be less than four inches in height, and each number must be black in color and made of metal or plastic. Any new dwelling, business or establishment must be numbered at the time the dwelling, business or building is completed. 
(Code 1994, § 20-2)  
Sec. 36-3. - Playing games or throwing rocks or missiles on streets. 
No person shall play any games or throw any rocks or missiles on any public street within the city. 
(Code 1994, § 20-3)  
Sec. 36-4. - Littering streets, alleys, or sidewalks prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to litter, place, throw, track, or allow to fall on any street, alley, or sidewalk, any refuse, glass, tacks, mud, or other objects or materials which are unsightly or which obstruct or tend to limit or interfere with the use of such public ways and places for their intended purposes. 
(Ord. No. 590, § 20-4, 12-15-2003)  
Secs. 36-5—36-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PAVING 
 
Sec. 36-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City road means a public road or public way that is listed on the official inventory of city roads and bridges adopted by the city council. 
Full width means the width of a road that is appropriate for the right-of-way available. Full width improvement on a 50-foot right-of-way would consist of a 20-foot roadway, five-foot shoulders, three additional feet to the center of the ditches and seven-foot back slopes. Full width improvement of a 36-foot right-of-way would consist of an 18-foot roadway, three-foot shoulders, two additional feet to the centerline of the ditches and four-foot back slopes. Improving a road to full width includes installation of proper drainage facilities. 
Residence means an occupied dwelling place including houses, modular homes and mobile homes which have permanent electrical power installation. 
Unimproved property means any tract of land that does not contain a residence. Improving a road to property with a residence when that road is not the primary access to the residence shall be considered improvement of a road to unimproved property. 
(Code 1994, § 20-31) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 36-32. - Work on city right-of-way and property. 
(a)  Waste soil. All waste soil shall be stockpiled on city property. If soil stockpiles exceed foreseeable needs or available space, such soil may be disposed of by the city purchasing agent, in accordance with the current procedure for disposal of city property. 
(b)  Gravel. City crews may place gravel on any city road from its beginning to the last residence served by the road. Beyond the last residence, the existing surface may be maintained by scraping but no sand, gravel or cinders will be added at city expense. City crews may place gravel purchased by others on a city road that does not meet the above criteria. This does not include the road acceptance fee. If a cul-de-sac is within 100 feet of the last residence, the 100 feet of road and cul-de-sac may be graveled. Through roads, i.e., roads with termination on a public road at both ends, may be graveled upon approval of the city council. 
(c)  Road improvements. Unless otherwise directed by the city council, a city road may be improved according to the following guideline: A road may be improved to full width to a residence by the most economical route, provided that a minimum density of one residence every 1,500 feet exists. Improving a road without the required density or beyond the last residence requires approval of the city council. 
(d)  Roadside ditches. The city may provide labor, equipment and cover material to pipe roadside ditches on city roads, provided that the affected property owner provides all necessary pipe, and catchbasin materials on the site, but if piping a roadside ditch on a city road or bridge will materially benefit the road or bridge, the city council may approve provision of the necessary materials at the city's expense. 
(e)  Driveway entrances. The city may provide and/or install drainage lines at private driveway entrances to facilitate proper roadway drainage, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  No more than 20 linear feet of pipe 36 inches or less in diameter may be provided per lot. 
(2)  No pipe or structures larger than 36 inches in diameter may be installed by the city. Larger structures installed on a city right-of-way by others require an encroachment permit. 
(3)  As many as two driveway entrances, not over 20 feet in width, will be permitted on each lot, and may be paved from a minimum distance of seven feet to a maximum distance of the right-of-way line, measured from the edge of the roadway and perpendicular to the centerline. No more than 20 feet of pipe may be furnished by the city. Although two driveway entrances are allowed, the city will only provide the materials for one driveway entrance. If a citizen desires a second one, the citizen must pay the cost of the materials, installation and maintenance. 
(4)  No pipe may be furnished, installed or maintained on private roads. Installation of pipe for private roads requires an encroachment permit. Roads being constructed for dedication to the city shall be considered private prior to final acceptance. 
(f)  Resurfacing. The street department shall prepare and submit to the city council annually a proposed resurfacing program. The roads in the program shall be presented to the city council in the order of their priority based upon their structural condition and use. All resurfacing that is more than 500 feet in length or 25 percent of the length of a road is subject to this requirement. 
(Code 1994, § 20-32)  
Sec. 36-33. - Work off city right-of-way and property. 
Work may be performed off city rights-of-way or property in the following cases: 
(1)  Protection of city street or bridge. For correcting a situation detrimental to a city street or bridge which affects the safety of the traveling public. Such work may include, but is not limited to, stream channel improvement and sight distance obstruction removal. Upon specific approval of the city administrator, private driveways may be scraped only to the extent necessary to protect a city or county road within the city limits by channeling water into side ditches and cleaning side ditches. Hold harmless agreements are required for all such types of work. 
(2)  Drainage work off city rights-of-ways and properties. To perform maintenance on dedicated easements, provided that such maintenance will provide for the free flow of surface water to a live stream and/or relieve regional flooding conditions along a live stream. The city may provide labor and equipment to perform maintenance on drainage easements and installation of erosion protection, but the easement, in general, must carry water from public roads or lands or be regional in nature. This work will be accomplished only upon request and approval of all property owners adjacent to the easement and after a properly executed hold harmless agreement, and right of entry agreement, signed by all such owners is filed with the city and accepted for recording. Felled trees may be removed only if impeding the normal flow of water and only if it affects a public interest, public health, or public safety. 
No maintenance assistance is offered any development until completion. After completion of a development project, no such assistance shall be rendered to commercial developments, industrial sites, golf courses, apartment complexes, or mobile home parks, without specific approval of council. A record of each project undertaken is to be maintained in the city public works department and made available upon request. The record is to include manpower and equipment usage. 
In the event the work is done by the private property owner, the work must be performed by a licensed, qualified contractor. All work must be inspected during installation and approved by the public works department upon completion and before covering. 
Types of work. The following types of drainage assistance may be performed by the city public works department provided it affects a public interest, public health, or public safety: 
a.  Machine cleaning of normally dry drainage easements to allow free flow of surface water. 
b.  Installation or removal of pipe (labor and equipment only) on normally dry drainage easements. Materials must be furnished by the property owner. All materials furnished including pipe, catch basins, grates and lids must meet city standards. 
c.  Installation of large stone or other erosion protection materials (labor and equipment only) on normally dry drainage easements. 
d.  Unclogging and repair of pipe systems (labor and equipment only) on normally dry drainage easements. 
Conditions. The drainage assistance described above may only be performed under the following conditions: 
a.  All requests for off right-of-way drainage assistance must be approved by the public works director. 
b.  All affected property owners must execute drainage assistance agreements which shall include an easement with permanent encroachment provisions and a hold harmless agreement. These agreements shall be filed with the public works department. 
c.  Drainage assistance may be provided for circumstances involving water which originates from public lands or public rights-of-ways to natural stream beds or drainage systems. 
d.  No materials will be furnished by the city for any of the above types of work. 
e.  No assistance shall be provided to any development prior to its completion. 
f.  No off right-of-way drainage assistance shall be performed more than once in a 12-month period except under extraordinary circumstances and with the concurrence of the city administrator. 
(Code 1994, § 20-33; Ord. No. 542, § 1, 8-20-2001; Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-34. - Road acceptance. 
A road may be accepted into the city system if it satisfies one of the following conditions: 
(1)  Construction meeting the requirements of the city subdivision regulations. 
(2)  Construction as provided by ordinance of council in areas not subject to subdivision regulations. 
(3)  Satisfaction of the following criteria: 
a.  Continuous, unrestricted use by the general public since 1965, as evidenced by aerial photographs and affidavits. 
b.  The road must have served two or more properties in 1965. 
c.  The road must serve two or more residences at the time of acceptance. 
d.  A 50-foot right-of-way or consent agreement, acceptable for recording, must be executed and submitted by all abutting property owners. 
Any road not meeting such criteria may be accepted by the council if it determines that special circumstances exist. 
(Code 1994, § 20-34; Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-35. - Emergencies. 
The city administrator is authorized to use city labor, equipment and material for the purpose of meeting emergencies that may exist and that, in the opinion of the administrator, warrant the use of such equipment, labor and material to protect the property or lives of people in the city provided it affects a public interest, public health, and/or public safety. The city administrator shall file a report with council at its next meeting after such work is completed showing the nature of the emergency and the amount of materials used. 
(Code 1994, § 20-35; Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-36. - Furnishing city equipment, material or labor. 
Except as specified in this article, no city equipment, material or labor will be furnished to corporations, partnerships, buildings, developers, contractors, industrial or commercial establishments or individuals. 
(Code 1994, § 20-36; Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-37. - Authority to participate in cost sharing agreements. 
The city is authorized to participate in cost sharing agreements involving benefited private property within its corporate limits for: 
(1)  Constructing, reconstructing, extending, and otherwise building or improving storm sewer and drainage systems which benefit the public; 
(2)  Constructing, reconstructing, paving, widening, installing curbs and gutters, and improving streets which benefit the public; 
(3)  Constructing, reconstructing, paving, widening or improving sidewalks along any public street which benefits the public. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-38. - Basis for making cost sharing agreements. 
Cost sharing agreements may be made on the basis of: 
(1)  The frontage of private property abutting the project at an equal rate per foot of frontage; or 
(2)  The area of land served, or subject to being served, by the project at an equal rate per unit of area; or 
(3)  The value added to the land served by the project or which may be served by it, as calculated by determining the difference between the appraised value of the land without improvements as shown on the tax records of the county, and the appraised value of the land with improvements according to the appraisal standards and rules adopted by the county at its last revaluation, at an equal rate per dollar of value added; or 
(4)  A combination of two or more of these basis. 
Whenever the basis selected for a cost sharing agreement is either area or value added, council may provide for benefit zones according to the distance benefited property is from the project being undertaken, and may establish differing charges to apply uniformly throughout each benefit zone. 
For each project, council shall endeavor to establish a cost sharing method from the criteria set out in this section which will most accurately reflect the benefit conferred upon it by the project. Council's decision as to the method of determining cost sharing terms shall be final and conclusive and not subject to further review or challenge. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-39. - Corner lot exemptions. 
Council shall have authority to establish exemptions from charges for corner lots when a project is undertaken along both sides of such lots. The exemptions shall be based on categories of land use (residential, commercial, industrial, or agricultural) and shall be uniform for each category. Exemptions are not allowed that exceed 75 percent of the frontage of any side of a corner lot, or 150 feet, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-40. - Cost sharing agreement resolution; contents. 
Whenever council decides to finance a proposed project by cost sharing agreements, it shall first adopt a preliminary resolution that shall contain the following: 
(1)  A statement of intent to undertake the project; 
(2)  A general description of the nature and location of the project; 
(3)  A statement describing the proposed basis for a cost sharing agreement, which shall include a general description of the boundaries of the area benefited if the basis is either area or value added; 
(4)  A statement as to the percentage of the cost of the work that is to be paid for by the private property owner or a specific amount to be paid for by the private property owner; 
(5)  A statement defining any cost to be paid by the private property owner to be held in abeyance and the time therefore; 
(6)  A statement of the proposed terms of payment by the private property owner and the time therefore; 
(7)  A provision establishing a time and place for a public hearing on all matters covered by this article which shall not be earlier than three weeks nor later than ten weeks from the date of the adoption of this article. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-41. - Notice. 
At least ten days before the date set for the public hearing, council shall publish a notice that a cost sharing resolution has been adopted and that a public hearing will be held to receive public comment at a specified time and place. The notice shall generally describe the nature and location of the improvement. In addition, at least ten days prior to the hearing, council shall have a copy of the resolution mailed to the owners of all property subject to cost sharing in the event the project is undertaken. The person designated to mail these resolutions shall file with the council a certificate showing that they were mailed by first-class mail and the date of mailing. The certificate shall be deemed adequate notice of compliance. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-42. - Determination of costs. 
When the project is complete, council shall ascertain the total cost including those for construction, all necessary legal services, engineering services, interest paid during construction, obtaining necessary rights-of-way, and publication of notices and resolutions. The determination of council as to the total cost of any project shall be conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-43. - List of affected property owners. 
When the total cost of a project has been determined, council shall have a list of all affected property owners prepared which shall contain a brief description of each lot, parcel, or tract of land involved, the basis for the costs, the amount charged to each private property owner, the terms of payment including any schedule of discounts, if such a schedule is to be established, and the name of the owner of each parcel of land. A map of the project showing each parcel and the basis of the charges, the amount charged, and the name of the owner, shall be a sufficient list of affected property owners. 
After the list of affected property owners has been completed, it shall be filed in the city clerk's office and made available for public inspection. A notice of the completion of the list of affected property owners, setting forth in general terms a description of the project, the availability of the list of affected property owners in the clerk's office for inspection, and the time and place for a public hearing concerning the list of affected property owners, shall be disseminated at least ten days before the date set for the hearing on the list of affected property owners. Council shall require that a notice of the hearing concerning the list of affected property owners be mailed to the owners of property listed thereon at least ten days before the hearing. The notice shall include the time and place of the hearing, the availability of the list of affected property owners for inspection in the city clerk's office and the amount of the charges for each property owner shown on the list of affected property owners. The person designated to mail these notices shall file with the council a certificate showing they were mailed by first-class mail and the date mailed. The certificate shall be conclusive evidence that the notices were mailed in accordance with the requirements of council unless fraud is shown by an aggrieved property owner. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-44. - Public hearing. 
At the public hearing, council shall hear all interested persons who appear with respect to any matter covered by the cost sharing agreement resolution. After the public hearing, council may adopt a resolution directing that the project or portions thereof be undertaken. This article shall describe the project in general terms (which may be by reference to projects described in this article) and shall set forth the following: 
(1)  The basis of the costs to be shared by the property owner, together with a general description of the boundaries of the area benefited if the basis of the cost sharing is either area or value added; 
(2)  The percentage of the cost to be shared by the property owner, or the specific amount to be shared by the property owner; 
(3)  The terms of payment, including the conditions under which the property owner's shared cost are to be held in abeyance, if any. 
The percentage of the property owner's shared costs may not be different from the percentage proposed, and the projects authorized may not be greater in scope than the projects described in the initial resolution. In the event council decides that a different percentage of the cost or specific cost should be charged than those proposed in the initial resolution, or that any project should be enlarged, it shall adopt and advertise a new resolution as herein provided. 
At the public hearing, all persons shall have an opportunity to be heard, including objections to the list of affected property owners. Thereafter, council shall annul, modify, or confirm the charges, in whole or in part, either by confirming the initial charges for any or all of the lots or parcels described in the list of affected property owners, or by canceling, increasing, or reducing them as may be proper in compliance with the basis of the charges. If any property is omitted, council may place it on the list and levy the proper charges. Whenever council confirms charges for any project, the city clerk shall enter in the minutes of the council meeting the date, and time of confirmation. After the time of confirmation, the property owners shared costs shall constitute a lien on the property in the same manner as a lien for county and city property taxes in accordance with the priorities set out in section 36-48. After the list of affected property owners is confirmed, a copy shall be delivered to the city finance director for collection in the same manner as property taxes, except as provided herein. 
This hearing may be held in conjunction with the public hearing to confirm the list of affected property owners (see section 36-45). 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-45. - Publication of notice of confirmation of list of affected property owners. 
After the expiration of 20 days from the confirmation of the list of affected property owners, the city finance director shall publish a notice that the list of affected property owners has been confirmed, and that charges may be paid without interest at any time before the expiration of 30 days from the date that the notice is published. If not paid within this time, all installments thereof shall bear interest as provided in section 36-48. The notice shall include the schedule of discounts, if one has been established; to be applied to the property owners shared costs paid before the expiration date for payment of property owners shared costs without interest. 
This hearing may be held in conjunction with the public hearing to consider the cost sharing agreement resolution (see section 36-44). 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-46. - Reassessment. 
Council shall have the power when, in its judgment, any irregularity, omission, or error in any of the proceedings related thereto, has occurred, to set aside any special charge made by it and thereupon to make a reassessment. In that event, all additional interest paid, or to be paid, as a result of the delay in confirming the property owners shared costs shall be included as a part of the project cost. The proceeding shall, as far as practicable, take place in the same manner as those used in determining the original property owners shared costs. The new property owners shared costs shall have the same force as if they had originally been properly made. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-47. - Payment of assessments in cash or by installments. 
Property owners involved shall have the option, within 30 days after the publication of the notice that the list of affected property owners has been confirmed, of paying the shared costs either in cash or in installments as determined by council in the resolution. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Sec. 36-48. - Enforcement of property owners shared costs; interests; foreclosure; limitations. 
(a)  Any portion of property owners shared costs that are not paid within 30 days after publication of the notice that the list of affected property owners has been confirmed shall bear interest until paid at a rate to be fixed by council at a rate not more than eight percent per annum. 
(b)  If any installment of a property owners shared costs is not paid on or before the due date, all of the installments remaining unpaid shall immediately become due and payable, unless the council waives acceleration. Council may waive acceleration and permit the property owner to pay all installments in arrears together with interest due thereon and the cost to the city of attempting to obtain payment. If this is done, the remaining installments shall be reinstated so that they fall due as if there had been no default. Waiver of acceleration and reinstatement of future installments may be done at any time before foreclosure proceedings have been instituted. 
(c)  Liens may be foreclosed under any procedure prescribed by law for the foreclosure of property tax liens, except that lien sales and lien sale certificates shall not be required, and foreclosure may be begun at any time after 30 days after the due date. The city shall not be entitled to a deficiency judgment in an action to foreclose a lien. The lien shall be inferior to all prior and subsequent liens for state, local, and federal taxes, and superior to all other liens. 
(Ord. No. 821, 3-20-2017)  
Secs. 36-49—36-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Repair of streets, etc., generally, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-27-120. 
 
Sec. 36-71. - Permit required; fee. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to break, dig holes or trenches in or cause excavation of any kind to be made in any of the streets, alleys, parks, squares, sidewalks or rights-of-way of the city, for the purpose of placing any poles, rails, cables or wires of any kind, for laying water, sewer, gas or other pipes or for any other purpose, except with a written permit from the city. A permit fee shall be charged for each permit. The amount of the excavation permit fee shall be set from time to time and a schedule of such fees is on file in the municipal clerk's office. 
(Code 1994, § 20-56)  
Sec. 36-72. - Cash deposit in addition to fee. 
When a permit is granted under this article, the person obtaining such permit may, before beginning work thereunder, deliver to the city a cash deposit in such sum as may be required by the city council. The return to the permittee of such cash deposit shall be conditioned upon the proper repair, renewal or replacement of any street, surface, pavement, sidewalk, curbstone or other public property that may be removed, disturbed or otherwise injured during the course of the work under such permit and upon the leaving by the permittee of the same in as good condition as before such work was done or such excavation made. Such cash deposit, if required, is in addition to the permit fee. 
(Code 1994, § 20-57)  
Sec. 36-73. - Bond. 
When a permit is granted under this article, the person obtaining such permit may be required by the city, before beginning work thereunder, to execute and deliver to the city a good and sufficient bond, in writing, in such sum as may be required by general resolution, conditioned upon the payment of any damages which may result to any persons or property by reason of any pole, pipe, wire, barrier or other obstruction of any kind placed in or upon the streets, alleys, parks, squares, sidewalks or curbstones of the city by the permittee or his agent and further conditioned upon the repayment to the city of any sum of money which the city may at any time be compelled to pay out by reason of any acts on the part of such permittee or his agent or the failure to properly repair the excavation. 
(Code 1994, § 20-58)  
Sec. 36-74. - Repair of pavement. 
When pavement is disturbed or removed by any person making excavations therein pursuant to a permit, the person making such excavation or causing the excavation to be made shall repair or replace the excavation in accordance with the requirements of the city and warrant such repairs for one year. 
(Code 1994, § 20-59)  
Sec. 36-75. - Removing, damaging pipes, poles, wires, other appurtenances. 
Whenever, in the opinion of the city council, it is necessary to have the pipes of gas or water companies or the poles, wires, rails or other appurtenances of any kind of telegraph, telephone, electric lighting, electric power or public transportation companies changed, removed or relaid for the purpose of improvements in streets, alleys, parks, squares, sidewalks or curbstones, whether by regrading, widening or otherwise improving such streets, parks, squares, sidewalks or curbstones, the owners of such pipes, poles, wires, rails or other appurtenances shall, within a reasonable time after demand made on them by the city council, remove, relay or otherwise change the position of such pipes, poles, wires, rails or appurtenances as may be directed by the city, but at the expense of such owners. In no case shall such owners be entitled to damages from the city for interference with or injury to such pipes, poles, wires, rails or other appurtenances by reason of work upon or improvement in or on any street, alley, park, square, sidewalk or curbstone by authority of the city or its officers or agents. 
(Code 1994, § 20-60)  
Sec. 36-76. - Depth of pipes. 
No person shall lay or place any sewer, water or gas pipes in or under any of the streets, alleys, parks, squares, sidewalks or curbstones in the city, unless such pipes shall be laid at such depth below the surface of such streets, alleys, parks, squares, sidewalks or curbstones as may be required by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 20-61)  
Sec. 36-77. - Liability for work and maintenance. 
Any person doing any work under this article shall be liable for any claims arising by virtue of such work and shall be liable for any claims by virtue of the failure to properly repair such street, etc. Such person shall be required to see to the proper maintenance of any repaved or filled-in area for a period of one year following the completion of the work. Any sinking or other defect shall be promptly repaired by such person. 
(Code 1994, § 20-62)  
Sec. 36-78. - Restoration prerequisite to turning on electricity or granting occupancy permit. 
No permanent electrical power shall be released to any property and no occupancy permit shall be granted for any building or dwelling until the owner or contractor has replaced or corrected any damage done to the right-of-way, curb and street adjacent to such property. 
(Code 1994, § 20-63)  
Sec. 36-79. - Maintenance of roadside vegetation. 
(a)  Trimming limbs and shrubbery. Tree limbs, shrubbery or other vegetation overhanging into city streets from public rights-of-way shall be trimmed or pruned one foot from the edge of the street pavement or one foot from the back side of curbing to a height of no less than 15 feet in height. Where tree limbs, shrubbery or other vegetation protrudes into the right-of-way, so as to interfere with vision, obscure a traffic sign or signal, obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic, and/or strikes or scrapes against such traffic, the city or its agent upon notification will take immediate action to remove the obstruction. 
(b)  Intersection site triangles. Intersection site triangles shall be maintained to allow proper site distance from intersections. All trees and shrubbery shall be trimmed or pruned to allow proper site distance from each direction at the intersection. All trees or shrubbery trimmed or pruned commercially shall be the responsibility of the contractor or property owner and it shall be their responsibility for disposal. 
(c)  Streetlight obstruction. Streetlights obstructed by vegetation will be reported to the respective utility. 
(Code 1994, § 20-64)  
Chapter 38 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Open containers of alcohol while in vehicles, § 4-8; abandoned and junked motor vehicles, § 18-61 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 22; municipal court, ch. 24; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 26; operation of motor vehicles in parks, § 30-4; truck loads or tires causing litter, § 34-85. 
State Law reference— Motor vehicles, S.C. Code 1976, tit. 56. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 38-1. - Jurisdiction of municipal court. 
The municipal court may try and determine criminal cases involving violations of the provisions of this chapter or of the S.C. Code of 1976 relating to motor vehicles and traffic occurring within the city limits when the penalty prescribed by state law for such violations does not exceed the penalties provided by section 1-6. The municipal court may have trial jurisdiction over such criminal cases the same as magistrates. 
(Code 1994, § 11-1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-6150.  
Sec. 38-2. - Adoption of state laws. 
Unless otherwise specifically covered by this chapter, all of the provisions and requirements of the general law of the state regulating traffic on highways registration and licensing, and driver's licenses, as contained in S.C. Code 1976, §§ 56-1-10 et seq., 56-3-10 et seq., and 56-5-10 et seq. insofar as such provisions can have application within the city, are hereby adopted and made a part of this chapter as fully as though set out in this section. All persons within the city shall strictly comply with all of the regulations imposed hereby, when so applicable. 
(Code 1994, § 11-2)  
Sec. 38-3. - Powers generally of city council. 
The city council, except as otherwise directed by this chapter or state law, shall have the power to: 
(1)  Regulate the operation and parking of vehicles within the city by the erection or placing of proper signs or markers indicating prohibited or limited parking, restricted speed areas, one-way streets, play streets, through or arterial streets, parking meter spaces in parking meter zones, U-turns, school zones, hospital zones, loading and unloading zones, quiet zones and other signs, markers and official traffic control devices indicating the place or manner of operating or parking vehicles within the city. 
(2)  Secure all necessary signs, markers or official traffic control devices to be erected or placed on any street or part of a street when such action is deemed necessary. The existence of such signs, markers or official traffic control devices at any place within the city shall be prima facie evidence that such signs, markers or official traffic control devices are erected or placed by and at the direction of the council and in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(3)  Regulate the movement of pedestrians upon the streets and sidewalks of the city by the erection or placing of proper signs or markers indicating the flow of pedestrian traffic. 
(4)  Designate bus stops and taxicab stands and erect signs prohibiting the parking of vehicles other than buses and taxicabs at their respective stops and stands. 
(5)  Designate truck routes and regulate the parking of vehicles of various sizes and weights. 
(6)  Mark off traffic lanes on streets and parts of streets indicating and directing the flow of traffic when, in the judgment of the council, such action is necessary. 
(Code 1994, § 11-3)  
Sec. 38-4. - State driver's and vehicle licenses required. 
No person shall operate a motor vehicle on any street in the city without a valid state driver's license to operate the vehicle, and such vehicle shall have valid state license tags. 
(Code 1994, § 11-4)  
Sec. 38-5. - Certificates of public convenience and necessity for taxicabs or ambulances. 
No person shall operate any taxicab or ambulance in the city without first having obtained a certificate of public convenience and necessity from the city council authorizing such operation. Upon application therefor, the city council shall investigate the matter and issue such certificates as they deem advisable, upon such terms and conditions as it, in its discretion, might require. 
(Code 1994, § 11-5)  
Secs. 38-6—38-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION 
 
Sec. 38-41. - Improper use of driveways. 
It shall be unlawful for any person driving a vehicle to use the driveway of any filling station or service station in the city as a roadway or thoroughfare. 
(Code 1994, § 11-31)  
Sec. 38-42. - Turning movements restricted; use of private property for U-turn.
