It shall be unlawful for any person driving a vehicle to make any U-turn or other prohibited turn at any point where such turn is prohibited. It shall be unlawful to accomplish a U-turn by deviously going into or through private property adjoining the street where such turn is prohibited. 
(Code 1994, § 11-32)  
Sec. 38-43. - Use of vehicle for advertising. 
No person shall operate or park any vehicle on any street for the primary purpose of advertising. 
(Code 1994, § 11-33)  
Sec. 38-44. - Obstruction of intersections. 
No driver shall enter an intersection or marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal to proceed. 
(Code 1994, § 11-34)  
Sec. 38-45. - Negligent operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle upon a public way in the city negligently or heedlessly or without due caution in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. Any person found guilty of this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 11-35)  
Secs. 38-46—38-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Obstructing fire equipment, firefighters; parking near fire hydrant, § 20-1; following fire apparatus too closely or parking near fire, § 20-2. 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate stopping, standing and parking, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710(1); stopping, standing and parking regulated, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2510. 
 
Sec. 38-81. - Obstructing roadways. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon a street, other than an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic; except, that a driver may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals of a police officer. 
(b)  No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1994, § 11-56)  
Sec. 38-82. - Loading zones. 
The city council may from time to time designate parking spaces as loading zones. No vehicle shall be parked in such spaces except trucks and commercial vehicles for the purposes of loading or unloading cargo. 
(Code 1994, § 11-57)  
Sec. 38-83. - Regulations not exclusive. 
The provisions of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1994, § 11-58)  
Sec. 38-84. - Parking prohibited on certain streets. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful to park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets so designated. The city administrator may designate such areas with the recommendation of the traffic engineer or by direction of the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 11-59)  
Sec. 38-85. - Parking restricted on certain streets. 
When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful to park a vehicle between the hours and on any day specified on such signs upon any of the streets in the city. Such areas may be designated by the city administrator upon the recommendation of the traffic engineer or by direction of the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 11-60)  
Sec. 38-86. - Prohibited in specified places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to stop, stand or park such vehicle in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control sign or signal: 
(1)  On a sidewalk. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway or so near thereto as to interfere with the unobstructed use of such driveway. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
(5)  On a crosswalk. 
(6)  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
(7)  Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located on the side of a roadway. 
(8)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless indicated for a different length by official signs or markings. 
(9)  Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing. 
(10)  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station or on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of such entrance. 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a street or within a highway tunnel. 
(14)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping, standing or parking or within any zones designated for buses, taxis or any public service vehicles. 
(15)  In any designated parking zone beyond the time specified by any adjacent parking or traffic control sign or device. It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally or willfully erase, remove, or obliterate any marks or symbols placed upon any vehicle by a police officer pursuant to his duties, or to move a motor vehicle in such a manner or to another location so as to park beyond any prescribed time periods or to avoid payment of any parking penalties or to evade any parking ordinances of this city. 
(16)  Adjacent to a curb marked with red or yellow paint. 
(17)  In any parking zone designated for handicapped parking unless the vehicle has a valid license tag issued by the state department of highways and public transportation with a special number or identification indicating that such tag has been issued to a handicapped person. 
(18)  On any railroad tracks. 
(19)  On any controlled access highway. 
(20)  In the area between roadways of a divided highway, including crossovers. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(Code 1994, § 11-61)  
Sec. 38-87. - Proximity to curbs. 
(a)  Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a roadway where there are adjacent curbs shall be so stopped or parked with the righthand wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within 18 inches of the righthand curb, except where angle parking is permitted and except on one-way streets where parking is permitted on both sides. 
(b)  No violation of this section shall be deemed to have occurred whenever such parked vehicle is located within the outside boundary lines or pavement marks indicating the limits of such parking space when such exist. 
(Code 1994, § 11-62)  
Sec. 38-88. - Manner of parking within parking zones. 
(a)  When a parking space in any parking zone is parallel with the adjacent curb or sidewalk, any vehicle parked in such parking space shall be parked with the foremost part of the vehicle pointed in the direction of the flow of traffic. On two-way streets, such parking causes the right side of the vehicles to be adjacent to the curb or sidewalk. 
(b)  When a parking space in any parking zone is at an angle from the adjacent curb or sidewalk, any vehicle parked in such parking space shall be parked with the foremost part of the vehicle adjacent to the curb or sidewalk. 
(Code 1994, § 11-63)  
Sec. 38-89. - Stopping, standing or parking in loading zones. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to stop, stand, or park such vehicle for a longer period of time than is necessary for the expeditious loading and unloading of passengers or materials in any place marked as a loading zone. In no case shall such period exceed 30 minutes. Such loading zones shall be marked with yellow paint along the curb or other appropriate sign or device. 
(Code 1994, § 11-64)  
Sec. 38-90. - Parking to be incidental to use and operation of vehicle. 
No vehicle shall be parked on any street except when such parking is incidental to the use and operation of the vehicle. The storage or parking on the streets of vehicles, by garages, dealers or other persons, when such storage or parking is not incidental to the bona fide use and operation of the vehicle is prohibited. 
(Code 1994, § 11-65)  
Sec. 38-91. - Notice to appear to answer charge of parking violation. 
(a)  Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked in violation of any of the parking restrictions of this article, the officer finding it shall take its registration number and any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and affix conspicuously to such vehicle a notice in writing, on a form provided by the city, for the driver to answer to the charge against him during the hours and at the time and place specified in the notice. The officer shall send one copy of such notice to the municipal court. 
(b)  Any driver of a motor vehicle who willfully neglects to answer to the charges set forth in a notice so affixed by a police officer in accordance with this section shall have the fine doubled if not paid by court date. If after 60 days the fine has not been paid, a warrant will be issued by the court. Proof of ownership of any motor vehicle shall be prima facie evidence that such owner parked such vehicle. 
(Code 1994, § 11-66)  
Sec. 38-92. - Responsibility of owner for vehicle found illegally parked. 
If any vehicle is found upon a street in violation of any provision of this article regulating the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles and the identity of the driver cannot be determined, the owner or person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be held prima facie responsible for such violation. 
(Code 1994, § 11-67)  
Sec. 38-93. - Parking of commercial vehicles on residential streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any commercial vehicle to park on a street in a residentially zoned area, except as authorized in this section. 
(b)  A commercial vehicle shall include any of the following: 
(1)  Vehicles designed to transport more than ten people. 
(2)  Vehicles with more than six wheels. 
(3)  Farm tractors and tractors with a fifth wheel designed for transporting trailers or other equipment. 
(4)  Construction equipment and bulldozers. 
(5)  Trailers. 
(6)  Recreational vehicles with sleeping facilities. 
(7)  Motor vehicles which exceed or equal a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) of 15,001 pounds. The term "gross vehicle weight rating" (GVWR) means the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle. 
(c)  Vehicles delivering products or services to a nearby dwelling or residence are exempt from this prohibition while in the process of such delivery. Public utility vehicles are also exempt while on duty at the site. 
(Ord. No. 509, § 11-69, 11-15-1999)  
Sec. 38-94. - Fines. 
A schedule of fines shall be applied to parking violations within the city. The schedule is not printed in this section but is on file in the municipal clerk's office. 
(Code 1994, § 11-68)  
Sec. 38-95. - Parking or driving upon city-owned or city-used property. 
(a)  No person may stop, stand, or park any vehicle upon city-owned property or any property used by the city pursuant to lease, agreement, easement, etc., or any portion thereof in violation of any parking restriction posted on signs, markings, traffic control devices, or gates. 
(b)  No person shall park or permit to be parked upon city-owned or city-used property any vehicle unless the parking of such vehicle is incidental to the use of the city property where the vehicle is parked. 
(c)  No person may drive or operate a vehicle upon city-owned or city-used property in a manner which impedes the use of said property. 
(d)  For the purposes of this ordinance, "city-owned property" subject to this section shall mean any lands which the city owns, leases, or uses pursuant to agreement or easement, or in which it has acquired a beneficial interest by virtue of an agreement for sale or conveyance. 
(e)  The city may have any vehicle that violates this section towed at the owner's expense. 
(f)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section may be fined in accordance with the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 792, 10-19-2015)  
Secs. 38-96—38-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - RAILROADS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Mailing copies of municipal ordinances affecting railroads required, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-7-35. 
 
Sec. 38-121. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Grade crossing means a crossing at grade of a public street or highway over tracks of a railroad. 
Railroad means a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than streetcars, operated on stationary rails. 
Railroad signal or sign means any sign, signal or device erected by authority of a public body or official or by a railroad and intended to give notice of the presence of railroad tracks or the approach of a railroad train. 
Railroad train means a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto and operated upon rails, other than a streetcar. 
(Code 1994, § 11-91) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 38-122. - Complaints to state public service commission. 
The mayor or city council may apply directly to the state public service commission for relief from conduct of any railroad within the city limits in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1994, § 11-92) 
State Law reference— Complaints of railroads by local governments, S.C. Code 1976, § 58-17-190.  
Sec. 38-123. - Duties at crossings generally. 
It shall be the duty of the flagman to keep a lookout for the approach of cars crossing such streets and to warn persons crossing or about to cross at such place of the approach of any train, car or engine. 
(Code 1994, § 11-93)  
Sec. 38-124. - Red flag or light required. 
Each flagman shall be provided with and keep a red flag during the daytime and a red light during the nighttime, and the appropriate signal shall be displayed at all times upon the approach of any train, car or engine. 
(Code 1994, § 11-94)  
Sec. 38-125. - Disregarding warnings; interfering with, resisting or annoying. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cross the railroad track after having been warned by a flagman. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, resist or annoy any flagman while in the discharge of the duties imposed by this article. 
(Code 1994, § 11-95)  
Secs. 38-126—38-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - WRECKERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 10. 
 
Sec. 38-161. - Criteria for assignment to rotation list. 
Any firm having its principal business operation within the city limits shall become eligible to be considered for assignment of wrecker service calls by the police department provided that: 
(1)  The firm has a valid license to do business in the city. 
(2)  The firm's storage lot, which will be used to contain any vehicle towed as a result of a service call from the police department, is located within the city limits. 
(3)  The firm conforms to the rules and requirements of this plan. Any deviation from the requirements of this plan or any failure to provide reasonable, quick, and efficient service may result, upon a finding by the chief of police, in that firm's being removed from the police duty wrecker list. 
(4)  The owner's request will be honored only if the requested tow truck is on the scene within 15 minutes from the time that it is dispatched, or at the discretion of an investigating officer. 
(5)  No tow truck will respond to any scene without being called by the city. 
(6)  Tow truck drivers will be responsible for cleaning all debris from the road and right-of-way. 
(7)  The tow service must have a telephone located in the business and must furnish the city with at least one after-hours telephone number. 
(8)  There shall be an attendant on call, capable of responding to police calls for towing as well as being present or available for the release of vehicles to the public during normal business hours. 
(9)  Each firm shall be expected to provide adequate public liability and property damage insurance to protect the public from any loss or damage arising from the operation of the wrecker. 
(10)  Each firm shall have a storage lot within the city in close proximity to its regular place of business. Such lot shall have adequate storage. 
(Code 1994, § 11-116)  
Sec. 38-162. - Application of article provisions. 
It is not the purpose or intent of this article to regulate any person owning a wrecker and operating the same in connection with an automobile sales or repair agency in the city and who does not wish to apply to be placed on the list of wreckers on call by the city police department and rotate on a basis as provided by this article; provided, however, that the provisions of section 38-161 shall apply to all persons owning or operating a wrecker in the city. 
(Code 1994, § 11-117)  
Sec. 38-163. - Storage of disabled vehicles. 
All business operations under this article and the storage of all wrecked or disabled vehicles shall be in conformity with all other existing ordinances of the city, particularly the ordinances pertaining to planning and zoning. 
(Code 1994, § 11-118)  
Sec. 38-164. - Charges regulated. 
The city council may promulgate and fix the charges which an applicant shall charge for his wrecker or towing services. A copy of such charges shall be furnished to the applicant and signed by the applicant thereby agreeing to abide by the charges so fixed. 
(Code 1994, § 11-119)  
Sec. 38-165. - Rules; regulations. 
The chief of police and the city administrator shall have the authority to promulgate and enforce other reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article for the proper and efficient operation of wrecker or towing services in the city. 
(Code 1994, § 11-120)  
Sec. 38-166. - Establishment and use of rotation list. 
The city administrator and the chief of police shall determine when each wrecker service shall be subject to call by the police department of the city. The city administrator and the chief of police shall have the authority to determine the number of wrecker operators to be placed on the rotation list and subject to call by the police department of the city in any given year, according to duly adopted rules and regulations providing for criteria to be considered in selecting operators subject to call by the police department. 
(Code 1994, § 11-121)  
Sec. 38-167. - Right of vehicle owner not impaired. 
Nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the owner of any wrecked or disabled vehicle from selecting a wrecker service of his own choice if he is unwilling to permit the wrecker service then on call to handle his vehicle. 
(Code 1994, § 11-122)  
Sec. 38-168. - Application of rotation system. 
All persons licensed by the city under this article to operate a wrecker or towing service shall abide by the rotation system to be promulgated and shall not answer any call or offer its services to the owner of any wrecked or disabled vehicle unless specifically requested by the owner. 
(Code 1994, § 11-123)  
Sec. 38-169. - Solicitation restricted. 
No person operating a wrecker in the city, whether licensed under this article or not, shall solicit business for his wrecker at the scene of any wreck. 
(Code 1994, § 11-124)  
Sec. 38-170. - Determination of violation. 
The operator of any wrecker that appears on the scene of a wreck without being called by the owner of the wrecked or disabled vehicle or the police department of the city and who attempts to solicit business or refuses to leave the scene of a wreck upon request of the police department shall be held in violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 11-125)  
Sec. 38-171. - License. 
(a)  Required. No person shall engage in the wrecker or towing service or business within the city: 
(1)  Unless he maintains and operates such business on private property within the city limits. 
(2)  Without first obtaining a business license for the operation of his business from the finance administrator. 
(b)  Application. Any person desiring to operate a wrecker or towing service in the city shall first be required to complete an application form containing the information provided for in this section. The application shall set forth the following information and any other pertinent information as may be required by the city administrator: 
(1)  The name, home address and proposed business address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location of the applicant's place of business, the hours during which the business will be open for service, the number of and a description of each wrecker or towing truck which will be owned by the applicant setting forth the serial number of each vehicle and if not owned, the name of the owner or lessor. 
(3)  The number of available spaces that the applicant has for the storage of wrecked or disabled motor vehicles, together with a description of the building or enclosure in which the wrecked or disabled vehicles will be stored. The daily or weekly charge for such storage for each vehicle. Storage areas shall be completely enclosed by a fence. 
(4)  The names of the drivers and attendants who will operate the wrecker or towing vehicles. These employees shall be of good moral character, and the applicant shall set forth all state or city traffic violations for the past three years which any of these employees have been charged with and the disposition of the charges. 
(5)  Such other information as the city administrator shall find reasonably necessary to effectuate the purpose and intent of this article. 
(c)  Insurance coverage. 
(1)  Before any license shall be issued under the provisions of this article for the city, the applicant shall furnish and file with the city a copy of an insurance policy as follows: 
a.  A garage keeper's regular liability policy covering fire, theft or any damage which may result to a person's motor vehicle in the care or under the control or in storage with the applicant in the amount of at least state-required coverage subject to a deduction for not more than $100.00. 
b.  A garage liability insurance policy covering the operation of the applicant's business equipment or vehicles in an amount not less than the minimum amount required by state law for a general automobile liability policy of an individual. 
(2)  Each policy required in subsection (c)(1) of this section must contain an endorsement providing that the insurer shall give to the city at least 30 days' notice of any change or cancellation of the policy. The policies required in this section shall be kept on file by the city in the office of the finance administrator. 
(d)  Revocation. The chief of police or the city administrator shall have the right to revoke any license issued under this division for cause after giving to the applicant or licensee three days' written notice of a hearing before the city administrator, which notice shall state the time, date and location of such hearing and the act complained of. 
(Code 1994, §§ 11-126—11-129)  
Chapter 40 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 40-1. - Construction of sanitary sewer facilities. 
(a)  Generally. Any person may, after entering into an agreement with the city, construct sanitary sewer facilities in the city. All lines, treatment facilities and other phases of the plans and work must be approved by the city council prior to commencement of any work. All work shall be subject to inspection and approval by the city council. 
(b)  Procedure. 
(1)  Plans and specifications. Any person who proposes to construct sanitary sewers in the city, or elsewhere if such sewers are to connect onto the city sewer system or are to be connected to the sewer system in the city drainage basin, shall be required to have plans and specifications for such sewers prepared by a registered engineer. Prior to construction, such plans shall be submitted to the municipal clerk, who will forward the plans to the city engineer for approval or disapproval. In the event of disapproval, such plans must be revised to meet the requirements of the city engineer. After approval, at least 24 hours' notice must be given the city engineer before construction begins. 
(2)  Inspection, certification of completion of work; map of house service connections. During construction, the city engineer may inspect the work to determine that proper materials and techniques are being used. After completion, the city engineer will require that the owner's engineer furnish the city with a certificate that the sewers have been tamped, metered for infiltration and the trench tamped and that the sewers have been built in general accordance with the plans. The owner's engineer shall also submit to the city a map showing the locations of house service connections. 
(3)  Acceptance by city. The city may accept such sewers in the city sewer system upon the city engineer certifying to the city that the requirements of the city and the city engineer have been met. 
(4)  Fee for services of city engineer. The owner of the sewer system shall be required to pay for the services of the city engineer at his regular charge of salaries plus 125 percent, plus expenses. 
(Code 1994, §§ 22-1, 22-2)  
Sec. 40-2. - Connections generally; connection fees. 
(a)  No sewer connection or tap of any kind whatsoever may be made into the city's sewer system without obtaining a permit therefor from the city. All connections must be made according to the requirements of the city and inspected and approved by a representative of the city before the ditch has been backfilled. 
(b)  All properties annexed into the city shall be required to connect to the city sewer system within 60 days after annexation if sewer service is reasonably available to the annexed property at the time of annexation. Council may, in its discretion, annex property which does not have sewer reasonably available at the time of annexation. If sewer service to the annexed property is not reasonably available at the time of annexation, but subsequently becomes available, then the annexed property must connect to the city sewer system within 60 days after sewer service becomes available to said property. City council shall have the sole discretion to determine whether or not sewer service is reasonably available to any property located within the city or under consideration for annexation. In the event that the septic tank system of a property owner fails when sewer service becomes available, then said property owner must immediately connect to the sewer system and the 60-day time period to connect to the system shall not apply. 
(c)  A sewer tap fee is imposed for all new construction or additions which require a new sewer tap within the city. The amount of such fee is set from time to time, and a schedule of such fees is on file in the municipal clerk's office. 
(d)  All owners of improved real estate using a septic tank where sanitary sewer service is available shall connect to the sewer system prior to the sale of such property. 
(e)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1994, § 22-3; Ord. No. 733, 4-16-2012) 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to require sewer connections, impose connection charges, etc., S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-2010.  
Sec. 40-3. - Connections for subdivisions. 
No subdivision or portion of a subdivision which is not a subdivision of record with streets fully constructed as of the date when the contract for the sanitary sewer system for the city is signed shall be sewered by the city. The developer or owner thereof shall be required on any such subdivision or portion of subdivision to install sewer lines within such subdivision as may be required by the city, to connect the same to each lot in such subdivision and to connect the sewer line to the city sewer system. All necessary sewer and drainage easements shall not be accepted or approved by the city until this section has been fully complied with. 
(Code 1994, § 22-4)  
Sec. 40-4. - Interfering with manhole covers; dumping trash, or other waste into manholes. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to open, move or tamper with any manhole cover of the public sewer system of the city without written permission of the city. It shall further be unlawful for any person to dump any trash, waste or other material into any manhole of the city without receiving prior approval of the city. Any person violating this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 22-5) 
Cross reference— Solid waste management, ch. 34. 
State Law reference— Interference with sewers, manholes, etc., S.C. Code 1976, §§ 5-31-20, 6-11-280.  
Sec. 40-5. - Sewer services fee. 
(a)  Every sewer user in the city, having a water tap, shall be charged an annual fee to be collected quarterly on the billing made by the Greenville Water System in accordance with the schedule for sewer services, maintenance, and operation except water meters used exclusively for landscape irrigation. The amount of such fee shall be set by city council resolution, and such schedule of fees shall be on file at the municipal clerk's office. All industrial, commercial and residential users outside the city limits utilizing city sewer lines shall be charged in accordance with the sewer service fee schedule. The revenue will go into the designated sewer fund. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided for in section 1-6. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1994, § 22-6; Ord. No. 517, § 22-6, 6-19-2000)  
Sec. 40-6. - Installation of backflow preventers. 
(a)  Any user of the city sanitary sewer system who has a private sewer service line which: 
(1)  Is below or near the level of the sewer collection line; 
(2)  Has previously back flowed or surcharged; 
(3)  Is, after study and determination by the public works department or building official, in danger of a backflow or surcharge during periods of heavy rain; or 
(4)  Is new residential construction that is either in a condition described in subsection (a)(1) or (a)(3) of this section, 
shall, after receiving written notice from the city, install, at the expense of the user, a city-approved swing check backflow preventer fixture. Such written notice may be by mail to the occupant of the property. 
(b)  Failure of the user or the person in control of the property to install the backflow preventer within 60 days thereafter shall be a violation of this section and the standard building codes. Violations will be enforced in a manner prescribed in the Code. 
(Code 1994, § 22-7)  
Sec. 40-7. - Annexation. 
(a)  Any property owner seeking sewer service from the city whose property is contiguous to the city must annex the property into the city limits before a sewer permit may be issued in the event that the mayor and council decide to annex the property. 
(b)  Any property owner seeking sewer service from the city whose property is not presently contiguous must sign appropriate documents that the property will be immediately annexed into the city when it becomes contiguous to the city limits before a sewer permit may be issued in the event that the mayor and council decide to annex the property. Sewer service to any property owner shall be terminated if the property owner refuses to annex into the city limits when the property becomes contiguous thereto. 
(Ord. No. 666, 12-17-2007)  
Secs. 40-8—40-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SEPTIC TANKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal authority to make regulations relative to septic tanks, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-2010. 
 
Sec. 40-41. - Where permitted. 
Where public sewers are inaccessible or nonexistent and construction of a multiple use sewage collection and disposal system is impracticable, a septic tank sewage system may be used for disposal of domestic waste. 
(Code 1994, § 22-31)  
Sec. 40-42. - Conditions for use. 
Septic tanks and drainfields may be used for disposal of domestic waste; provided, however, that: 
(1)  The groundwater elevation shall be at least 36 inches below the surface or not less than six inches below the bottoms of the ditches within the absorption field, whichever shall be greater. Rock formations or other impervious strata shall be at a depth greater than six feet below the surface. 
(2)  No part of a septic tank or drainfield shall be constructed within 50 horizontal feet of a private or public well or an impounded or natural body of water, including open drainage ditches. 
(3)  The area of the lot or plot of ground is of sufficient size so that no part of the disposal system will be within five feet of the building, property line or under a building, driveway or parking area. 
(4)  The soil on the lot is suitable for the proper functioning of this type of disposal system. Standard procedures shall be followed in performing percolation tests, if used to determine the suitability of the soil. 
(5)  The designed system is of adequate size, properly located on the lot. 
(Code 1994, § 22-32)  
Sec. 40-43. - Permission to construct. 
Application for permission to construct a septic tank system in the city must be made to the county health department or a duly elected or approved sanitary district commission, and approval must be secured therefrom. 
(Code 1994, § 22-33)  
Sec. 40-44. - Maintenance not to create nuisances, health hazards; permitting overflow. 
All septic tanks and drainfields shall be maintained so that they shall not constitute a nuisance or health hazard. No septic tank shall be allowed to overflow onto the surface of any property, including streets and walkways. The occupants of the premises shall be responsible under the terms of this section. Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day of violation shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1994, § 22-34)  
Sec. 40-45. - Compulsory termination of use and connection to public sewer system. 
If the building inspector determines that any septic tank in the city is not properly functioning or is inadequate, and, further, that a public sewer line is available to serve the property, the building inspector may give the owner of such property notice to discontinue the use of such septic tank and connect to the public sewer system within 30 days from such notice. 
(Code 1994, § 22-35)  
Secs. 40-46—40-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 
 
Sec. 40-81. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Proper maintenance means preventing deterioration of stormwater management systems and repairing damage or replacement of the practice if one or more of its components fail. Proper maintenance shall include, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Fertilization and management of vegetation as well as cutting or spraying with approved herbicide to remove undesirable vegetation. 
(2)  Removal of all foreign materials from systems. 
(3)  Removal of silt from the system if the design capacity is reduced by two percent. 
(4)  Repair of erosion or other damage. 
(5)  Any other item that, in the opinion of the county engineer, is detrimental to the proper functioning of the system. 
Required by the city means any stormwater management system installed by an owner or developer of any site prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy by the city. 
Stormwater management system means any system that controls the flow and/or volume of stormwater runoff. Stormwater management systems include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Detention ponds. 
(2)  Underground detention. 
(3)  Retention ponds. 
(4)  Underground retention. 
(5)  Rooftop storage. 
(6)  Parking lot storage. 
(7)  Gravel and/or grass areas designed to limit or control stormwater runoff. 
(Code 1994, § 18-66) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 40-82. - Requirements. 
The following requirements shall apply to stormwater management systems: 
(1)  Maintenance. Any stormwater management system required by the city must be properly maintained at all times by the owner. 
(2)  Modifications. No stormwater management system required by the city may be modified or altered in any way without prior written approval of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 18-67)  
Sec. 40-83. - Penalties. 
Violation of the provisions of section 40-82 shall be deemed a misdemeanor by the owner punishable, upon conviction, in accordance with section 1-6. 
(Code 1994, § 18-68)  
Chapter 42 - VEGETATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; damaging shrubbery in cemeteries, § 12-2; environment, ch. 18; parks and recreation, ch. 30; collection of tree limbs, cuttings, shrubbery and leaves, § 34-9; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 42-1. - Purpose and intent of chapter. 
The purpose and intent of this chapter is to encourage the preservation, protection and replacement of trees in open spaces within the city, and to prevent their unnecessary destruction. 
(Code 1994, § 21-1)  
Sec. 42-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Tree (except as used in section 42-5) means any woody plant which: 
(1)  Has a trunk four inches or more in diameter at four and one-half feet above the ground; or 
(2)  Is of horticultural or an ornamental variety including, but not limited to, dogwood, redbud, crab apple, buckeye or holly, and has a trunk diameter of three inches or more at one foot above the ground, or a height of eight or more feet. 
Tree protective zone means that portion of any parcel of land coinciding with the front, side and rear yard setback requirements as established by applicable city zoning ordinances. 
(Code 1994, § 21-2) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 42-3. - Application and exemption. 
This chapter shall apply to all property located within the city except as excluded by section 42-7 and this section. 
(1)  Public property shall include that property of the city, or agency thereof, including that owned entirely by such public body, or over which it holds a right-of-way or easement on any streets, roads, parks, malls or other public lands. Private property, property subject to ad valorem property taxes and all easements and rights-of-way across such property are excluded from this subsection. 
(2)  Private property shall include all other property not excluded in this chapter except it shall not include single-family lots which now exist or appear on recorded plats of subdivisions which have been approved by the necessary governmental authorities. 
(Code 1994, § 21-3)  
Sec. 42-4. - Procedures and enforcement; failure to comply. 
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. Each tree destroyed or damaged in violation of this chapter shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1994, § 21-4)  
Sec. 42-5. - Requirements. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person on public property shall: 
(1)  Damage, cut, carve, abuse or harm any tree or injure the bark. 
(2)  Pick the flowers or seeds of any tree. 
(3)  Attach any rope, wire or other contrivance to any tree unless necessary for its support. 
(b)  No person on public property under the authority of the city shall trim, spray, plant, set out or remove trees without obtaining the prior written approval from the city administrator. 
(Code 1994, § 21-5; Ord. No. 686, § 1, 1-26-2009)  
Sec. 42-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 686, § 1, adopted Jan. 26, 2009, enacted provisions which repealed former § 42-6 in its entirety, due to a conflict with the more restrictive language of § 6:17 of the zoning ordinance. Former § 42-6 pertained to approval of site plan, and derived unamended from § 21-6 of the Code of 1994.  
Sec. 42-7. - Utilities. 
Public and private utility companies shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter, provided that they file with the city administrator the policies and procedures followed in their tree trimming and removal practices and a mutually acceptable standard is agreed upon, and such utilities abide by the policies and procedures filed pursuant hereto. 
(Code 1994, § 21-7)  
Sec. 42-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 686, § 1, adopted Jan. 26, 2009, enacted provisions which repealed former § 42-8 in its entirety, due to a conflict with the more restrictive language of § 6:17 of the zoning ordinance. Former § 42-8 pertained to trees of historic value, and derived unamended from § 21-8 of the Code of 1994.  
Secs. 42-9—42-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TREE BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 696, adopted July 20, 2009, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. II, §§ 42-41—42-59, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 567, adopted Sept. 16, 2002, and Ord. No. 619, adopted Jan. 23, 2006. 
Cross reference— Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-201 et seq. 
 
Sec. 42-41. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Park trees means trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas, owned by the city, or to which the public has free access such as a park, bike, jogging, or walking trail, or small street or civic garden. 
Street trees means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 42-42. - Creation and establishment. 
There is hereby created and established a tree board for the city, which shall consist of a seven member board. Tree board members shall be citizens and residents of the city with one member being a representative from the city council. The director of parks and recreation will serve as a nonvoting ad hoc member of the board. All appointed members shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-43. - Term of office. 
The initial term of office for two members appointed to the tree board shall be for two years; the initial term of office for the other three members shall be four years. Thereafter, their term of office for the appointed tram board members shall be for four years. The city council representative term shall be an annual appointment by the mayor and approved by the city council. If a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, a successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-44. - Compensation. 
Members of the tree board or related committees shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-45. - Duties and responsibilities. 
It shall be the responsibility of the tree board to make recommendations annually for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal, or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets, bike trails, and in other public areas. The tree board, when requested by the mayor and city council, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-46. - Operation. 
The tree board shall elect all officers including chairman, vice chairman and secretary, make its own rules and regulations and keep minutes of its proceedings. All officers will have a one-year length of term with eligibility for reelection. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-47. - Street tree species to be planted. 
The following list constitutes the official street tree species of the city. No species other than those included in this list may be planted as street trees without permission of the city tree board. 
Willow Oak Quercus phellos 
Water Oak Quercus nigra 
Red Oak Quercus rubra 
Red Maple Acer rubrum 
Sugar Maple Acer saccharum 
Pecan Carya illinioensis 
Tulip-tree Liriodendron tulipifera 
Live Oak Quercus virginiana 
Southern Magnolia Magnolia grandiflora 
Laurel Oak Quercus laurifolia 
Black Walnut Juglans nigra 
Shagbark Hickory Carya ovata 
Pignut Hickory Carya glabra 
American Hornbeam Carpinus caroliniana 
Eastern Hop Hornbeam Ostrya virginiana 
American Beech Fagus grandifolia 
American Chestnut Castanea dentata 
White Oak Quercus alba 
Black Oak Quercus velutina 
Red Mulberry Morus rubra 
Black Mulberry Morus nigra 
Ginkgo Ginkgo biloba (male species only) 
Sassafras Sassafras albidum 
American Sycamore Platanus occidentalis 
London Planetree Platanus X acerifolia 
Redbay Persea borbonia 
Black Cherry Prunus serotina 
Eastern Redbud Cercis canadensis 
American Holly Ilex opaca 
Silver Maple Acer saccharinum 
Norway Maple Acer platanoides 
Planetree Maple Acer pseudoplatanus 
Horse Chestnut Aesulus hippocastanum 
Carolina Basswood Tilia caroliniana 
Flowering Dogwood Cornus florida 
Sourwood Oxydendrum arboreum 
White Ash Fraxinus americana 
Green Ash Fraxinus pennsylvanica 
Crepe Myrtle Lagerstoemia indica (red color) 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-48. - Distance from the curbs and sidewalks. 
The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks will be no closer than six feet. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 36.  
Sec. 42-49. - Distance from street and fireplugs. 
No tree shall be planted closer than 30 feet of any street corner, measured from the point of the nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No street tree shall be planted closer than eight feet of a fireplug. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-50. - Utilities. 
No street tree other than those listed may be planted under or within 15 feet of any overhead utility wire, or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 40.  
Sec. 42-51. - Public tree care. 
The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, and public ways to promote safety or preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The city tree board may remove or cause or order to be removed any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, water lines, or public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of trees is in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-52. - Tree topping. 
It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger that three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this chapter at the determination of the city tree board. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-53. - Pruning; corner clearance. 
Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of 14 feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Such owners shall remove all dead, diseased, or dangerous trees or broken or decayed limbs, which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or interferes with the visibility of any traffic control device or sign. Pruning shall conform to standards described in ANSI A-300, the American National Standards for Tree Care Operations. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-54. - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. 
The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city when such trees constitute a hazard to life or property, or harbors insects or disease which constitutes a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city will notify in writing the owners of such trees and may charge the cost of the removal on the owner's property tax notice. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-55. - Removal of stumps. 
All stumps of street trees or park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-56. - Interference with board. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay, or interfere with the city tree board, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this article. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-57. - Arborist license and bond. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business and occupation of pruning, treating, or removing street trees or park trees within the city, without first being a certified arborist by the International Society of Arboriculture in addition to any other license required by law. No certification shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. Tree care work performed by licensed, certified arborists shall follow the tree care standards described in ANSI A-300, American National Standards for Tree Care Operations, and the safety standards described in ANSI Z-133.1. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-58. - Review by the mayor and city council. 
The mayor and city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts, and decisions of the city tree board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree board to the mayor and city council who may hear the matter and make a final decision. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)  
Sec. 42-59. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any provision of the chapter shall be, upon conviction or plea of guilty, subject to a fine not to exceed $500.00 per tree. Any person who willfully and/or maliciously maims, injures, kills any street tree or park tree will be made to pay restitution, in addition to any fines or assessments for the replacement cost of the tree. 
(Ord. No. 696, 7-20-2009)

PREFACE 
    This volume is a publication of the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Mauldin, South Carolina, as adopted June 10, 1968, revised April 19, 1999, and kept current through June 2014. 
    This zoning ordinance establishes zoning regulations for the City of Mauldin, South Carolina, and provides for the administration, enforcement, and amendments thereof, and creates a board of zoning appeals in accordance with the provisions of the South Carolina Local Government Comprehensive Planning Enabling Act of 1994, S.C. Code Title 6, Chapter 29. 
    The 2014 publication was under the direct supervision of Katrina Hansen, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Kim Hamel, Director of Business and Development, for her cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that the efforts have resulted in a Code which will make the active zoning laws of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida

ARTICLE 1. - PURPOSE, AUTHORITY 

Sec. 1:1 - Purpose. 
The zoning regulations and districts as herein set forth have been made in accordance with a comprehensive plan and are designed to lessen traffic congestion; to secure safety from fire, panic, and other danger; to promote health and the general welfare; to provide adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate the adequate provisions of transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks, and other public requirements. Such regulations have been made with reasonable consideration, among other things, to the character of each district and to its peculiar suitability for particular uses, and with a view to conserving the value of buildings and encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the City of Mauldin. 
Sec. 1:2 - Authority. 
The provisions of this ordinance are adopted under authority of the South Carolina Local Government Comprehensive Planning Enabling Act of 1994, S.C. Code Title 6, Chapter 29. 
Sec. 1:3 - Jurisdiction. 
In an annexation by Petition, the Mayor and Council shall establish the initial zoning use for the newly annexed property, which shall be included in the annexation ordinance. After annexation, a property owner who desires a change in the zoning established by Mayor and Council at the time of the annexation must comply with the provisions of Section 4:1.2 of the Zoning Ordinance of the City concerning amendments to the zoning map. 
ARTICLE 2. - OFFICIAL MAP 

Sec. 2:1 - Official Zoning Map. 
The boundaries of each zoning district are shown on a map entitled Official Zoning Map, Mauldin, South Carolina, which is hereby adopted and declared to be a part of this Ordinance. 
2:1.1 Amendments. 
Amendments to the Official Zoning Map shall be made as necessary so that the map at all times portrays the current status of the zoning districts or zoning district boundaries. 
2:1.2 Custodian of Map. 
Copies of the Official Zoning Map shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk and copies shall be available at all times for inspection by the public. 
Sec. 2:2 - Interpretation of District Boundaries. 
When uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of districts as shown on the Official Zoning Map, the following rules shall apply. 
2:2.1 Delineation. 
District boundary lines are intended to follow the center lines of streets, highways, alleys, easements, and other rights-of-way; the center lines of streams or other water channels; and platted lot or other property lines. In the absence of visual district boundaries or specified distances on the Official Zoning Map, dimensions or distances shall be determined by scaling the distance on the Official Zoning Map. 
2:2.2 Interpretation. 
When the physical or cultural features existing on the ground are at variance with those shown on the Official Zoning Map, the Board of Appeals shall interpret the district boundaries. 
2:2.3 Divided Lot. 
Where a district boundary divides a lot which was in single ownership at the time of passage of this Ordinance, the Board of Appeals may permit, as a special exception, the extension of the regulations for either portion of the lot not to exceed fifty (50) feet beyond the district line into the remaining portion of the lot. 
ARTICLE 3. - ZONING DISTRICTS, GENERAL STANDARDS, DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 3:1 - Zoning Districts. 
The City of Mauldin, as now or hereafter established, is hereby divided into the following districts: 
R-20 Residential District R-15 Residential District R-12 Residential District R-10 Residential District RM-1 Mixed Residential R-M Residential, Multifamily District O-D Office District CRD Central Redevelopment District C-1 Commercial District C-2 Commercial District S-1 Services District I-1 Industrial District PD Planned Development AP Airport Protective Area POD Planned Office District  
Sec. 3:2 - General Standards. 
3:2.1 Application. 
The regulations set forth in this Ordinance affect all land, every building, and every use of land and/or buildings and shall apply as follows. 
3:2.2 New Uses or Construction. 
After the effective date of this Ordinance, any new construction or uses of land shall conform to the use and dimensional requirements for the district in which it is to be located. 
3:2.3 Open Space Requirements. 
After the effective date of this Ordinance, no part of a yard, court, or other open space, or off-street parking or loading space required for the purpose of complying with the provisions of this Ordinance, shall be included as part of a yard, open space, or parking and loading space required for any other building. 
3:2.4 Reduction of Lot and Yard Area Prohibited. 
No yard or lot existing at the time of passage of this Ordinance shall be reduced in size or area below the minimum requirements set forth herein. Yards or lots created after the effective date of this Ordinance shall meet at least the minimum requirements established herein. 
( Ord. No. 786 , amd. 7, 3-16-2015) 
Sec. 3:3 - Definitions. 
Except where specifically defined herein, all words used in this ordinance shall carry their customary meanings. Words used in the present tense include the future tense; the singular number includes the plural. The word "shall" is mandatory, not directory. 
AAN Standards. The American Standard for Nursery Stock, published by the American Association of Nurserymen (AAN), current edition. 
Abandoned sign or sign structure. A sign or sign structure which was erected on a property in conjunction with a particular use, said use having been discontinued for a period of one-hundred eighty (180) calendar days or more or a sign of which the contents pertain to a time, event, or purpose which no longer applies or which has occurred. Signs on property shall be considered abandoned when there is clear evidence that a business or activity has vacated the building or grounds. 
Accessory Apartment. A separate and complete dwelling unit that is contained on the same lot as the structure of a single-family detached dwelling or a business. 
Accessory Dwelling. A residence located on premises with a main non-residential use and occupied only by a caretaker or guard employed on the premises and, as applicable, his or her family. 
Accessory Structure. A structure that is clearly incidental and subordinate in area to a principal use and/or structure. An accessory structure shall only be permitted when it is located on a parcel that contains a principal use. 
Accessory Use. A use of land or of a building or portion thereof customarily incidental to the principal use of the land or building and located on the same lot with such principal use. For the purpose of this ordinance, accessory uses include swimming pools, game courts, and satellite dish antennas and shall meet the requirements of Section 3:10. 
Acre means forty-three thousand five hundred sixty (43,560) square feet. 
Adaptive Reuse. Refers to the process of adapting old structures for new purposes while retaining some of the architectural details that make the building unique. 
Addition. New construction involving an existing building where the gross floor area of the structure is increased or where a portion of the gross floor area is relocated. 
Adjacent. Meeting and touching at some point, or having nothing of the same kind intervening. 
Adult Day Care Center. A nonresidential facility in which custodial care is provided for adults, related or unrelated, who are in need of supervision and/or assistance with routine daily functions but who are not in need of regular medical attention, and where the adults are receiving said care on a regular and recurring basis during a part of the twelve-hour period between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., for not less than three (3) and not more than twelve (12) hours. Such a facility shall comply with all state and local codes and/or ordinances regarding zoning, building, fire, and health. Adult Day Care Center facilities located in residential districts are limited to providing care for up to sixteen (16) adults. Such a facility shall comply with all state and local codes and/or ordinances regarding zoning, building, fire, and health. 
Adult Day Care Home. A home occupation (accessory use) consisting of a private family home in which custodial care is provided for not more than five (5) adults, related or unrelated, who are in need of supervision and/or assistance with routine daily functions but who are not in need of regular medical attention, and where the adults are receiving said care on a regular and recurring basis during a part of the twelve-hour period between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., for not less than three (3) and not more than twelve (12) hours. Such a facility shall comply with all state and local codes and/or ordinances regarding zoning, building, fire, and health. 
Advertising device. Any structure or device erected or intended for the purpose of displaying advertising or for which is designed to or attracts attention to the premises, situated upon or attached to real property. For purposes of this Code Section, an advertising device is a "sign." 
A-frame Sign (also known as a Sidewalk or Sandwich Board sign). A self-supporting, portable sign with one (1) or two (2) faces that are adjoined at the top and displayed at an angle, which is not permanently anchored or secured. 
A-Frame Sign Examples:

Alteration, sign. Any change to a sign or sign structure because of construction, repair, maintenance. 
Alteration, structure. Any change, addition, or modification in construction or occupancy of an existing structure. 
Animated sign. A sign with action, motion, sound, or changing colors, which accomplishes such action, motion, sound, or changing colors with or without electrical energy. This includes signs with lights or other illuminating devices that blink, flash, fluctuate, or have a changing light intensity, brightness, or color. This definition does not include a time, date and temperature or electronic message signs as defined by this Code Section. 
Antenna. A device, dish or array used to transmit or receive telecommunications signals. 
Apartment. See "Dwelling, Multifamily." 
Approved Plant List. List of trees, shrubs, and ground covers, approved for use in the City of Mauldin for compliance with Section 6:2 and the Mauldin City Code: Chapter 21, Sections 1-8 for tree preservation and planting regulations. 
Appurtenance. An accessory, something added to the main structure or land. 
Area of sign. The area within a continuous perimeter enclosing the limits of writing, representation, emblem, figure, or character together with any frame, other material, open space, or color forming an integral part of the display or used to differentiate such writing, representation, emblem, figure, or character from the background against which it is placed. For double-faced signs, only the largest display face shall be measured in computing the sign area, or only one (1) face shall be measured in computing sign area if the display faces are the same size. The display of street address on a ground sign, wall, or window shall not be computed in determining the maximum allowable area of a ground, wall, or window sign. 
Assisted Living Facility. A structure or structures containing two (2) or more rooming units in occupancy and occupied by persons unable to live independently and may include spouses or partners (except for rooms occupied by resident staff personnel), and which provide indoor, conveniently located, shared food preparation service and major dining areas, and common recreational, social, and service facilities for the exclusive use of all the residents. Such a facility shall comply with all state and local codes and/or ordinances regarding zoning, building, fire, and health. 
Attached sign. Any sign attached to, applied on, or supported by any part of a building, including but not limited to, a wall, window, projecting sign, or a sign on a canopy or awning. 
Authorized Healthcare Provider. An individual authorized by law and currently licensed in the State of South Carolina to provide specific treatment, care, or services to residents. 
Automobile Parts Sales. A wholesale or retail store that only sells automobile parts and may not be involved in any shop-related activities such as parts rebuilding, refurbishing, or installation. 
Automobile Parts Sales and Shop. A wholesale or retail store that sells automobile parts and is involved in shop-related activities such as parts rebuilding, refurbishing, or installation. 
Automobile Salvage-wrecking yard. A lot or parcel of land on which the dismantling or wrecking of used motor vehicles or the storage, sale or dumping of dismantled or wrecked vehicles or their parts occur. The presence of two (2) or more vehicles on a parcel of land being used for nonresidential purposes which, for a period exceeding forty-five (45) days, have not been capable of operating under their own power or from which parts have been or are to be removed for reuse or sale, constitutes evidence of an automobile salvage-wrecking yard. (This definition does not include Automobile towing service uses that provide for the removal and temporary storage of functioning, inoperable or wrecked vehicles.) 
Awning. An architectural projection or shelter projecting from and supported by the exterior wall of a building and composed of a covering of rigid or non-rigid materials and/or fabric on a supporting framework that may be either permanent or retractable. 
Awning sign. An awning that contains letters, numbers, symbols, pictures, logos, or visual display, or other communication, attached, painted on, or made an integral part of an awning. For purposes of this Code Section, "awning signs" shall be considered "wall signs." 
Banner. A sign with or without characters, letters, illustrations, or ornamentation applied to cloth, paper, plastic, or natural or synthetic fabric of any kind with only such material for a backing. For purposes of this Code Section, a "banner" is a "sign." 
Bar. Any establishment including cocktail lounges, taverns, etc., however designated, whose primary function is the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises and cannot be licensed as a restaurant under state A.B.C. regulations. 
B & B. Roots of plant material which have been balled and burlapped, in accordance with AAN Standards, in preparation for delivery and transplanting. 
Berm. An earthen mound formed to shield undesirable views, decrease noise, and/or add topographical interest. The slope of a berm should not exceed a rise of one (1) foot in four (4) horizontal feet, unless approved otherwise. 
Block Face. The properties abutting on one (1) side of a street and lying between the two (2) nearest intersecting or intercepting street(s), un-subdivided land, watercourse, or city boundary. 
Example of Block Face: 

Boarding House. An establishment where the owner or manager is a full-time resident of said establishment, and which provides lodging for compensation to three (3) or more tenants; is enclosed within one (1) structure, which shall only have one (1) kitchen, a common dining room or study area, and no dining facilities or kitchens in the lodger's rooms; and where meals may be prepared or served; excludes hotels, motels, bed and breakfast homestays and inns. 
Buffer. An area of land used to separate visibly one (1) use from another or which acts as a separation between two (2) land uses of different intensity. 
Bufferyard. A linear strip of land combined with a vertical element such as plants, berms, fences, or walls, which physically separates and screens incompatible land uses. 
Building. Any structure having a roof supported by columns or walls and intended for the shelter, housing, or enclosure of any person, process, equipment, or goods. 
Building, Accessory. A structure attached to or detached from a principal building on the same lot and customarily incidental in use to the principal building. 
Building, Principal. A building in which is conducted the principal use of the lot. 
Building Setback Line. A line establishing the minimum allowable distance between the nearest portion of any building excluding steps, gutters, and similar fixtures and the property line when measured perpendicularly thereto. 
Business Signs on Vehicles. Signs displaying a business name, trademark, or other identifier shall be allowed provided they are moved periodically during the normal course of business and maintain a current and valid registration. When not in use, said vehicles are to be parked in such a manner so as to minimize their visibility from the street and other public property. 
Candela. The unit of luminous intensity equal to one-sixtieth ( 1/60 ) of the luminous intensity per square centimeter of a blackbody radiating at the temperature of solidification of platinum (2,046 degrees Kelvin) also called a candle. 
Canopy. A permanent attached structure which projects from and is supported by a building, which serves as a cover providing shelter or decoration and which extends beyond the building. 
Canopy, attached. A multi-sided structure or architectural projection supported by attachment to a building on one (1) or more sides and also supported by columns at additional points. Signs placed on attached canopies are considered "wall signs" for the purposes of this Code Section. 
Canopy, freestanding. A multi-sided structure or architectural projection supported by columns. Signs placed on freestanding canopies are considered "wall signs" for the purposes of this Code Section. 
Canopy sign. A sign on a canopy. For purposes of this Code Section, a sign on a canopy is a "wall sign" (see figure, "Types of Attached Signs"). 
Car Title Loan Business. An establishment that makes small consumer loans that leverage the equity of a car or other vehicle as collateral where the title to such vehicle is owned free and clear by the loan applicant and any existing liens on the car or vehicle cancel the application. Failure to repay the loan or make interest payments to extend the loan allows the lender to take possession of the car or vehicle. 
Catering Truck. A truck, van, or similar vehicle from which the vendor offers for sale food and beverages that are prepackaged. 
Certificate of Occupancy. A statement signed by the Zoning Administrator setting forth that the building, structure, or use complies with the Zoning Ordinance and that the same may be used for the purpose stated herein. 
Certified Treated Wood. Wood that has been treated with a permanent preservative as defined by the American Wood Preservers Association. 
Change of Use. The act of eliminating the type of land use in a structure or on a lot and replacing it with another type of land use; or the act of adding another type of land use in a building or on a lot which did not previously exist there. A change of use may or may not involve any type of new construction or building renovation. Single tenant developments where a use has ceased or is no longer in operation for a period of one hundred eighty (180) calendar days or more shall render the prior use inactive and subsequent uses of the property shall be considered as new development and reviewed, as such. Multi-tenant developments where fifty (50) percent or more of the gross floor area of a structure or lot (accommodating two (2) or more uses) has ceased or is no longer in operation for a period of one hundred eighty (180) calendar days or more shall be considered new development and reviewed as such. 
Changeable Copy. Any permanently unframed sign, illuminated or not which is principally devoted to and designed for changeable copy text and graphics, but which specifically excludes time/date/temperature signs and electronic message signs as herein defined. Changeable copy signs may involve either manual or automatic changeable copy. No changeable copy sign may have its copy changed more than two (2) times in a twenty-four-hour period. Any automatic changeable copy sign which changes more than two (2) times in a twenty-four-hour period shall be defined to be an electronic message sign. Portable or moveable signs are not considered changeable copy signs. 
Check Cashing Business. An establishment that provides one (1) or more of the following and is regulated pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 41 of Title 34 of the S.C. Code of Laws. 
A.  An amount of money that is equal to the face of the check or the amount specified in the written authorization for an electronic transfer of money, less any fee charged for the transaction; or 
B.  An agreement not to cash a check or execute an electronic transfer of money for a specified period of time; or 
C.  The cashing of checks, warrants, drafts, money orders, or other commercial paper for compensation by any person or entity for a fee. 
Child Day Care Center. A facility providing care for more than six (6) children who do not reside in the facility, are present primarily during daytime hours, do not regularly stay overnight, and that may include some instruction. Such a facility shall comply with all state and local codes and/or ordinances regarding zoning, building, fire, and health. 
Child Day Care Home. A home occupation (accessory use) in which a permanent occupant of the dwelling provides for the care of up to six (6) children. Those receiving care are not all related to the occupant or to each other by blood or marriage and are not the legal wards or foster children of the attendant adults. Those receiving care and who are not dependents of the occupant do not reside on the site. Such a facility shall comply with all state and local codes and/or ordinances regarding zoning, building, fire, and health. 
Civic Event. An event sponsored by government organization. 
City Sponsored event means that the city, solely or in partnership with another entity, produces and/or coordinates the event. 
Cluster Subdivision. A form of residential subdivision that permits housing units to be grouped on sites or lots with dimensions, frontages, and setbacks reduced from conventional sizes, provided the density of the tract as a whole shall not exceed the density allowed by the zoning district under existing regulations and the remaining land area is devoted to common open space. 
Commissary. A commissary is defined as a permitted fixed food establishment that serves as an operating base for a mobile food vehicle. The commissary is where the vehicle will be stored, parked, serviced, cleaned, supplied, and maintained. 
Common Open Space. Land and/or water within or related to a cluster residential development, not individually owned, which is designed and intended for the common use or enjoyment of the residents of the development, or the public, which may contain such accessory structures and improvements as are necessary and appropriate for passive recreational purposes and utilities. A condition of the cluster residential development approval shall be that common open space may not be further subdivided. 
Communications Tower. A tower, pole, or similar structure of any size which supports communications (broadcast or receiving) equipment utilized by commercial, governmental, or other public and quasi-public users above ground in a fixed location, freestanding, guyed, or on a building. This does not include private home use of satellite dishes and television antennas or amateur radio operators as licensed by the Federal Communications Commission. 
Conforming sign. A sign that is legally installed and is in compliance with all applicable local laws and ordinances. 
Construction. The erection of any on-site improvements on any parcel of ground whether the site is presently improved, unimproved or becomes unimproved by demolition, destruction of the improvements located thereon by fire, windstorm or other casualty. 
Construction Sign. A sign whose message is limited to identification of architects, engineers, contractors, and other persons involved with the construction project or to the name of the building being constructed, the intended purpose of the building and the expected completion date. 
Convenience Store. Any retail establishment offering for sale prepackaged food products, household items, and similar products, which meet the convenience shopping needs of its patrons. These establishments may or may not offer gasoline for sale; however, they do not offer any automobile maintenance services or repair. 
Critical root zone. The minimum area beneath a tree which must be left undisturbed and protected from construction disturbance in order to preserve a sufficient root mass to give a tree a reasonable chance of survival. The critical root zone is delineated by a concentric circle with the tree trunk as the center. The radius of the critical root zone equals one (1) foot for every one (1) inch of tree diameter. Example: a twenty-inch diameter tree will have a critical root zone radius of twenty (20) feet. 
Cutoff Fixture. An outdoor lighting fixture shielded or constructed in such a manner that no more than two and one-half (21/2) percent of the total light emitted by the fixture is projected above the horizontal plane of the fixture. 
Debt Relief Company. Any establishment that advertises and/or promises to reduce unsecured debt through settlement and accepts any funds, payments or fees in advance of said settlement.
