9:1.5 Prohibited Temporary Uses. 
A.  Retail sales or display of goods, products, or services are prohibited from being located in a public right-of-way except when the sale of goods are part of an authorized and permitted Temporary event where the event requires the closing of streets. 
B.  Substantial permanent changes to a development site to specifically accommodate a temporary use or activity is prohibited. 
9:1.6 General Provisions. 
Compliance with the following general provisions is required for all temporary uses unless otherwise specified. 
A.  Parking, Accessibility and Traffic Control. Off-street parking shall be provided in accordance with Section 6:1.1.6, Minimum Parking Requirements, and 6:1.1.7, Additional Requirements for the Physically Disabled and/or Handicapped. Parking must be located on the site where the temporary use is proposed and shall accommodate the temporary use(s), and existing use(s), if applicable. 
B.  Signs. Unless specifically addressed otherwise in this subsection, signage used for a temporary use shall be in accordance with Section 6:4.1.12.B(6), Temporary Signs. A sign permit must be obtained prior to display. 
C.  Lighting. Site lighting shall be in accordance with Section 6:3, Lighting Standards. 
D.  Impacts. Temporary uses and their associated functions will be closely evaluated to ensure that adjacent and/or adjoining properties are not negatively affected; and that the use will not create hazardous vehicular or pedestrian traffic conditions. The Business and Development Services Director shall have the authority to impose additional requirements to mitigate potential negative impacts, including but not limited to: locating event staging areas, noise control, setbacks, screening, and temporary traffic control devices to minimize congestion. 
E.  Adequate Facilities. Sanitary sewer, utilities, drainage, refuse management and any other facilities deemed necessary by the City to protect the public's health, safety and welfare must be provided on site and made accessible to employees, patrons and/or participants. 
F.  Setbacks. Temporary uses, and associated structures and functions shall not be located in any required building setback, landscape buffer, street tree planting strip, or any other landscaped areas required under this chapter. In no case, shall a temporary display or structure be located within fifteen (15) feet of the street right-of-way nor interfere with site visibility at ingress/egress points onto the property. 
G.  Presence of another use. A temporary use may be located on a property housing a a permanent use or may be located on a vacant lot as long as the site is determined to be fully compliant with the State adopted accessibility standards and any other requirements the City deems necessary to ensure public heath, safety and welfare. The location of the temporary use shall not violate any requirements placed on any permanent use. 
H.  Other permits, licenses, inspections. These regulations do not exempt the operator from obtaining any other required permits or inspections such as, but not limited to, building and fire permits; issuance of a city business license, State permits, and Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC). A City business license shall not be issued until an approved temporary use permit is obtained. 
I.  Discontinuation of use. All materials, structures, and products related to the temporary use must be removed from the premises between days of operation on the site, provided that materials, structures and products related to the temporary use may be left on-site overnight between consecutive days of operation. Each site occupied by a temporary use shall be left free of debris, litter, or other evidence of the temporary use upon completion or removal of the use. 
9:1.7 Temporary Uses and Associated Structures Exempt from obtaining a Permit. 
Unless otherwise stipulated in this article, the following uses and/or associated structures shall be permitted in all zoning districts; and do not require the issuance of a zoning or temporary use permit. Such uses, however, shall conform to the general provision requirements set forth in subsection 9:1.6 General Provisions, the requirements set forth below in Section 9:1.7; and any other applicable permitting and licensing requirements of the City of Mauldin. While a zoning permit or temporary use permit is not required for the following uses, a City building and/or fire permit may be required for temporary structures and/or tents. 
A.  City (co) sponsored events and/or other authorized events located on city-owned property are reviewed and approved through a separate City process. 
B.  Construction Related Structures (containers) that are located within the area or parcel of an approved development plan that is under construction shall be allowed without a separate temporary use or zoning permit but may require a building permit. Said structure(s) may be utilized for the duration of the building permit and shall be removed within thirty (30) days following the issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy or Certificate of Completion. 
C.  Fundraising (non-commercial, not for profit) events are only permitted in non-residential districts and/or on property occupied by a public or institutional use in residential districts. If a fundraising event is specifically listed as a temporary use in subsections 9:1.8, 9:1.9 below, then the provisions of that subsection shall apply. Except as specifically permitted as follows, a fundraising event shall be permitted for no more than three (3) consecutive days. 
D.  Garage/Yard Sales, Residential are permitted in all residential districts but must be located on a parcel containing a dwelling unit(s) and/or on a parcel occupied by an approved non-residential or institutional use. Sales are permitted on any parcel for a total of thirty (30) days per calendar year. The maximum duration for each occurrence is three (3) days. Garage and Yard sales signs are subject to the provisions outlined in Signs, subsection 6:4.1.8. 
E.  Intermittent Food Sales: a vendor and/or mobile food unit that does not sit idle for more than fifteen (15) minutes at any one (1) place shall be permitted in all districts with a valid mobile food vendor decal and City Business License. Intermittent Food Sales located on permitted and active construction sites shall not exceed two (2) hours in duration at any given site and shall exempt from the separation requirements of subsections 9.1.10-A(8) and 9.1.10-B(2) of this Article. 
F.  Outdoor retail sales that are located on the same lot as the merchant's principal use and where no structure is erected in conjunction with a sale are permitted in all nonresidential districts for a maximum of sixty (60) days per calendar year. When such use is located on an internal sidewalk, a minimum of five (5) feet must remain unobstructed so as not to block or interfere with State adopted accessibility requirements and/or pedestrian movement. 
G.  Private, non-commercial events on private property and evangelistic, religious events and services are permitted in all districts without a temporary use permit for events with a duration of one (1) day or less. Exception: A temporary use permit shall be required for multi-day events, when the event attendance is expected to exceed one hundred (100) patrons or more, and/or if mobile food sales are provided. Such events are limited to eight (8) hours in duration, up to six (6) times a year. 
H.  Reserved. 
I.  Storage Containers, Portable on demand, Residential Use. Portable, on demand storage containers are allowed in all zoning districts and shall be subject to the following standards: 
1)  One (1) storage container shall be allowed on a property containing a residential use. Such containers shall not be permitted on any lot that does not contain a principal building. 
2)  To the maximum extent practicable, storage and/or portable on demand containers shall not be located in the front yard. When such structure requires location in the front yard, a Temporary Use permit shall be required. 
3)  Such structures and/or containers shall be setback from all street rights-of-way a minimum of twenty (20) feet and located a minimum of ten (10) feet from side and rear lot lines. 
4)  When located on a property containing a residential use, the unit shall be used only for temporary incidental residential accessory use purposes; it shall not be used for any non-residential purposes or storage nor shall it be used in conjunction with a home occupation. 
5)  No utility shall be connected to the unit. 
6)  No unit shall remain in place longer than thirty (30) days without the issuance of a Temporary Use permit. The Business and Development Services Director may extend the use in thirty-day increments but in no case shall a unit remain in place more than one hundred twenty (120) days in any twelve-month period. 
7)  The Business and Development Services Director shall have the authority to modify the standards of Subsection 9.1.7.I, in the event of a natural or manmade disaster and when there is an active permit on site for repair or reconstruction. 
9:1.8 Short-term Temporary Events. 
Short-term temporary events shall conform to the general provision requirements set forth in subsection 9:1.6 General Provisions, the requirements set forth below in Section 9:1.8; and any other applicable permitting and licensing requirements of the City of Mauldin. Unless otherwise specified, short-term events are only permitted in non-residential districts. 
A.  Permit Required. All short-term temporary events must obtain a Temporary Use permit as set forth in subsection 9:1.11 below. The approved permit must be displayed on the permises at all times when the temporary event is in operation. 
B.  Duration. Except as specifically provided for elsewhere in this section, a short-term events shall be permitted for a period not to exceed four (4) times a year and a maximum duration of fourteen (14) days per event in any given calendar year. The dates of operation must be listed on the permit. A day in operation shall mean any or part of any day on which the use is conducted. 
C.  Limitation on permits. Only one (1) temporary use permit shall be active on any lot or parcel at any given time. An exception to this limitation shall be allowed with written consent from the property/land owner and a staff review of a site plan that shows that the temporary event does not affect the operation of the site nor cause the property to be in violation with local and/or state ordinances. 
D.  Additional standard for specific uses. In addition to the general requirements for temporary uses/structures set forth in subsection 9:1.6 above, the following temporary uses shall comply with the following: 
1)  Seasonal Sales. Seasonal sales, including the sale of such items as Christmas trees and pumpkins, seasonal produce, and other similar agricultural products may be permitted in all non-residential districts or on residentially zoned parcels occupied by a public and/or an approved institutional use subject to the following time limits in Table TU-2 below: 
TABLE TU-2: SEASONAL SALE EVENTS Pumpkin sales 45 days per calendar year Christmas tree sales 60 days calendar days per year Garden sales 60 days per event; two times per year Produce Stands/Farmers Market 180 days per calendar year Ice cream/frozen treat stands 180 days per calendar year  
9:1.9 Interim Temporary Uses/Structures. 
An interim temporary use/structure is use (and structure containing a use) which is located on a property often for periods exceeding one hundred twenty (120) days due to the nature of the use. Such uses are subject to the standards in this section and in subsection 9:1.6, General Provisions and are only permitted in nonresidential districts and on property occupied by an institutional use in residential districts. 
A.  Temporary Facilities (Factory fabricated building) for Expansion or Replacement of Existing Facilities for schools, churches and other institutional uses. Factory fabricated transportable buildings that are designed to arrive at the site ready for occupancy (except for minor unpacking and connection to utilities) and designed for relocation to other sites, may be permitted as follows: 
1)  Duration. The time period shall not exceed a maximum of two (2) years and/or the duration of an active Building permit that has been issued for the expansion or replacement for which the temporary facility is needed. This period may be extended for an additional twelve-month period for good cause shown upon approval of a written request for such an extension by the Zoning Administrator. The request shall be submitted to the Zoning Administrator at least thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the permit. With exception to public schools, in no event shall the extension allow the temporary structures to remain on the site for more than three (3) years. 
2)  Location. Such structures shall comply with the setback requirements as defined by the applicable zoning district. In addition, structures shall not be located within existing vegetated buffers or other areas designated on the site plan to remain free from land disturbance. 
3)  Other requirements. 
a.  The temporary structure shall be either a modular building unit or a building constructed to the standards of the SC State Building Code. 
b.  Underpinning, skirting, or other curtain wall material shall be installed. 
c.  All permits required by applicable building, electrical, plumbing, and mechanical codes shall be obtained prior to installation of the temporary structure. 
d.  The temporary structure shall be compatible with the existing building on the site in terms of exterior color. 
e.  A sketch plan containing sufficient information to show compliance with the above standards shall be submitted and approved prior to installation of the temporary structure. 
B.  Construction related activities/structures located on an adjacent site. Because of site constraints, construction related activities might need to occur on a site that is adjacent to or nearby the construction site. Such uses shall be removed and the site restored to its previous condition within thirty (30) days after the issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy or Certificate of Completion. 
C.  Real estate sales and/or model home offices. Temporary facilities used as sales/ leasing offices, including those located in a model unit of a residential project or used during construction to expand or replace a permanent building, may be permitted on the same site as the permanent use. Sales offices may be established for pre-sales or leasing prior to construction of the project. 
1)  Duration. Real estate sales and/or model home offices may be approved for a period of up to three (3) years. This period may be renewed for an addition twelve-month period for good cause shown upon approval of a written request for such an extension by the Zoning Administrator. The request shall be submitted to the Zoning Administrator at least thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the permit. Such uses shall be removed and the site restored to its previous condition within thirty (30) days after the issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy or Certificate of Completion. 
2)  There is no time limit on the use of model sales units for rental housing. 
9:1.10 Temporary Mobile Food Sales (including Catering trucks, food trailers, food and ice cream trucks). 
A.  Specific Requirements for Temporary Mobile Food Sales. Unless otherwise stated, all Temporary Mobile Food Sale uses shall be subject to the General Provisions of subsection 9:1.6 and the following requirements: 
1)  Commissary. Mobile food vendors are required to have a DHEC-approved commissary. Mobile food vendors must report to their commissary at least once every twenty-four (24) hours for cleaning, restocking and general maintenance of their vehicle(s), equipment, and products. Every mobile food vendor shall keep and post in the vehicle a log of regular weekly inspections of the vendor's vehicle(s) and equipment so as to ensure proper repair and sanitary conditions at all times. 
2)  General Maintenance. Mobile food vendor vehicles must keep their vehicle(s) in good, working order. This includes, but is not limited to, keeping vehicle(s) free of excessive wear or damage including dents, rust, and abrasions; maintaining exterior paint so as not to allow excessive chipping, cracking or fading; and replacing any windows with noticeable cracks, dents or scratches that may cause a hazard or reduced clarity of vision below a level specified by manufacturer. 
3)  Goods for Sale. Mobile food vendors shall be limited to edibles and hot and cold beverages containing no alcohol. The selling of non-food or non-drink items shall be limited to merchandise displaying the mobile food vendor's company logo and/or branding. No items for sale may be displayed outside of the vehicle. Ice-cream trucks are allowed in all residential zones, but may only operate for less than thirty (30) minutes in one (1) location, must remain mobile, and only use sound-producing equipment to announce their arrival for no more than five (5) minutes. 
4)  Inspections. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as limiting or replacing the role of the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC), which has the primary task of inspecting mobile food vendors. The city inspector, or their agents, shall have the right, at any time, after displaying proper identification, to enter into or upon any mobile food vendor vehicle for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not any of the provisions of this division are being violated. Any mobile food vendor vehicle which is found, after any city or state inspection, to be unsafe or in anyway not compliant with this chapter or other applicable laws and ordinance may be directed to be out of operation until the cited deficiency is corrected. 
5)  License. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a mobile food vendor within the city without first obtaining a City of Mauldin Business License, Temporary Use permit, and a Mobile Food Vendor Decal. Upon being granted a business license, mobile food vendor decal, and temporary use permit the vendor must comply with the affirmative mandates and must not violate the prohibitions regarding sales, operations, locations, and restrictions contained in this chapter. The failure to do so may result in the revocation or suspension of the business license, applicable permits and decal. 
6)  Noise. Mobile food vendors, their vehicle(s) and their customers shall not cause any public disturbance through noise caused either by the operation of a vehicle or their public interactions. No mobile food vendor may use a public address system, speaker system, or any other device that produces a loud noise to attract customers or advertise products. Mobile food vendors are subject to compliance with the City of Mauldin Noise Ordinance. 
7)  Power and Water. Mobile food vendor vehicles must be self-contained and not require any outside power or water source. Mobile food vendors may utilize power and water if provided to them with written permission granted from the property owner of the site at which the mobile food vendor is located. 
8)  Proximity to Restaurants and other eating establishments. Unless approved as an intermittent food vendor per subsection 9:1.7E and/or part of a city (co) sponsored event and/or located on city owned property, mobile food vendor vehicles shall not operate or be located within two hundred fifty (250) feet of a lawful eating establishment during the establishment's normal operating hours. This requirement may be waived if the mobile food vendor provides written documentation, signed by the establishment's owner, that the owner has no objection to a closer proximity. If a new, lawful eating establishment opens within two hundred fifty (250) feet of a permitted mobile food vendor's location, the mobile food vendor may remain at that location until the permit expires. 
9)  Recycling. Mobile food vendors are encouraged to use recyclable materials for the serving of their food products, and shall provide adequate recycling receptacles for the disposal of those products. 
10)  Restrooms. Mobile food vendor vehicles must be located within three hundred (300) feet of a restroom available to employees and customers. Written permission of use of private restrooms located near public property is allowed but must be included in the permit application outside of those hours. 
11)  Spacing. When multiple mobile food vendor vehicles have been approved to locate on the same property, there should be no less than twenty (20) feet between each vehicle to allow for easy passage by customers. No mobile food vendor vehicle shall impede pedestrian traffic, emergency vehicle passage, or block any private entrances and/or exits, sidewalks, or pedestrian entrances and exits. 
12)  Streets. Mobile food vendors may not conduct business on public streets, in city-owned rights-of-way, or positioned in areas causing customers to be within twenty (20) feet of a public street. In the event a mobile food vendor is a part of an approved special event that requires the closing of streets, the mobile food vendor may conduct business in the closed street as a part of the event. 
13)  Trash. Every mobile food vendor must supply adequate trash receptacles for use by customers during operations. Each mobile food vendor shall pick up any and all litter resulting from their operations in the vicinity of their vehicle(s) and dispose of any and all waste in a street trash receptacle, dumpster, or other large capacity waste receptacle. Mobile food vendors must have permission to dump waste into a private receptacle. 
14)  Zoning Restrictions. Food Trucks, Food Trailers, and Mobile Markets are restricted from operating on private property located in areas zoned "Residential", unless approved and permitted as part of a temporary private, non-commercial neighborhood event or residential properties occupied by a permitted institutional or public use, or as authorized under a separate provision of this ordinance. 
B.  Temporary Mobile Food Sales on Private Property. Mobile food sales are permitted in all non-residential districts with an approved temporary use permit provided that the use/structure/vehicle for mobile food sales is compliant with the General Provisions outlined in subsection 9:1.6, Specific Requirements in subsection 9:1.10 above and the following standards: 
1)  Permit Required. All mobile food vendors must obtain a temporary use permit and vendor decal both of which are to be displayed at all times on the premises where the temporary use is in operation. Existing eating establishments with mobile food vending facilities located on-site shall be exempt from obtaining a temporary use permit when mobile food vending sales occur on the same property as the existing eating establishment. 
2)  Restrictions. Mobile Food Sales shall not be located within two hundred (200) feet of a residential use and/or within two hundred fifty (250) feet of a lawful eating establishment during the establishment's normal operating hours unless operating as an intermittent food vendor per subsection 9:1.7E, or part of a city (co) sponsored event and/or located on city owned property, or permitted as part of a temporary private, non-commercial neighborhood event or residential properties occupied by a permitted institutional or public use, or as authorized under a separate provision of this ordinance. 
3)  Duration. A Temporary Use permit for Mobile Food Sales shall be permitted for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days in any calendar year. The day(s) of operation must be listed on the permit. A day in operation shall mean any or part of any day on which the use is conducted. 
4)  Hours of Operation. Temporary Mobile Food Sales shall be permitted to operate from 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m., or 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. when located within two hundred fifty (250) feet of a residential use. 
5)  Location. Temporary Mobile Food Sales may be located on vacant, undeveloped and/or existing developed properties with written consent from the property owner(s). Such consent must be provided with the Temporary Use Permit application. Multiple vendors may be approved on vacant and/or undeveloped parcels with review and approval of an approved site plan. 
6)  Proximity to public right-of way. All structures and sales shall be conducted at least fifteen (15) feet from all public rights-of-way. 
7)  Structures and Signs. Mobile food vendors are restricted from placing tables, chairs, tents, or other structures outside of their vehicle. This excludes tables used for menus and condiments. Mobile food vendors may not display signage outside of their vehicle with the exception of an A-frame menu board advertising the menu for the mobile food vendor. A-frame menu boards shall be limited to a sign face area of twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches and shall not exceed four (4) feet in height. 
8)  Site Plan. Mobile food vendors and/or private property owners must submit a site plan detailing the property location, layout of the mobile food vendor vehicle(s) on the site, and distance(s) (setback) from all street rights-of way. When located on a developed/active parcel, a complete site layout is required illustrating existing buildings, setbacks, parking, and loading and vehicular use areas. 
C.  Temporary Mobile Food Sales on Public Property. Mobile food sales may be permitted to operate on public property with an approved temporary use permit provided that the use/structure/vehicle for mobile food sales is compliant with the General Provisions outlined in subsection 9:1.6, Specific Requirements in subsection 9:1.10 above and the following standards: 
1)  Permit Required. All mobile food vendors must obtain a temporary use permit and vendor decal both of which are to be displayed at all times on the premises where the temporary use is in operation. 
2)  Insurance. At the time of application for a business license, the mobile food vendor must provide proof of general liability insurance for operation of the vehicle as a motor vehicle and the conduct of the business if the business is to be conducted on public streets or city owned property in amounts reasonably determined by the city in consultation with its risk manager. Failure to maintain this insurance will result in immediate revocation of the license. 
3)  Restrictions. Mobile food vendors shall not operate on public property that is within two hundred fifty (250) feet of a public fair, festival or event also located on public property, unless they are a part of the specified festival, fair or event, at which point they are confined to the approved area of the special event only. 
4)  Duration. A Temporary Use permit for Mobile Food Sales shall be permitted for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days in any calendar year. The days of operation must be listed on the permit. A day in operation shall mean any or part of any day on which the use is conducted. 
5)  Hours of Operation. Temporary Mobile Food Sales shall be permitted to operate from 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m., or 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. when located within three hundred (300) feet of a residential use. A mobile food vendor vehicle is limited to six (6) hours of operation in a specified public area per day. 
6)  Location, City Owned Properties. Temporary Mobile Food Sales may operate on the following city owned properties: Mauldin Cultural Center, Mauldin City Hall, Mauldin Senior Center, and all city-owned parks and/or green spaces. An approved temporary use permit is required for operation in these locations specifying the date(s), time(s) and nature of operation. The city reserves the right to limit the number of permits issued for a specific site during a specific time frame, restrict the exact placement of mobile food vendors/vehicles on approved site(s), and place additional restrictions as needed for operations located on public property. Mobile Food Vendors located on City owned properties shall not be subject to the separation requirements from residential uses and/or eating establishments. 
7)  Location, Schools. Mobile food vendors are restricted from school property between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. unless written permission signed by the principal and/or other authorized school official is submitted with the Temporary Use permit application. 
8)  Proximity to public right-of way. All structures and sales shall be conducted at least fifteen (15) feet from all public rights-of-way. 
D.  Temporary Mobile Food Sales, Special Events. Mobile food vendors with their base operations located outside the Mauldin City Limits and participating in an approved Special Event are not required to apply for a separate temporary use permit or Mobile Food Vendor decal provided that the Special Event has included mobile food vending sales in their site plan and has met all requirements. Operation of a mobile food sale/vendor/vehicle during a Special Event is restricted to the hours of the Special Event and the boundaries of the Special Event. All mobile food vendors involved in a Special Event must possess, and display, appropriate and valid SC DHEC inspection papers at all times during the Special Event. 
E.  Additional Permit Requirements. In addition to compliance with the Temporary Use permit requirements outlined in subsection 9:1.11 below, mobile food vendors shall file for a Mobile Vendor Decal permit with the City of Mauldin's Business and Development Services Department. 
1)  The applicant shall provide the following information (one (1) permit application is required for each mobile food vendor vehicle): 
a.  Name and description of applicant, business and goods to be sold. 
b.  Name, address and contact number of Commissary. 
c.  A color photograph of the applicant taken within thirty (30) days prior to the date of filing. 
d.  A ten-year background check as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any criminal offense, other than a moving violation, and the punishment or penalty assessed therefore. 
e.  A ten-year driving record. Certified by the SC Department of Transportation or the comparable agency of any state in which the applicant has lived in the past ten (10) years. 
f.  A copy of the vehicles registration and insurance. 
g.  Color photographs of the vehicle's interior, exterior, equipment and set up. 
h.  Such other relevant information as maybe required by the City in order to assure a full review of information needed to assess the impact of the proposed operation on the health, safety and well-being of the public. 
2)  Upon being issued a Temporary Use permit, each mobile food vendor applicant will receive a mobile food vendor window decal, which must be displayed prominently on the front or driver's side window of the mobile food vendor vehicle. Decals are valid January 1 until December 31 each year after which a new decal, permit application, and payment of applicable fees are required. 
3)  Each mobile vendor decal permit issued by the City shall contain the signature and seal of the Zoning Administrator and shall show the permittee's name and address, a license plate tag number of the vehicle used, the kind of goods to be sold, the decal permit number, date of issuance, and the length of time the permit shall be valid. 
4)  The permit and decal are issued to a specific mobile food vendor for a specific mobile food vendor vehicle. No mobile food vendor shall transfer a permit or decal to another vehicle owned or controlled by the same mobile food vendor. In the event the mobile food vendor acquires during a calendar year a replacement vehicle to serve the same purpose as the vehicle for which the city issued a permit and decal, then a replacement permit and decal shall be issued and the original permit and decal shall become null and void, and must be returned to the city prior to the issuance of replacements. 
5)  Mobile Food Vendors shall be responsible for Business License fees and Hospitality Taxes as required by the City of Mauldin. 
9:1.11 Administration and Temporary Use permit procedures. 
To ensure that proposed Temporary uses comply with the requirements of this chapter, no use that is classified as a temporary use shall be placed or established on the property without first receiving a temporary use permit. An application for a Temporary Use Permit shall be filed with the City of Mauldin's Business and Development Services Department on an application form provided by the office. 
A.  Applicant. Temporary Use permit application may be filed by the owner of the property or by an agent specifically authorized by the owner to file such application. Where an agent filed the application, the agent shall provide written documentation that the owner of the property has authorized the filing of the application. 
B.  Information Required. Each application for temporary use permit shall contain the information required on the application form. The application shall be accompanied by a sketch plan showing the boundaries of the property, the use of adjacent properties, the location of the temporary use or structure on the property, access and parking provisions, restroom facilities, and other information sufficient to show that the temporary use/structure complies with the standards set forth in this chapter. 
C.  Restrictive Covenants. It shall be the sole responsibility of the owner and/or applicant to ensure that all proposed temporary uses and activities requiring a city permit are in compliance with any existing lawful restrictive covenant. In the event a permit is issued and a conflict between the restrictive covenant and the issuance of the permit is determined, the more restrictive requirement of the two (2) shall prevail. 
D.  Fees. An application fee as determined by the City of Mauldin Permit Fee Schedule shall be due and payable when the application is submitted. Uses established without an approved permit shall be subject to a penalty fee. 
E.  Staff Review and Issuance. Provided the application is complete, staff shall have ten (10) business days to review the application for compliance with the provisions of this ordinance. In addition to a Temporary Use permit, certain structures may require building and/or fire permits. In the event a Building or Fire permit is required, the Temporary Use permit shall be held until all such permits have been approved. 
F.  Permit Validity. The Temporary Use permit shall be valid for the time period stated on the permit. 
G.  Appeals. Appeals of the decision of the Zoning Administrator shall be heard by the Zoning Board of Appeals and subject to the provisions set forth in subsection 4:1.7 of this ordinance. 
H.  Public Emergencies. In the event of a natural disaster, catastrophic even or public emergency the City Administrator or his/her designee may waive any temporary use permit procedures and authorize the placement of temporary use facilities that are deemed necessary or desirable in conjunction with the management of the emergency. 
( Ord. No. 782 , amd. 1, 12-15-2014; Ord. No. 815 , amd. 2, 2-20-2017) 
ARTICLE 10. - CONDITIONAL USES 
Conditional uses are uses that are generally compatible with the other uses that are permitted in a particular zoning district but require a closer evaluation on the location, characteristics, configuration, and intensity of the use. The following standards and criteria are over and above those set forth elsewhere in this Ordinance; and are imposed herein on all such conditional uses, listed below to enhance land use compatibility. 
( Ord. No. 786 , amd. 5, 3-16-2015) 
Editor's note- At the discretion of the editor, and in order to maintain the Code format, sections have been added. 

Sec. 10:1 - Accessory Apartment: R-10, R-8, and R-6, RM-1, RM Districts. 
1.  An accessory apartment may be attached, within an existing single-family dwelling, or housed in an approved accessory structure that is located in the rear yard and is not located closer than five (5) feet of an adjacent or neighboring property line. 
2.  An accessory apartment shall only be permitted on a lot that is owner occupied and contains a detached single family dwelling unit. 
3.  No more than one (1) accessory dwelling unit shall be permitted on a single deeded lot in conjunction with the principal dwelling unit. 
4.  The accessory dwelling unit shall not be served by a driveway separate from that serving the principal dwelling unless the accessory dwelling is accessed from a rear alley and the principal dwelling is accessed from a street. 
5.  Accessory apartments shall not be considered as an additional dwelling unit for the purpose of determining minimum lot size or maximum density. 
6.  The gross floor area of the accessory apartment housed within an existing single-family dwelling shall not exceed five hundred (500) square feet or contain no more than twenty-five (25) percent of the gross floor area of the principal single-family dwelling, whichever is greater. When housed within an accessory structure, the size of an accessory apartment shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of the gross floor area of a principal dwelling unit on the property (for example, establishment of a five hundred (500) square foot accessory apartment would require the principal dwelling unit to be at least one thousand (1,000) square feet in size.) 
7.  Accessory dwelling units shall not be sold apart from the principal dwelling unit upon the same lot where it is located. 
8.  Accessory dwelling units shall not be leased or rented for tenancies of less than thirty (30) calendar days or leased to more than eleven (11) different individuals in any calendar year. 
9.  Home Occupations shall be prohibited from operating within an accessory dwelling unit. 
( Ord. No. 786 , amd. 5, 3-16-2015) 
Sec. 10:2 - Accessory Structures: All Residential Districts. 
1.  Location: Accessory Structures (except for detached garages) shall only be located in a side or rear yard and shall not be located to project beyond the front building line of the principal structure. 
2.  Setback: Except for fences, and/or walls erected on a property line, accessory structures shall be setback a minimum of five (5) feet from all adjacent and/or neighboring property lines. 
3.  Detached Garages/Carports: Detached garages shall only be permitted in front of the principal structure if the garage/carport is not located within the front setback; and the structure is located and/or designed so that it is clearly subordinate to the principal structure in terms of scale. A garage accessed from an alley shall have a minimum rear setback of at least twenty (20) feet from the rear property line. 
4.  Size: The maximum floor area of all residential accessory structures contained on a site shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of the total gross floor area of the principal structure. 
5.  Height: Accessory structures located in a residential district shall comply with the height standards set forth for the district, and in no case shall exceed the height of the principal structure. 
6.  Common Facilities: Accessory structures providing common facilities for residential developments (clubhouse, pool house, etc.) shall not be subject to the gross floor area limitations or location requirements set forth in this subsection. 
7.  Non-residential: Accessory structures for non-residential uses that are permitted in a residential zoning district shall not encroach into any required setback and shall be screened from the view of adjacent residential uses with a fifteen-foot landscape buffer that shall consist of a mix of evergreen trees and shrubs that will be provide a year round visual screen. 
( Ord. No. 786 , amd. 5, 3-16-2015) 
Sec. 10:3 - Adult Care Center-RM-1, and RM residential districts; all Commercial Districts (excluding I-1 District). 
1.  The minimum lot area requirement for an Adult Care Center shall be 30,000 square feet. 
2.  No structure shall be located closer than twenty-five (25) feet to an exterior property line, and no structure shall be located closer than thirty-five (35) feet to a public right-of-way. Interior setbacks are not regulated. 
3.  The structure shall have a residential appearance. 
4.  When located in a residential district, the maximum number of adults to be cared for shall be limited to sixteen (16). 
5.  Off street parking shall be provided at the rate of: One (1) space per staff person and consultative person expected on the premises at any one (1) time, plus one (1) space for each six (6) adults permitted. 
6.  Safe and adequate provisions shall be provided on-site to accommodate all drop-off and pick up activities, ensuring a safe route from motor vehicle to the building entrance. 
7.  Adult daycare centers located in a designated residential district are limited to those following the social (non-medical) model of care for individuals who need supervision and activities but not extensive personal care or medical monitoring. 
8.  Each daycare facility shall provide forty (40) square feet of available activity space per participant, inside the center, not including offices, bathrooms, kitchens, closets, vestibules, and private living space; and also provide a minimum outdoor recreation area of fifty (50) square feet per participant outside of the center. The outdoor space shall afford adequate facilities such as decks, patios, and manicured lawn areas in a manner that allows participants safe access and enjoyment outside. 
9.  A fifteen-foot landscape buffer shall be provided and maintained along all exterior property lines that abut a residential use. The landscape buffer shall consist of a mix of evergreen trees and shrubs that will be provide a year round visual screen. 
10.  Except as may otherwise be required by state or federal law, nothing herein shall allow or authorize the use of any daycare facility as: 
a)  A public or private hospital, retreat, institution, community residence, house or place where a mentally ill person, or a person who is alcoholic dependent or drug-dependent is received or detained as a patient or for treatment or rehabilitation; or 
b)  A community residence, halfway house, transitional house or other state or federally regulated facility to which persons are or may be transferred from correctional facilities or institutions. 
( Ord. No. 786 , amd. 5, 3-16-2015) 
Sec. 10:4 - Adult Day Care Home-All residential districts. 
Shall be required to obtain a Home Occupation permit and shall be subject to the following provisions: 
1.  Adult Day Care Homes (by definition) are limited to providing service to no more than five (5) adults. 
2.  Adult Day Care Homes shall only be located within a single family detached dwelling unit that is owner occupied. 
3.  The residential character and appearance of the structure shall not be altered to accommodate the use except to provide a suitable means of egress and handicap accessibility. 
4.  In addition to the owner, one (1) full time non-resident employee shall be permitted. The employee's position shall be listed on the business license application (as well as the occupant) certifying compliance. 
5.  No more than one (1) vehicle may be used in conjunction with the business. Said vehicle must be stored in a carport, garage, or enclosed in an area that is screened from the view of adjacent and/or adjoining properties. 
6.  Parking shall not be permitted within any required setback and must be located on premises. 
7.  Client drop off and pick up areas shall be located on site so as not to obstruct traffic flow on adjacent public and/or private streets. 
8.  Hours of operation shall be limited to the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m.; and no overnight accommodations shall be permitted. 
9.  During the hours of business activity, the total gross floor area of the dwelling unit may be devoted to the use. 
10.  All outdoor recreation areas located within fifty (50) feet of a residential use, shall provide a ten-foot landscape buffer consisting of a mix or evergreen trees and shrubs to provide a year round visual screen. 
( Ord. No. 786 , amd. 5, 3-16-2015) 
Sec. 10:5 - Child Day Care Center: RM-1 and RM Residential Districts; all Commercial Districts (excluding I-1 district). 
1.  When located in a residential zoning district, the maximum number of children to be cared for shall be limited to sixteen (16). 
2.  Off street parking shall be provided at the rate of: One (1) space per staff person and consultative person expected on the premises at any one (1) time, plus one (1) space for each six (6) children permitted. 
3.  Safe and adequate provisions shall be provided onsite to accommodate all drop-off and pick up activities ensuring a safe route from motor vehicle to the building entrance. 
4.  Child daycare facilities shall provide forty (40) square feet of available activity space per participant, inside the center (not including offices, bathrooms, kitchens, closets) and shall also provide a minimum outdoor play area of fifty (50) square feet per participant. 
5.  The entire play area shall be enclosed by a fence having a minimum height of four (4) feet, and constructed to provide maximum safety to the children. 
6.  A fifteen-foot landscape buffer shall be provided and maintained along all exterior property lines that abut a residential use. The landscape buffer shall consist of a mix of evergreen trees and shrubs that will be provide a year round visual screen. 
7.  Except as may otherwise be required by state or federal law, nothing herein shall allow or authorize the use of any daycare facility as: 
a)  A public or private hospital, retreat, institution, community residence, house or place where a mentally ill person, or a person who is alcoholic dependent or drug-dependent is received or detained as a patient or for treatment or rehabilitation; or 
b)  A community residence, halfway house, transitional house or other state or federally regulated facility to which persons are or may be transferred from correctional facilities or institutions. 
( Ord. No. 786 , amd. 5, 3-16-2015) 
Sec. 10:6 - Child Day Care Home-All residential districts. 
1.  Child Day Care Homes shall only be located within a single family detached dwelling unit that is owner occupied. 
2.  The residential character and appearance of the structure shall not be altered to accommodate the use except to provide a suitable means of egress and handicap accessibility. 
3.  By definition, a Child Day Care Home is limited to providing care to six (6) or fewer children. 
4.  Hours of operation shall be limited to the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m.; and no overnight accommodations shall be permitted. 
5.  During the hours of business activity, the total gross floor area of the dwelling maybe devoted to the use. 
6.  The building shall contain a minimum of thirty-five (35) square feet of floor area for each child present. 
7.  Client drop-off and pick-up shall be located on site so as not to obstruct traffic flow on adjacent public and/or private streets. 
8.  Parking shall not be permitted within any required setbacks and must be located on premises. 
9.  At least seventy-five (75) square feet of outdoor play area shall be available for each child present. Outdoor play shall only occur between the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. 
10.  The entire play area shall be enclosed by a fence having a minimum height of four (4) feet, constructed to provide maximum safety to the children. If the outdoor play area is within fifty (50) feet of another residential structure, a ten-foot landscape buffer shall be required at the rate of one (1) evergreen tree or evergreen shrub per five (5) linear feet of fence line. 
( Ord. No. 786 , amd. 5, 3-16-2015) 
Sec. 10:7 - Dwelling, Single Family Attached Housing: R-10, R-8 and R-6 and RM-1, RM Districts. 
a)  Single Family, Attached housing developments shall be subject to the following development standards based on the zoning district in which the development is proposed:
